channel.title: Quartz
channel.description: Quartz is a digitally native news outlet for the new global economy.

item.title: Napa Valley counts its losses
item.dc:creator: kevinjdelaney
item.content:encoded: Already hit hard by drought, Napa Valley's more than 500 wineries have been seriously affected by the 6.0 magnitude earthquake that struck California in the early hours on Sunday morning. Economic losses are estimated to be as high as $100 million for the valley, home to a $13 billion wine industry. The area faces a 54% chance of a big aftershock in the next week.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Jawbone, the maker of the UP fitness-tracking wristband, has data showing how much sleep its users lost in the quake, depending on how far they were from the epicenter. [caption id="attachment_254890" align="alignnone" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: Videogaming is no longer dominated by men.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/254534/video-gaming-is-no-longer-a-mans-world/

item.title: Cyber moths!
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Scientists at North Carolina State University can remote-control the flight of moths by placing electrodes in their muscles. This is a giant leap toward the creation of “biobots”—and, presumably one day, of Terminators.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jR325RHPK8o#t=70[/embed]

item.title: India throws a spoke in Uber’s wheels
item.dc:creator: kevinjdelaney
item.content:encoded: The central bank has closed a loophole that gave the online car service an edge over local radio-taxi companies. To pay for an Uber ride with a credit card, customers must now enter a code delivered by text message too. That’s a norm for Indian credit-card transactions that Uber had hitherto avoided.

item.title: No ransom for an American hostage in Syria
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The US says it paid no money to release Peter Theo Curtis, an American journalist kidnapped nearly two years ago in Syria who was freed Sunday. He was being held by Jabhat al-Nusra, an al-Qaeda offshoot; Qatar mediated his release. He originally entered Syria via Turkey, which is now under growing pressure to tighten its border with Syria to stop militants on their way to join ISIL.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Curtis's release comes just days after ISIL beheaded James Foley. A close look at Twitter has led British authorities to suspect Foley's masked killer is a rapper from London.

item.title: The takeaway from Jackson Hole
item.dc:creator: kevinjdelaney
item.content:encoded: The annual conclave of global economic policymakers is over. Fed chair Janet Yellen raised more questions than answers: The US job market is still weak, she suggested, but demographics and other structural issues make it hard to assess what’s really going on. The ECB’s Mario Draghi delivered a clearer message, urging European governments to embrace more fiscal stimulus to spur growth on the continent.

item.title: Iceland’s volcano is all sound, no fury
item.dc:creator: kevinjdelaney
item.content:encoded: Despite intensifying earthquakes, the country’s Civil Protection Agency walked back a previous announcement that Bardarbunga was about to blow. Iceland’s last major eruption, in 2010, led to the cancellation of tens of thousands of commercial flights and cost the global economy an estimated $5 billion.

item.title: The ironies of Ukrainian independence day
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The country is marking its freedom from the Soviet yoke even as Russia tries to reverse it. As the Ukrainian army paraded in Kyiv, pro-Russian separatists countered with a provocative anti-independence show of captured Ukrainian soldiers. President Petro Poroshenko announced an additional $3 billion in military spending in response to a “constant military threat.”

item.title: Spy vs. Spy over the dark web
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: US and British intelligence agencies trying to hack Tor, the free software that allows users online anonymity, are being undermined by their own colleagues. A top Tor engineer told the BBC the tip-offs from spies allowed his team to fix holes in the software, protecting it against the NSA and the British GCHQ.

item.title: Richard Attenborough, director of "Gandhi" and other classic films, dies at 90
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: An actor, director and producer, his career spanned 74 years. His 1982 biopic of Mahatma Gandhi won eight Oscars and was one of his greatest achievements, but he was most familiar to moviegoers for his recurring role in Steven Spielberg's Jurassic Park trilogy.

item.title: Burger King wants to move to Canada
item.dc:creator: kevinjdelaney
item.content:encoded: The Miami-based burger chain said it is working on an acquisition of Tim Hortons, a Canadian coffee-and-donut chain. The deal would shift its official domicile to Canada—a so-called "tax inversion" to cut its overall tax bill. Buying Canada's equivalent of Dunkin' Donuts might also help Burger King in the fast-food breakfast wars.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Tim Hortons made its own move into the US in 2009, when it took over the locations of a dozen Dunkin' Donuts outlets in New York City. (In a taste test at the time, New York Times writers concluded that both chains' donuts were equally mediocre.) Businessweek recently profiled Burger King's youthful top management.

item.title: Malaysia Airlines may lay off one-fifth of its staff
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The national carrier is considering cutting 3,000-4,000 of its roughly 20,000 jobs, canceling some aircraft orders and shutting down some routes, sources have told Bloomberg. The government is working on a restructuring plan for the airline after two fatal disasters this year.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Jeremy Grant in the Financial Times on how the airline's structural problems are a microcosm of the country's (paywall):
Any airline would struggle in the aftermath of such tragedy. For the airlines’ employees it is especially hard to take because the carrier’s safety record was one of the best in the industry. But the events have exposed a deeper malaise at the airline that is emblematic of much that has long plagued Malaysia as it struggles to escape from a so-called middle income trap.

item.title: Sony recovers from a hacker attack
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Sony’s online PlayStation Network is back up Monday after “artificially high traffic” took it down over the weekend, along with other gaming websites and the Vatican's homepage. A group called Lizard Squad claimed responsibility for the outages while invoking "jihad." Sony said personal information about its 53 million users was not compromised.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Lizard Squad also said on Twitter there might be explosives on an airplane carrying Sony Online Entertainment head John Smedley over the weekend. The airplane was diverted and searched.

item.title: The French government disbands
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: French prime minister Manuel Valls announced the government’s resignation, and said he's been charged by president François Hollande with creating a create a new one. This comes after sharp criticism by the outspoken economic minister, Arnaud Montebourg, for new economic policies that are lighter on austerity. It's the second reshuffle in six months.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: "France is the eurozone's second-biggest economy, the world's fifth-greatest power, and it does not intend to align itself, ladies and gentlemen, with the excessive obsessions of Germany's conservatives," Montebourg said.

item.title: Japan offers an experimental Ebola drug
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: A senior official said favipiravir, an influenza drug developed by Fujifilm Holdings and US firm MediVector, could be made available to countries hit by the deadly virus. Also known as T-705, the drug is awaiting approval by the World Health Organization and the US Food and Drug Administration; the developers say they have enough for 20,000 patients.

item.title: ISIL takes a vital Syrian air base
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: The terrorist group, also known as the Islamic State, seized control of the Tabqa base, the government's last foothold in the northern province of Raqqa, after a battle that cost over 500 lives. The province, bordering Turkey, is now practically entirely under ISIL control. Gen. Martin Dempsey, chairman of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff, said he would recommend military action against the group if he determined it threatened the US homeland.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Tabqa is also the location of Syria's largest hydroelectric dam, which is now under ISIL control. The terrorist group has systematically taken control of vital infrastructure, in both Syria and Iraq. It briefly held the Mosul dam in Iraq, before being beaten back by Kurdish fighters and US air strikes.

item.title: Islamist militias claim Libya’s capital
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Islamist militias calling themselves "Dawn of Libya" said they have taken control of Tripoli (paywall), pushing back rival groups after a weekend of fighting that destroyed much of the capital’s international airport. The uptick in violence, the worst since 2011 (paywall), comes after Islamist parties lost elections in July.

item.title: Russia can't put the EU on its embargo hit list without hurting itself
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/254255/how-russia-can-hurt-the-west-an-embargo-hit-list-for-vladimir-putin/

item.title: Original Superman comic book sells for $3.2 million
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: An unidentified bidder on e-Bay has snagged a near-pristine 1938 copy of Action Comics issue No. 1 for a record $3.2 million. It features the first-ever appearance of the man from Krypton.

item.title: The S&P hits 2,000
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: After flirting with the milestone last week, the stock index finally passed it, hitting 2,000.27 on Monday morning before falling to 1,997.92 at the close—still a record high. However, the rising stock market disproportionately benefits the country’s most affluent households.

item.title: Hopes shift from ZMapp to Avigan
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: A senior Liberian doctor infected with Ebola who was treated with the experimental drug ZMapp has died from the disease. The drug had raised great hopes after apparently curing two American health workers. Japan is awaiting the WHO’s go-ahead to provide another experimental drug, Avigan, that it says could treat 20,000 patients. Developed by a subsidiary of Fujifilm Holdings, the drug is a product of the company's diversification from photographic film.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Japanese drug is favipiravir, an influenza drug developed by Fujifilm Holdings and US firm MediVector, also known as T-705. It was approved for use against influenza in March (meaning it's known to be safe), and has successfully cured Ebola in small animals.

item.title: A call for peace at Michael Brown's funeral
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: National, community, and police leaders were among the thousands in attendance at the funeral of Michael Brown,the unarmed black teen shot by police in Ferguson on Aug. 9. The service began at 11am Eastern time and was live streamed. Brown's father asked for peace and silence during his son's funeral.

item.title: Ukraine says a rebel armored column has opened a new front
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: The government in Kyiv says its forces are battling an incursion of armored vehicles bearing separatist insignia that entered from Russia, near the southern town of Novoazovsk; until now, most of the fighting between Ukrainian and rebel forces had been near the eastern border with Russia. Russian foreign minister Sergei Lavrov, meanwhile, said Moscow would send a new, unsolicited humanitarian convoy into Ukraine soon.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The last so-called humanitarian convoy from Russia raised tensions between the two countries; it looks very much as if Russia is using the convoys as a way to bring in arms or supplies for the separatists, and it has been refusing to let Ukrainian customs officials inspect the trucks or let the Red Cross escort them as Ukraine has requested.

item.title: Your olive oil is about to get even more expensive
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: A prolonged drought in southern Spain, combined with a hit to the olive crop in Italy, will trigger a sharp rise in olive oil prices this year. Half the world's olive oil comes from Spain, of which nearly three-quarters is from the drought-ridden Andalusia region. If rain doesn't come soon, the crop would be down 40% from last year.

item.title: Egypt and the UAE launched air strikes on Libya in secret
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The two countries teamed up to attack Islamist militias battling for control of Tripoli. They carried out air strikes twice in the past seven days without informing the US, senior American officials told the New York Times (paywall).

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Islamist militias who call themselves "Dawn of Libya" said they have taken control of Tripoli, pushing back rival groups after a weekend of fighting that destroyed much of the capital’s international airport. The uptick in violence comes after Islamist parties lost elections in July.

item.title: Amazon is getting its own YouTube
item.dc:creator: dfrommerqz
item.content:encoded: The online retailer has confirmed that it is buying Twitch, a web video service for videogame players, for almost $1 billion, as previously reported (paywall). Twitch is touted by some as "the next YouTube," and was previously in talks with Google, which owns YouTube. The move represents Amazon's increasing interest in web video, where YouTube dominates.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Information reports (paywall) that Twitch had signed a term sheet agreeing to be acquired by Google—which wanted it to "anchor YouTube's live strategy"—for more than $1 billion. But the Information cites anonymous sources saying the deal fell apart after a due-diligence process in which Twitch executives had concerns about how much independence they'd retain once acquired.

item.title: Ukraine is having early elections
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: President Petro Poroshenko dissolved the country's parliament, setting it up for early elections in October. The move was expected, as a way for Poroshenko to secure his position and pass laws weakening Russia's influence on Ukraine. Elections will take place October 26.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Dissolving parliament will probably only temporarily halt Ukrainian politicians' penchant for frequent brawls:

https://twitter.com/jamesharveytm/status/496898613252227072

The Washington Post's Rick Noack writes:

Some scholars believe that the frequent brawls express a serious underlying problem in Ukraine's political culture – a problem which could have big implications for the country's current crisis. "In the past, physical violence has often been used in the parliament to block procedures and to cause a gridlock," says Tarik C. Amar, an assistant professor specializing in Eastern European history at Columbia University. Physical violence as a way to prevent votes from being taken goes back to the years following the Orange Revolution in summer 2006 when Viktor Yanukovych came back to power. "The inability of many Ukrainian politicians to respect the parliament's basic rules could easily augment the polarization of the country," Amar predicts.

item.title: Israel is shelling Lebanon
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Israeli shells have landed in south Lebanon after two rockets were fired into northern Israeli towns. There was another rocket salvo in July, but so far there seems to be little sign that Hezbollah, which fought against Israel in 2006, is opening up a front again.

item.title: A Chinese satellite spots a giant field of weed
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The country's space agency says an advanced satellite launched last year, the Gaofen-1, has identified "the biggest known marijuana farm spotted since the founding of the People's Republic of China in 1949," reports the South China Morning Post (paywall), which also says a statement on the agency's website has since been taken down. The field might actually be a legal hemp farm.

item.title: Ukraine and Russia prepare to talk
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The two presidents are due to meet in Minsk today, but it's hard to see them having much to discuss. Russia has denied that armored vehicles bearing separatist insignia, which entered Ukraine from southern Russia on Monday, are in fact full of Russian troops, and is promising to send a second “humanitarian” convoy over Ukraine’s strenuous objections. Ukraine's president plans to dissolve Parliament and hold new elections in October.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The last so-called humanitarian convoy from Russia raised tensions between the two countries. It looks very much as if Russia is using the convoys as a way to bring in arms or supplies for the separatists, and it has been refusing to let Ukrainian customs officials inspect the trucks or let the Red Cross escort them as Ukraine has requested.

item.title: Investors love Burger King's Canada deal
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Bill Ackman’s hedge fund, Pershing Square, made $203 million after the fast-food chain's stock soared 20% on Monday on news that it is looking to buy Canadian chain Tim Hortons. Burger King plans to move its headquarters to Canada and cut its tax bill in the deal. The Wall Street Journal reports (paywall) that Warren Buffett is helping Burger King finance the roughly $10 billion takeover, which could be announced soon.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Quartz's Lily Kuo explains the logic behind Burger King's strategy:
Known as “tax inversion” deals, these arrangements allow companies to lower their overall corporate rate, and some use them to access cash held overseas while avoiding a hefty US tax bill. Health care companies like the Chicago-based pharmaceutical firm Abbvie are big fans—Abbvie bought UK drug maker Shire for $54 billion in July, one of the largest inversion deals to date and a move that could save Abbvie as much as $8 billion in taxes over the next 15 years.

item.title: Floods worsen in Bangladesh
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Half a million people have already been left homeless (paywall) by heavy flooding in Bangladesh, and the situation is expected to get much worse in the next 72 hours. A week of heavy rains has caused flash floods, destroyed villages, and washed out crops. Flooding in the monsoon season is common in Bangladesh, but climate change and rising seas are expected to worsen the problem in coming years, the Asian Development Bank said.

item.title: Scotland's "yes" vote gains steam
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Scotland's pro-independence leader Alex Salmond "steamrolled" opposition Alistair Darling in a Monday night debate, media and viewers agree—71% of Scots polled by the Guardian declared Salmond the winner. Whether that will provide enough momentum to propel "yes" voters to victory in the Sept. 18 referendum on Scotland's independence is still unclear, as they still trail "no" voters by a narrowing margin.

item.title: The US is tracking ISIL in Syria
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: The US has started surveillance flights over Syria to track Islamic militant group ISIL, the AP reports, after President Obama gave the go-ahead. Defense officials said Monday the US would use planes and drones to survey the group's movements, ahead of  possible airstrikes targeting the organization. The Syrian regime warned the US must coordinate any airstrikes with the acting government, but the US said it won’t ask Syria for permission.

item.title: Burning Man won't be a total washout
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Doors at the annual week-long desert celebration were shut on opening day yesterday due to "rain and standing water," organizers said, but will reopen today at 6am. The temporary delay has been a boost to tourism in Reno, Nevada, where hundreds of "Burners" decamped to wait out the storm, and DJs who were scheduled to play Burning Man set up in local clubs and bars.

item.title: Israel targets high rises
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Israel's air strikes are now targeting large residential buildings in Gaza, and have brought down five towers and shopping complexes since Saturday. The inhabitants of two buildings leveled today received warnings and were evacuated. One 13-story building housed 70 families. Egypt has called for Hamas and Israel to resume cease-fire talks.

item.title: Time Warner is cutting senior staff
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Time Warner’s broadcast division will cut more than 500 senior staff (paywall) as it tries to trim costs after rejecting a $71 billion offer from Rupert Murdoch in July. Turner Broadcasting employees 55 and over will be offered buyouts today, part of a bigger “Turner 2020” restructuring plan. In addition to lowering costs, the company hopes to boost ratings.

item.title: South Africa is growing again
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Despite a crippling strike that shut down its platinum industry, South Africa still eked out economic growth in the second quarter. Thanks to finance and agriculture, the country's GDP grew at an 0.6% annualized pace in the three months to June, reversing a 0.6% drop in the previous quarter. The mining industry recorded a 9.4% drop in the quarter, following a 25% plunge in the first three months of the year.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_255757" align="alignnone" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: The US is in its best mood since the crisis, but is still depressed when compared with the years that preceded the Great Recession
item.dc:creator: zachseward

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/255879/america-is-in-its-best-mood-since-the-crisis-i-e-mildly-depressed/

item.title: The Burger King-Tim Hortons deal has Warren Buffet's stamp of approval
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The billionaire investor's Berkshire Hathaway is financing the $11 billion burger-donut merger, which was confirmed today, to the tune of $3 billion, at a 9% interest rate. The combined company will be the world's third-largest fast-food group, with some 18,000 restaurants in 100 countries.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: With the planned move to Canada, the Burger King deal is the latest in a string of "tax inversions" by American companies. The scheme to lower the company's tax bill was cooked up by Burger King's fairly young management team. CEO Daniel Schwartz is 34, CFO Joshua Cobza is 28, and the head of investor relations Sami Siddiqui is 29.

item.title: A truce deal over Gaza
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Israel and Hamas have agreed to an open-ended ceasefire brokered by Cairo, after seven weeks of hostilities that have left 2,200 dead, most of them Palestinian. It includes an agreement to ease Israel's blockade on Gaza immediately, with talks on further measures in a month, including Gaza's demands for an airport and seaport and Israel's demands that Hamas disarm.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The truce comes after Israel began targeting large buildings with airstrikes, bringing down five towers and shopping complexes since Saturday. According to Gaza's health ministry, of the 2,133 Palestinians killed during the war, 577 were children.

item.title: Guatemala grapples with drought
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: In response to one of the country's worst droughts in decades, the government has declared a state of emergency in 16 of the country's 22 provinces. The drought has affected some 236,000 families, destroying staple crops and killing hundreds of cattle.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Drought is affecting a wide swathe of Central America this year, notes a report (pdf) from the US's National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration. [caption id="attachment_255929" align="alignnone" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: France unveils a new cabinet
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: France has a new government for the third time since president François Hollande became president just over two years ago. Hollande and prime minister Manuel Valls ejected left-wing rebels from the cabinet, most notably replacing the outspoken firebrand Arnaud Montebourg with Emmanuel Macron, a former investment banker.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Libération has a good rundown (link in French) of some of the new faces in the government. Among those who kept their jobs are finance minister Michel Sapin and foreign minister Laurent Fabius.

item.title: Ukraine and Russia agreed not to make things worse
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Russian president Vladmir Putin and his Ukrainian counterpart Petro Poroshenko will prepare a "roadmap for peace," Poroshenko said after their meeting in Minsk, but there was no "breakthrough" to resolve key differences. Earlier, Ukraine released videos of what it claims to be Russian soldiers captured on its side of the border, which could raise tensions further.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The talks began with Putin threatening to jeopardize trade (paywall) with Ukraine if Kyiv pursues closer ties with Europe, ostensibly for fear of European goods spilling over into Russia's market. The two leaders also agreed to revive stalled energy talks.

item.title: Behold, the Knee Defender
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: A flight from Newark to Denver was diverted to Chicago because a heated altercation over legroom got a little out of hand. The male passenger, 48, used a gadget called the "Knee Defender" to stop the woman in the seat in front of him, also 48, from reclining her seat.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
You can buy your very own Knee Defender. Though it's been around for years, this is the first time it's made headlines. [caption id="attachment_256059" align="alignnone" width="320"] Gizmodo[/caption]   Gizmodo writes:
A pair of plastic braces—which cost only $21.95—are inserted on the passenger's tray table arms to prevent the seat in front of them from moving backwards. Airlines spoke out against the Knee Defender when it came out, but the FAA said they did not violate any specific rules. It even pretends to be polite: It comes with little courtesy cards you can print out and hand to the passenger in front of you to explain why their seat reclining feature is temporarily disabled.

item.title: An update on Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The US is one step closer to bombing Syria after it launched surveillance flights to track the Islamic State (IS), but Syria warned the US not to carry out any strikes on its soil. IS is demanding a $6.6 million ransom for an American hostage; it's unclear whether she is one one of the four missing Americans that Qatar is trying to free.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Meanwhile, Iran is helping Iraqi Kurdish forces fight the Islamic State in Iraq. The Obama administration faces multiple questions about how to address all this. John Cassidy writes in in the New Yorker:
Absent a formal agreement with Assad, the United States could simply ignore his objections and press ahead with strikes on ISIS targets in Syria, using drones or cruise missiles launched from outside Syria. Ultimately, however, the U.S. can’t bomb its way to victory over the jihadists. The real keys to success lie in mobilizing the Kurdish and Iraqi forces to repel the jihadist fighters, engineering some sort of resolution to the disastrous Syrian civil war, and closing down ISIS’s international support network. That means keeping up the pressure on Iraqi politicians to form a more representative national government, trying to resurrect the Syrian peace talks, and, perhaps, sending more U.S. military trainers into Iraq. It also means exerting some real pressure on U.S. allies in the region that have been enabling and financing the jihadists inside Syria: Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and Turkey come to mind. Without the support, or the tacit encouragement, of any sovereign state, ISIS would be a much weaker force.

item.title: The S&P 500 closed above 2,000
item.dc:creator: mattphillipsqz
item.content:encoded: It's the first time ever the broad gauge of US stocks has closed above that level (on Monday it blipped past 2,000 but closed below it). But the market gained only 0.1% on the day, despite consumer confidence hitting a new post-crisis high.

item.title: Snapchat and OtterBox draw rich valuations
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The Wall Street Journal reports (paywall) that Silicon Valley venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins has agreed to invest up to $20 million in the photo-messaging service, which has almost no revenue, valuing Snapchat at $10 billion. Reuters reports that Otter Products, which makes OtterBox protective cases for mobile phones, is exploring a sale that could value the company at $2.5 billion.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Snapchat's fast growth and ability so far to fend off formidable competition may mean a $10 billion valuation isn't crazy. For those needing a refresher, Alexis Madrigal last year tackled "What is Snapchat?" in The Atlantic. His summary:
Snapchat is a photo-sharing service with one key distinguishing feature: the photos you send disappear. Seconds after opening "snaps," users can no longer access them and the images are deleted from the company's servers. Snapchat is an ephemera generating and sharing machine.

item.title: Apple is making an even bigger iPad
item.dc:creator: dfrommerqz
item.content:encoded: An iPad with a 12.9-inch screen is set to begin production by early next year, Bloomberg reports. (Current iPads are 8 and 10 inches.) The oft-rumored “iPad Pro”—likely to carry a larger price tag, too—seems likely aimed at business users. Microsoft recently launched a 12-inch Surface tablet.

item.title: Climate change is hitting Russia with a vengeance
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/256020/russias-warming-faster-than-the-rest-of-the-planet-and-seeing-disease-drought-and-forest-fires-as-a-result/

item.title: A busy day for the milk industry
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: New Zealand's Fonterra, the world's largest dairy exporter, announced a deal to buy a stake in Beingmate, a Chinese infant-formula maker. Fonterra was badly hurt by its previous foray into China, when its partner at the time, Sanlu, sold contaminated formula linked to the deaths of six children in 2008.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Fonterra also announced a major expansion of its processing capacity and reaffirmed its milk-price forecast for the 2014-15 season. The Kiwi dollar and other local markets rallied on the news, as investors looked for better news from the country's large dairy industry, which has suffered from a 40% fall in wholesale milk prices so far this year. [caption id="attachment_256433" align="alignnone" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: Christine Lagarde is being investigated
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: The IMF head is under a formal probe by a French court for her alleged role in the French government's 2008 payout to businessman Bernard Tapie, when she was finance minister. Tapie was awarded $527 million to settle a share sale dispute with Credit Lyonnais; investigators allege the payment was linked to his support for then-president Nicolas Sarkozy.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The New York Times explains what this might mean for Lagarde:
In the French legal system, a formal investigation suggests prosecutors believe they have enough of a case that they may ultimately bring criminal charges and trial. The reality is that many such investigations drag on for years with no charges being filed before being dropped.

item.title: There's merit to Ebola jokes
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Joking about Ebola has become a coping strategy for people in Africa stricken with the disease, Bloomberg reports. From Facebook quips about curfews that keep straying husbands at home to YouTube videos of the "Ebola handshake," the jokes help to spread knowledge of the disease and help people regain their humanity, sociologists say.

item.title: Millions of Americans woke up to no internet
item.dc:creator: zachseward
item.content:encoded: Time Warner Cable, the nation's second-biggest internet provider, suffered an outage across the US, including its key markets of New York and Los Angeles. The company said its services "were largely restored" as of 8am EDT, but some of its 11.4 million internet customers still reported issues.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The company's statement:
At 430am ET this morning during our routine network maintenance, an issue with our Internet backbone created disruption with our Internet and On Demand services. As of 6am ET services were largely restored as updates continue to bring all customers back online.
Map of the outage: [caption id="attachment_256495" align="alignnone" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: Labor doesn't pay like it used to
item.dc:creator: zachseward

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/257222/us-workers-kick-off-labor-day-weekend-with-some-depressing-charts/

item.title: End of the beginning for Gaza
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: As an open-ended ceasefire seemed to hold, celebrations erupted in Gaza City while Israeli prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu faced strong criticism over his leadership during the seven-week war. But the true test for Gaza is in some ways just beginning, as Hamas will press Israel for permission to open the Rafah border crossing next month and start construction on a Gaza seaport.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The numbers are clear in Israel's most recent offensive in Gaza. 50 days of fighting, $6 billion in damage, and 2,169 deaths—2,100 of them Palestinian. But what isn't clear is what was gained from the war. Quartz's Tim Fernholz writes:
It’s not clear what Israel has earned from this battle besides the degradation of Hamas military capabilities and the promise that the moderate Palestinian Authority will take over the administration of Gaza. The cease-fire contains no details about future security concerns, especially compared to a cease-fire agreement proposed by US Secretary of State John Kerry that was ultimately rejected by Israeli leaders in July as too weak.

item.title: Zara's latest fashion faux pas
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The Spanish clothing retailer pulled a “striped ‘Sheriff’ t-shirt” that looks a little too much like a Nazi concentration camp uniform. The shirt was inspired by Western films, according to Zara. Naturally, everyone is now remembering its infamous swastika handbag.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Here is the kids' shirt that received all the complaints. [caption id="attachment_256613" align="alignnone" width="320"] [/caption] Zara apologized today on Twitter. https://twitter.com/ZARA/status/504559921472753665

@haaretzcom we honestly apologize, it was inspired by the sheriff’s stars from the Classic Western films and is no longer in our stores

— ZARA (@ZARA) August 27, 2014

item.title: Oil majors beat a retreat from Nigeria
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: A consortium of Shell, Eni and Total is selling $5 billion worth of oil assets to domestic buyers. The Financial Times calls it (paywall) a reaction to "growing theft and sabotage" in a country shaken up by Boko Haram, but could it also be because the US shale boom is dinging Nigerian exports?

item.title: Jack Ma is China's richest man
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The chairman and founder of Chinese e-commerce firm Alibaba has a net worth of $21.8 billion, $5.5 billion more than "Pony" Ma Huateng of Tencent, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. Just imagine what he could be worth after Alibaba's US IPO later this year, which could raise more than $20 billion (paywall).

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Alibaba on Wednesday reported a 46% jump in year-on-year revenue and 26% jump in profit for the second quarter, but most interesting is that sales on mobile devices nearly quadrupled.

item.title: Fighters from al-Qaeda's Syrian franchise grab a border crossing with Israel
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: Members of the al-Nusra Front were among a group of rebels who seized the Quneitra crossing in the Golan Heights after a fierce battle with Syrian forces, an NGO reported. An Israeli officer was injured in stray fire.

item.title: An experimental Ebola vaccine
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: As two more health workers fell victim to the virus in Sierra Leone, curbing the outbreak is posing to be a challenge. An experimental vaccine in the works, by GlaxoSmithKline, and will begin safety trials on humans as early as next week.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Joking about Ebola has become a coping strategy in Africa, Bloomberg reports, as well as an incidental way to spread knowledge about the disease. Wives quip that it keeps their husbands at home, and the "Ebola handshake" is now, apparently, a thing: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AW7gCxn5X6Q

item.title: Erdogan gives his last speech as PM
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Turkish prime minister and president-elect Tayyip Erdogan said today was the birth of "a new Turkey," in a farewell speech to his AK party before his formal inauguration tomorrow. He said the goals and ideals of his party would carry on in his new role as president and change only in "form," not "essence."

item.title: Just what the Ukraine conflict needed: a third front
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: After presidents Petro Poroshenko of Ukraine and Vladimir Putin of Russia agreed to focus today's talks on a "roadmap for peace," tensions flared again when Ukraine accused Russia of opening up a new front in the fighting, saying activity by Russian forces in a southeastern border town amounted to an invasion (paywall).

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The alleged entrance into the southeastern town raises new fears for the violence in Ukraine. The Associated Press writes:
Novoazovsk, a resort town of 40,000 on the Sea of Azov, lies in a strategically significant location -- on the road linking Russia to the Ukrainian port of Mariupol and onto Crimea, the Black Sea peninsula Russia annexed. Wednesday's incursion, reported by the town's mayor, was the first time in the four-month-long conflict between the government in Kiev and separatists in the east that fighting has reached as far south as the seacoast. It suggests that the rebels -- who Ukraine, NATO and Western nations all say are being supported by Russia -- have been both emboldened and reinforced. The new southeastern front also raised fears the separatists are seeking to create a land link between Russia and Crimea. If successful, it could give them or Russia control over the entire Sea of Azov and the gas and mineral riches that energy experts believe it contains. Ukraine already lost roughly half its coastline, several major ports and significant Black Sea mineral rights in March when Russia annexed Crimea.

item.title: Apple's iWatch is imminent
item.dc:creator: dfrommerqz
item.content:encoded: The company "plans to unveil a new wearable" at its iPhone event on Sept. 9, according to Re/code. While the so-called iWatch has been expected for a while, surprisingly little is known about it. Some basic questions: What will it do? And what does it look like?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: We're betting that it won't look like any of the concept designs. [caption id="attachment_256789" align="alignnone" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: More horrors from the Islamic State
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Pictures on social media found today show the militants executing Syrian soldiers captured at Tabqa air base, which IS took at the weekend. The US has been gathering a coalition to fight IS, but it won't act without allies. A UN report says both IS and Syria are committing war crimes.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The mother of Steven Sotloff, an American journalist held by IS, has made a video appeal directly to its leader, reports the New York Times:
“I am sending this message to you, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi al-Quraishi al-Hussaini, the caliph of the Islamic State. I am Shirley Sotloff. My son Steven is in your hands,” she begins. “You, the caliph, can grant amnesty. I ask you please to release my child,” she continues. “I ask you to use your authority to spare his life.”

item.title: Did Russia hack US banks?
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The FBI is investigating a hacking attack in mid-August that lifted data from JPMorgan and at least four other banks, Bloomberg reports. The sophistication of the attack suggests the hand of a government, and the FBI suspects it could be retaliation for US sanctions on Russia, but cyber-criminals have not been ruled out.

item.title: Don't Hyperlapse and drive
item.dc:creator: javinsqz
item.content:encoded: Instagram's new Hyperlapse app, which creates quality time-lapse videos, is the second standalone app Instagram has released since being acquired by Facebook in 2012. Many have pointed out how perfectly the technology will lend itself to the upcoming New York Fashion Week, but users around the world found an equally compelling, if quotidian subject: their commutes.

item.title: Microsoft's CEO heads to China
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Satya Nadella will visit China in late September, Reuters reports, after Chinese officials accused the company's Windows operating system and Office software of violating anti-monopoly laws. In July, dozens of investigators raided Microsoft's 0ffices in China, Windows 8 has been forbidden at state-run companies, and state television warned this summer that the operating system could be a national security threat.

item.title: Kia Motors plans a Mexico plant
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: The South Korean automaker plans to build a $1 billion assembly plant in the northeastern state of Nuevo León. The plant will add about 10% to Kia's current global manufacturing capacity, and produce  300,000 compact cars a year when it is completed in 2016.

item.title: More grim news about euro zone banks
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Business loans have been shrinking for 26 months in the euro zone, according to the latest data from the European Central Bank. Some analysts expect the ECB to unveil new stimulus measures—possibly full-blown quantitative easing—at its meeting next week, on top of a program of cheap credit for banks that it has already announced.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_257001" align="alignnone" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: A new front opens in Ukraine
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The Ukrainian military is under heavy attack along its southeastern coast, according to local officials. Pro-Russian rebels are pushing towards the port city of Mariupol, supported by regular Russian troops who have volunteered to fight while "on leave" from their regular duties, according to a separatist leader.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Ukraine's National Security and Defense Council has published a map detailing the latest flashpoints in the fighting. The US State Department has also expressed its worries about the incursions along the coast, which it claims are being directed by the Kremlin:
I’ll also note that we are – and I’m not sure many of you have seen this – but we’re also concerned by the Russian Government’s unwillingness to tell the truth even as its soldiers are found 30 miles inside Ukraine. Russia is sending its young men into Ukraine but are telling – are not telling them where they’re going or telling their parents what they’re doing. We’ll also note reports of wounded Russian soldiers in a St. Petersburg hospital and that other Russian soldiers are returning home to Russia for burial. These are not steps that certainly you take when you are operating in a transparent manner.

item.title: Would you like a cat with your mortgage?
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Sberbank, Russia's largest lender, is offering an unusual perk to homebuyers—if you take out a loan with the bank, it will throw in a free cat. Mortgage borrowers don't get to keep the feline, but bank officials will bring one of 10 cats to wander around a newly-purchased property before the new owners enter, which according to Russian superstition is thought to bring good luck.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4boS_2z5KKg

item.title: Samsung and LG announce new smartwatches ahead of Apple
item.dc:creator: dfrommerqz
item.content:encoded: Samsung's latest can make and receive calls without a phone, Reuters reports. LG's is round with a retro look. With Apple reportedly set to unveil a wearable gadget on Sept. 9, the question is: Will it be anything like these?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Here is what LG's smartwatch looks like: [caption id="attachment_257213" align="alignnone" width="320"] LG[/caption] And here's Samsung's: [caption id="attachment_257215" align="alignnone" width="320"] Samsung[/caption]

item.title: The US economy is peppier than we thought.
item.dc:creator: mattphillipsqz
item.content:encoded: The economy expanded at a 4.2% annual clip in the second quarter, faster than the 4.0% rise first reported. A burst of business spending helped push economic output up.

item.title: The record number of Ebola cases could get worse
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The World Health Organization said the 3,069 reported Ebola cases—and 1,552 deaths—will continue to accelerate and eventually surpass 20,000 cases. An experimental vaccine to curb the outbreak is in the works. The effort, by GlaxoSmithKline,will begin safety trials on humans as early as next week.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The virus isn't just taking a toll on those infected, it's also taking a toll on business in quarantine zones and across the continent. The Guardian writes:
Rural farmers like Kallon – whose rice, cocoa and cassava fields account for nearly half Sierra Leone's gross domestic production – are among the hardest-hit in the economic fallout of the world's biggest Ebola epidemic. The repercussions have radiated from these far-flung villages to the country's financial markets, prompting cutbacks by multinational firms whose revenues had previously spurred double-digit growth and allowed Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea painstakingly to rebuild their war-shattered economies over the last decade.

item.title: Dollar General chases after Family Dollar
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Family Dollar rejected Dollar General's takeover bid last week in favor of one from smaller rival Dollar Tree, but Dollar General isn't giving up. The discount chain says it will pursue the deal, undeterred by antitrust concerns raised by Family Dollar. The update comes in Dollar General's quarterly earnings release.

item.title: Erdogan is sworn in as Turkey's president
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: He immediately appointed Ahmet Davutoglu, his longtime foreign minister, as acting prime minister. The two men oversaw Turkey's rise—and fall—as a regional power and now face grave foreign-policy challenges.

item.title: Carnage and capture in Syria
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: President Barack Obama said the US does not yet have a strategy to tackle the terrorist group known as the Islamic State in the Middle East, in a statement from the White House today. Islamic State militants claimed they executed hundreds of members of the Syrian army, after seizing an airbase in the northeast. In the south, the UN said 43 of its peacekeepers were captured by "an armed group" on the Syrian side of Golan Heights; 81 other peacekeepers are trapped.

item.title: Another twist in the T-Mobile US ownership saga
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Deutsche Telekom, T-Mobile's biggest shareholder, would listen to offers for the fourth-largest US wireless carrier worth $35 a share, Bloomberg reports. That is below the $40 a share Sprint was expected to offer before it walked away, but above the $33 a share offer France's Illiad has put on the table. Reuters, citing its own sources, has contested the report.

item.title: Europe's banking system is doing it wrong
item.dc:creator: mattphillipsqz
item.content:encoded: Lending continues to contract in the euro zone, with loans to the private sector falling 1.6% in July compared to the prior year. Business lending is shrinking at an even faster clip, dropping  2.3% in July compared to the prior year. Not exactly a recipe for dynamic growth.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_257309" align="aligncenter" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: The NFL gets tough on domestic violence
item.dc:creator: zachseward
item.content:encoded: America's richest sports league said players will be suspended for six games after their first offense of domestic violence or sexual assault, and face a lifetime ban after the second. Commissioner Roger Goodell apologized for the two-game suspension dealt to a player accused of assaulting his fiancée. "I didn't get it right," Goodell wrote to team owners.

item.title: This hidden leading indicator tells us that the US job market is getting even stronger
item.dc:creator: mattphillipsqz
item.content:encoded: Each month we spotlight the so-called "jobs differential," and indicator that's buried in the Conference Board's monthly update on US consumer confidence. The jobs differential is basically the difference between the number of people who said jobs were “hard to get” and those who said jobs were “plentiful” in the the non-profit research group's monthly consumer sentiment survey. The jobs differential is considered a pretty good leading indicator of the job market’s health. (The official US jobs report is due a week from tomorrow, on Sept. 5.) And it has been falling fast—a good sign—in recent months. In August, it fell to 12.4, a new post crisis low, from 15.3 in July. This is an indication that job creation has been so robust that regular Americans are starting to notice. Essentially, Americans now feel jobs are about as hard to get as they were during early 2004, when the US economy was really starting to gain traction after the recession of the early 2000s.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_257419" align="aligncenter" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: Get ready for a bumper harvest.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: After interviewing locals, measuring ears, and counting bean pods in the rural US midwest, "crop tourists"—it's a thing (paywall)—have forecast record yields this year for corn and soybeans. The plentiful harvest should help ease grain prices and restock other agricultural markets that aren't experiencing optimal weather.

item.title: Google has been running a drone delivery program for two years
item.dc:creator: kevinjdelaney
item.content:encoded: Dozens of Googlers are working on the Project Wing effort to build flying robots than can deliver products across a city in a few minutes, according to The Atlantic. The secret project is competitive with drone delivery research by Amazon and others.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The Atlantic's Alexis Madrigal describes the custom drone design Google is using:
During this initial phase of development, Google landed on an unusual design called a tail sitter, a hybrid of a plane and a helicopter that takes off vertically, then rotates to a horizontal position for flying around. For delivery, it hovers and winches packages down to the ground. At the end of the tether, there’s a little bundle of electronics they call the “egg,” which detects that the package has hit the ground, detaches from the delivery, and is pulled back up into the body of the vehicle.
Madrigal concludes:
Taken with the company’s other robotics investments, Google’s corporate posture has become even more ambitious. Google doesn’t just want to organize all the world’s information. Google wants to organize all the world.

item.title: Nearly 8% of Ebola deaths are amongst health workers
item.dc:creator: amerelliqz
item.content:encoded: Since the start of the Ebola epidemic in West Africa, 240 health workers have contracted the virus and 120 have died from it. The victims include five of the authors of a genetics study of the virus that was published today in Science. According to the World Health Organization, 1,552 people have died of Ebola since July.

item.title: Abenomics takes a hit
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Japan's inflation rate held steady in July, household consumption dropped 5.9% for the month from the previous year, almost twice the expected loss, and the jobless rate unexpectedly spiked. The recovery in Japan's job market may have run its course (paywall).

item.title: Volcanoes in Iceland and Papua New Guinea are erupting
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Due to the lack of volcanic ash, Iceland's authorities have reopened airspace over the volcano Bárðarbunga, which had been closed after a fissure eruption began just after midnight. However, airspace near Papua New Guinea has been disrupted as Mount Tavurvur spewed ash as high as 60,000 feet (18 kilometers) and forced Qantas Airways to divert three flights.

item.title: Malaysia Airlines will delist, slash staff
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Malaysia Airlines will fire 6,000 to 14,000 employees, and delist from the Kuala Lumpur exchange, state-run investor Khazanah Nasional said today. The company was struggling even before two tragedies this year—Khazanah Nasional said it will return to profitability in three years.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Malaysia Airlines also reported a net loss of 307 million ringgit ($97.4 million) for the quarter that ended June 30, versus 176 million a year ago.

item.title: Syria's humanitarian emergency
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: President Barack Obama said Thursday evening the US does not yet have a strategy to tackle the terrorist group known as the Islamic State in the Middle East. The UN said 43 of its peacekeepers were captured by "an armed group" on the Syrian side of Golan Heights; 81 other peacekeepers are trapped. Islamic State militants claim they executed hundreds of members of the Syrian army yesterday, after seizing an airbase in the northeast.

item.title: Upping the ante with Russia, Ukraine says it will seek NATO membership
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: Prime minister Arseny Yatsenyuk said he would ask parliament to give up the country's nonaligned status. NATO's secretary general said the organization would "fully respect" (paywall) Ukraine's potential application to join the alliance.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: NATO's secretary-general condemned Russia's "blatant violation of Ukraine's sovereignty," and called on Moscow to "cease its illegal military actions" in Ukraine. NATO also released satellite imagery of 1,000 Russian troops in Ukraine and said there are 20,000 Russian troops massed at the border look like “an offensive army.”

item.title: Bad news at Tesco means a shorter break for the new boss
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Britain's largest retailer—the third-largest in the world—issued its third profit warning of the year and slashed its dividend by 75%. The company's new boss, Unilever's Dave Lewis, will join the group next week, a month earlier than planned; he has his work cut out.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Tesco has been losing ground to German discount chains like Aldi and Lidl on its home turf, while operations abroad are shaky too—the retailer called time on an expensive, ill-fated foray into the US last year and has been writing down the value of its operations in eastern Europe in recent quarters. Its share price dropped by nearly 7% today; Tesco's shares are down by more than 30% so far this year. [caption id="attachment_257835" align="alignnone" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: The euro zone's deflation flirtation
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Inflation in the euro zone fell deeper into the "danger zone," as economic officials have described prices that are rising at less than 1% per year. Euro zone inflation rose by only 0.3% in August; worryingly, Italy tipped into outright deflation during the month.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The European Central Bank will meet next week, and the markets will be looking for hints of more aggressive stimulus beyond measures the ECB announced in June but have yet to kick in—including, possibly, full-blown quantitative easing. Don't hold your breath, say analysts at Bank of America Merrill Lynch:
Recent developments should be enough, in our view, to implement a new round of QE, and we think the ECB should have taken this route long ago. However, we still do not see full conviction in the governing council (and, as we have been suggesting, there is uncertainty on whether when the ECB acts it will be too little, too late).

item.title: Modi's India is showing momentum
item.dc:creator: mattphillipsqz
item.content:encoded: India's economy grew 5.7% in the second quarter, compared to the same period last year. The increase was the fastest since the first quarter of 2012, and comes amid high expectations for newly installed Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Optimism has also driven a stock market surge, with the benchmark BSE Sensex up 26% so far in 2014.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_257725" align="aligncenter" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: Detroit gets a lifeline out of bankruptcy
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: Barclays Capital will raise $275 million to help the struggling city emerge from insolvency. Motor City has a long road ahead, though: the municipality is $18 billion in debt.

item.title: Brazil's economy has entered a pre-election recession
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: GDP shrank 0.6% in the second quarter as high borrowing costs and inflation hurt investment and consumer demand. First-quarter data was also revised to a 0.2% contraction; so, for the first time in more than five years, Brazil is in a recession. President Dilma Rousseff has slipped in opinion polls ahead of the Oct 5 general election.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The World Cup has played a part in damaging the country's economy. The focus on the sporting event hurt investment, while workers had more time off. Reuters reports:
Civil construction and manufacturing especially suffered during the second quarter, data showed. Brazil hosted the World Cup in June and July, which caused a slowdown at many factories and retailers as cities declared public holidays on game days to prevent logistical problems such as heavy traffic.

item.title: UK raises its terror threat level for the first time in three years
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: It was upped from 'Substantial' to 'Severe,' the second-highest of five levels, in response to events in Syria and Iraq, where at least 500 British nationals have traveled to join Islamist and rebel groups. The last time the level was set at 'Severe' was in 2011.

item.title: Another diverted flight over a legroom dispute
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: This time, it's international. A Paris-bound flight from Miami touched down in Boston after Edmund Alexandre, of Paris, got angry when the woman in front of him reclined her seat. He didn't have the Knee Defender, but the 61-year-old did chase after a flight attendant who tried to intervene.

item.title: As Time Warner gives up on Vice, A&E enters the fray.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Walt Disney and Hearst's jointly owned A&E Networks cable television group is nearing a deal (paywall) to buy 10% of Vice Media, the Financial Times reported. This comes hours after a New York Times report that Time Warner ended months of negotiations to acquire a stake in fast-growing Vice.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The reported terms of A&E's offer implies a valuation of $2.5 billion for Vice. That's a $1.1 billion increase from the valuation derived a year ago, when Vice sold a 5% stake to 21st Century Fox.

item.title: Ebola has reached another country
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Senegal became the fifth country hit by the Ebola virus, after a hospital in Dakar received a patient who had escaped the surveillance of health officials in nearby Guinea after being exposed to the virus there. Meanwhile, riots broke out in southeast Guinea, where infection rates are climbing.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The World Health Organization said the 3,069 reported Ebola cases—not including this recent one—and at least 1,550 deaths will continue to accelerate and eventually surpass 20,000 cases.

item.title: The US finds more sanctions violations
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: More than 25 people or businesses got penalized for evading sanctions against Iran. The Treasury Department targeted a Russian bank, an Iranian airline and other entities accused of helping Iran's weapons programs. Meanwhile the State Department sanctioned companies thought to have provided either support to Iran's petrochemical industry or means for weapons proliferation.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Some of the penalized companies include:
  • Asia Bank
  • Asian Aviation Logistics
  • Caspian Air
  • Dettin SpA
  • Faylaca Petroleum
  • Goldentex FZE
  • Jahan Tech Rooyan Pars
  • Lissom Marine Services
  • Mahan Air
  • Mandegar Baspar Kimiya Co.
  • Meraj Air
  • The Organization of Defensive Innovation and Research
  • Nuclear Science and Technology Research Institute
  • Pioneer Logistics

item.title: California Bay Area earthquake broken wine
item.dc:creator: kevinjdelaney
item.content:encoded: Janelle Dahl and her son Austin clean up broken bottles of wine in a tasting room after an earthquake at Dahl Vineyards Sunday, Aug. 24, 2014, in Yountville, Calif. A large earthquake rolled through California's northern Bay Area early Sunday, damaging some buildings, igniting fires, knocking out power to tens of thousands and sending residents running out of their homes in the darkness. (AP Photo/Eric Risberg)

item.dc:creator: jasonqz
