item.title: California blue whales are back from the brink of extinction.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: Researchers say there are 2,200 of these creatures, the largest mammals on the planet. That's 97% of historical levels; they were on the verge of being wiped out before a 1966 ban on whaling. There are so many blue whales now, they face a new challenge: collisions with ships.

item.title: Somalia on alert as al-Shabab names a new leader.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: The national security minister said there was evidence the terrorist group was planning attacks, in revenge for the killing of Ahmed Abdi Godane in a US airstrike. Al-Shabab named Abu Ubeid Ahmed Omar his successor.

item.title: Ukraine ceasefire seems to be holding.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: Leaders of both countries promised spoke on the phone about ways to keep the truce going. But Moscow said it "will react" if the US and European countries impose new sanctions.

item.title: Wanted: 20,000 grocery workers.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: Kroger, the largest supermarket chain in the US, said it needs to speed up hiring to manage growth, raising its sales force to 375,000. The company has more than 2,600 stores nationwide.

item.title: For the first time, poll shows Scots favor independence from UK.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: With less than two weeks to go before the Scottish referendum, a new poll has pro-independence voters ahead for the first time—by 51% to 49%. This represents a dramatic turnaround: a month ago, the vote was 39% to 61%.

item.title: A new King of Kong.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Robbie Lakeman has achieved the world record for the highest-ever score on Donkey Kong, taking it from Hank Chien, a plastic surgeon who held the title for almost four years. Lakeman called Chien personally to break the news. You can watch the record being broken on Twitch.

item.title: US launches airstrikes to safeguard an Iraqi dam.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The strikes are to prevent militants from the Islamic State seizing the Haditha Dam. The dam sits on the Euphrates River and officials fear the possibility of Baghdad being deliberately flooded. President Obama is also preparing to present a case for broader military action.

item.title: A by-the-numbers breakdown of dirty money around the world.
item.dc:creator: tmcbeeqz
item.content:encoded: The global economy loses at least $1.18 trillion every year to corruption, representing roughly 0.6% of global GDP.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/261098/chart-the-trillion-dollars-the-global-economy-loses-every-year-to-corruption/

item.title: Japan's shrinking economy.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The country's second-quarter GDP plunge was revised down even further, to a 7.1% decline from 6.8%, as prime minister Shinzo Abe's tax hike hurt even more than expected. The shrinkage was due to a drop in both capital expenditure and consumer spending, putting pressure on the central bank to expand its stimulus program.

item.title: Encouraging signs for an Ebola vaccine.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: GlaxoSmithKline’s experimental vaccine was fully successful in trials on monkeys, according to findings published by Nature Medicine, clearing the way for human tests. The World Health Organization says preventive treatments for health workers in affected areas of West Africa could be ready in a month.

item.title: China's trade surplus sets a new record.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The world’s second-largest economy reported a record trade surplus of nearly $50 billion, as foreign sales rose by a better-than-expected 9.4% while imports decreased by 2.4%. The new data suggest that Chinese manufacturers are benefitting from Beijing's stimulus, but consumers are not spending as freely as before.

item.title: The end of an era at GE.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: GE has sold the century-old business unit that developed some of the world's first washing machines and toaster ovens. Sweden's Electrolux paid $3.3 billion for the business, disposed as part of GE's plan to "reshape and focus its portfolio" to emphasize industrial products over consumer goods.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This is GE's first electric toaster, the model D-12, from 1905: [caption id="attachment_261328" align="alignleft" width="320"] Just add bread.[/caption]

item.title: Will and Kate are pregnant again.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: "Their Royal Highnesses The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge are very pleased to announce that The Duchess of Cambridge is expecting their second child," the monarchy said in a statement. As with her first pregnancy, the former Kate Middleton is suffering from hyperemesis gravidarum, an extreme form of morning sickness.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The announcement of the pregnancy during the run-up to Scotland's independence vote inspired a number of witty rejoinders on Twitter. [caption id="attachment_261378" align="alignnone" width="320"] [/caption] [caption id="attachment_261377" align="alignnone" width="320"] [/caption] [caption id="attachment_261376" align="alignnone" width="320"] [/caption]

item.title: Signs of life in Spain's housing market.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Prices in Spain's hard-hit housing market posted an annual gain for the first time since 2008. This comes among other encouraging signs of a long-delayed economic recovery, but don't pop open the cava just yet—the average house price remains nearly 40% below its peak, and by some measures is still overvalued.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_261336" align="alignnone" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: The ceasefire in Ukraine is looking shaky.
item.dc:creator: tmcbeeqz
item.content:encoded: Ukrainian president Petro Poroshenko said he would secure the defense of frontline city Mariupol on his visit there today. The truce—agreed on Sept. 5 between Kiev and pro-Russian rebels—appears shaky, after a second night of fighting near Donetsk airport and the city of Mariupol. The UN now puts the death toll at over 3,000, including the victims of the MH-17 crash.

item.title: Tesla extends an olive branch to Toyota.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: Elon Musk, the electric car maker's chief executive, remarked in Tokyo that he “would not be surprised if there was a significant deal with Toyota and Tesla." Tesla has made batteries for some of Toyota's RAV4 electric vehicles, but that program is winding down and the two companies have been at odds about their approach to electric vehicles.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: With its plans to build its first hydrogen fuel-cell car next year, Toyota took a different road from Musk, who has called the fuel cell approach "bullshit." At Aspen in June, Toyota Manufacturing’s North American CEO Osamu Nagata said: "Gas-powered hybrid is still the most reliable and realistic solution. Hydrogen vehicles require another decade or two decades to become more popular. And battery technology requires another round of innovation to improve their range."

item.title: The prospect of Scottish independence spooks the markets
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/261355/scottish-independence-is-a-real-possibility-and-the-markets-are-spooked/

item.title: Switzerland might give Edward Snowden safe haven.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The country's attorney-general has ruled that, were the NSA whistleblower invited to Switzerland to testify about US government surveillance, he probably wouldn't be extradited to the US and might be able to seek asylum too. The official opinion says Switzerland doesn't extradite people for "political" offenses, Swiss media reported.

item.title: Al-Shabaab retaliates for the killing of its leader.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The militant group sent car bombs to blow up an African Union peacekeeping convoy and Somali government vehicles on a road near Mogadishu, after a US airstrike killed its leader, Ahmed Abdi Godane, last week. The attacks killed 12; al-Shabaab claims four Americans are among them, though there's been no other confirmation so far.

item.title: Billions of dollars are flying out of Brazil.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/261365/how-billions-are-sneaking-out-of-brazil-and-harming-development/

item.title: NASA will send your tweets into space.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: The 50 best tweets and InstaGram images with the hashtag #AsteroidMission will be included in the time capsule on the spacecraft known as OSIRIS-REx, which will launch in 2016. Participants must muse on the future of communications and space travel. Tweeting in Klingon is unlikely to give you an edge.

item.title: Obama's campaign against the Islamic State will take three years.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: It will last beyond the president's term in office, reports the New York Times (paywall). The current air offensive in Iraq represents the first phase. The second includes training and equipping Iraqi and Kurdish forces; the third, taking on IS forces in Syria. Obama will announce his new "game plan" against IS in a speech on Wednesday.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The new United Nations human rights chief, who is also the first Muslim to hold the position, said that IS fighters in were trying to create a "house of blood" by targeting minorities, and urged world powers to focus on ending the conflict.

item.title: Ebola is escalating in Liberia.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The World Health Organization says the epidemic is spreading fast in Liberia, with thousands of new cases expected over the next three weeks. The country has more Ebola patients than there are beds at treatment centers, leading to people being turned away. As a result, the UN agency says efforts to control the outbreak are "not having an adequate impact."

item.title: Iraqi parliament votes in a new cabinet.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: After weeks of political horse-trading, prime minister Haider al-Abadi's team is still lacking ministers for defense and interior. His divisive predecessor, Nouri al-Maliki, is one of three vice-presidents.

item.title: The EU approves new Russia sanctions but holds them in reserve.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The new measures will limit (paywall) three big Russian oil firms' ability to raise money on European markets, but won't take effect for a few days (pdf)—which means, effectively, no new sanctions as long as the ceasefire in eastern Ukraine doesn't collapse completely.

item.title: The iPhone 6 release is going to give a massive boost to air cargo.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/262064/asian-freight-carriers-are-licking-their-lips-at-the-expected-release-of-the-new-iphone-6/

item.title: Yep, Home Depot was hacked.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: It doesn't appear that customers' personal identification numbers were compromised, but the US home-improvements retailer said its payment security system was in fact breached at more than 2,000 stores in the US and Canada, confirming reports that surfaced last week. The store saw its shares drop 3 percent on the news.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: So what happens to stolen credit card data? Sometimes, it ends up in plain view, on data resale websites like these.

item.title: Big Cereal goes natural.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: General Mills, maker of Cheerios and Yoplait will pay $820 million in cash for the organic food company Annie's, offering a 37% premium over Monday's closing price. Organic brands are seen as an opportunity for large food companies faced with sluggish growth prospects.

item.title: A nine-year prison term for insider trading that netted $275 million.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Matthew Martoma, a portfolio manager for SAC Capital Advisors (now Point72 Asset Management), was sentenced for his part in the most lucrative insider trading scheme in US history, which reaped huge profits from illegal trades on pharmaceutical stocks.

item.title: British retail is perking up.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: A surge in clothing and shoe purchases in August lifted retail spending by 2.7% from a year ago. But there was little good news for Tesco, Britain's biggest retailer, which continued to lose market share to both down- and up-market rivals.

item.title: Ikea puts together a solid quarter.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The privately-held furniture giant's sales for the year to August were up 5.9% at €28.7 billion ($37 billion), with like-for-like sales up 3.6%. China is the company's fastest-growing market but Ikea said the US and Europe were also performing well.

item.title: Google's EU antitrust deal is looking shaky.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Regulators want Google to amend a preliminary deal that was reached in February, after Microsoft and other European competitors complained that it was overly generous to the US search giant. The EU is now pushing Google to make deeper changes to its search algorithm to give competing services a higher billing, and has begun a preliminary investigation of its Android smartphone operating system.

item.title: A Japanese e-commerce firm makes further inroads into the US.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Rakuten, which has already bought online retailers Buy.com and Play.com, has agreed to acquire e-commerce rebate company Ebates for $1 billion. The deal is part of a wave of global investments made by Japanese companies looking for growth beyond their stagnant home market.

item.title: First results of the investigation into the MH17 crash.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The Malaysia Airlines flight that was shot down over eastern Ukraine in July broke into pieces in the air after it was damaged by "a large number of high-energy objects," according to a preliminary report by the Dutch Safety Board. Investigators did not attempt to assign blame, but the report's findings are consistent with the leading theory that MH17 was brought down by a ground-to-air missile.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
A key passage from the full report (pdf):
As yet it has not been possible to conduct a detailed study of the wreckage. However, the available images show that the pieces of wreckage were pierced in numerous places. The pattern of damage to the aircraft fuselage and the cockpit is consistent with that which may be expected from a large number of high-energy objects that penetrated the aircraft from outside. It’s likely that this damage resulted in a loss of structural integrity of the aircraft, leading to an in-flight break up. This also explains the abrupt end to the data registration on the recorders, the simultaneous loss of contact with air traffic control and the aircraft's disappearance from radar.

item.title: Greenhouse gases hit an all-time high.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: In particular, levels of carbon dioxide grew at the fastest rate ever in 2013, according to the World Meteorological Organization, reaching 396 parts per million, up 2.9 ppm from 2012. “Pleading ignorance can no longer be an excuse for not acting,” said WMO secretary-general Michel Jarraud.

item.title: UK leaders scramble to keep the Kingdom united.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Another poll of likely voters called the Scottish independence referendum a statistical dead heat. In response, pro-union parties all backed a plan unveiled by former prime minister Gordon Brown for the devolution of more powers to Scotland if it remains part of the UK. The pro-independence campaign says the plan smacks of "utter panic."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Prime minister David Cameron, deputy prime minister Nick Clegg (leader of the Liberal Democrats), and Labour leader Ed Miliband will all skip the weekly Prime Minister's Questions at parliament on Wednesday. Instead, they will travel to Scotland to try to win back voters, according to a joint statement:
There is a lot that divides us - but there's one thing on which we agree passionately: the United Kingdom is better together. That's why all of us are agreed the right place for us to be tomorrow is in Scotland, not at Prime Minister's Questions in Westminster. We want to be listening and talking to voters about the huge choices they face. Our message to the Scottish people will be simple: 'We want you to stay.' David Cameron, Ed Miliband and Nick Clegg.

item.title: Apple's big reveal.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Today’s event has begun. Here's how to watch it, but if you're having trouble with the live stream, try The Verge's live blog, instead. Apple is expected to unveil new iPhones with larger screens, some sort of wearable device, and a new mobile-payments system that some say will kill credit cards.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: So what exactly goes into these staged events by Apple? A lot, writes Quartz's Dan Frommer, who has done a breakdown of Apple keynotes in recent years: [caption id="attachment_261266" align="alignnone" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: Kashmir faces the worst rainfall in 50 years.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: 420 people have been killed and thousands are trapped on rooftops after flash flooding caught the authorities unprepared. The disaster is a test for both Indian prime minister Narendra Modi, for whom it's his first humanitarian emergency, and Pakistani prime minister Nawaz Sharif, who is under pressure to resign over claims of election fraud.

item.title: Atlantic City is losing more casinos.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Trump Entertainment Resorts is filing for bankruptcy (again) this week, adding to the swelling ranks of Atlantic City casinos in danger of closing. Three have already shut this year as gambling has expanded in neighboring states; the Trump closures could bring the total jobs lost this year to 10,000, one-fifth of the city's workforce.

item.title: People almost everywhere think the economy is terrible.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: A Pew Research Center survey of people in 44 countries confirms that most nations are gloomy about their economic conditions and prospects. But it wasn't all bad. Countries with a preponderance of optimists over pessimists included Germany, Israel, China, and—more intriguingly—Uganda, Nicaragua, and Bangladesh.

item.title: Apple unveils a smartwatch.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The Apple Watch was billed as a timepiece, small computer, and "health and fitness device." It sports an unusual interface and, in a nod to fashion, six interchangeable bands. But the watch doesn't go on sale until next year. The company also revealed the iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus, which are thinner—but not that much thinner—and have larger screens than their predecessors.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_262381" align="alignnone" width="640"] [/caption] The phones have a new sensor, new processor, and improved camera. The iPhone 6 starts at $199 with a two-year cellular contract, and the base level iPhone 6 Plus is $299. Both go on sale on Sept. 19. (Our complete guide to the iPhone 6 has more details.) Apple Watch starts at $349. The company also unveiled Apple Pay for conducting credit card transactions with the new phones and watch—but only in the US. Apple shares are now in the red after initially rising on the news, but that is on track with most launch days.  The company's usual marketing prowess failed when its live stream of the event crashed for many people. Here's a 90-second video with highlights from the presentation: https://www.youtube.com/embed/jKkxKAdebho

item.title: The slow improvement in the US job market continues.
item.dc:creator: mattphillipsqz
item.content:encoded: US hiring in July rose to 4.87 million, the best level since late 2007. While the data is somewhat stale—the August US jobs report last week showed a somewhat disappointing 142,000 jobs were created—the numbers from the so-called Job Openings and Labor Turnover (JOLTs) report (PDF) confirm the underlying trend of slow improvement in the US labor market.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_262330" align="aligncenter" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: Let's not forget about the iPod and its role in Apple's resurgence.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/263306/a-memorial-for-the-classic-ipod-which-changed-apples-fortunes-forever/

item.title: Hacking: Bitcoin edition.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The email of Satoshi Nakamoto, the founder of bitcoin, has been hacked. The hacker, known as "Jeffery," is threatening to release secrets and even information on Nakamoto's shielded identity if someone transfers 25 bitcoin (the equivalent of around $12,000) to him.

item.title: Microsoft, meet Minecraft.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: This is going to be an interesting culture clash: Microsoft is nearing a deal to buy Mojang AB, the Swedish company that created the Minecraft video game, for more than $2 billion, the Wall Street Journal reported (paywall). The deal, which could reignite Microsoft's Xbox game business, may be signed as early as this week, according to the WSJ's anonymous source.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Minecraft went live in May 2009; by June 2014 it had sold 54 million copies on all platforms. It has spawned books, conferences (and even scam conferences), a Hollywood movie-in-the-making, and a near-perfect digital facsimile of Denmark.

item.title: Will Obama call for bombing Syria?
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The US president will deliver a speech on Wednesday outlining his strategy against the Islamic State. He has already signaled he might authorize airstrikes without congressional approval, and a new poll shows most Americans would support them, while another poll shows growing (albeit still minority) support for a more active US foreign policy in general.

item.title: Jamie Dimon is doing well.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The JPMorgan Chase CEO is "feeling fine" during his treatment for throat cancer, said Marianne Lake, the bank's chief financial officer. Dimon disclosed his diagnosis on July 1 and said he would undergo eight weeks of treatment. With his travel curtailed, he appears to have more time to work closely with his executive team.

item.title: Greenhouse gases hit an all-time high.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Levels of carbon dioxide grew at the fastest rate ever in 2013, according to the World Meteorological Organization, reaching 396 parts per million, up 2.9 ppm from 2012. “Pleading ignorance can no longer be an excuse for not acting,” said the WMO’s head.

item.title: The internet is slowing down.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Or will seem to today, if you’re using one of the sites (including Netflix, Etsy, Reddit, and WordPress) taking part in a protest against proposed US rules allowing telecoms to create “slow” and “fast” lanes. The sites won’t actually load more slowly; they’ll just pretend to with “spinning wheel of death” icons.

item.title: Venezuela’s state oil company is selling Citgo.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: PDVSA is seeking offers for its US refinery and storage business, according to Reuters, in a deal that could be worth $10 billion. Venezuela is suffering severe cash flow problems, although the government denies this.

item.title: China downplays foreign firms' crackdown concerns.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Premier Li Keqiang tried to assure multinationals that recent antitrust investigations are not singling out non-Chinese companies. He told a group of CEOs at the "Summer Davos" conference in Tianjin, China that “only 10%” of investigated companies are foreign.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: "I feel concerned that you are actually concerned," Li told foreign executives. "China's door has opened, and it will never be closed again."

item.title: Superstar DJs are making mistakes on purpose
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The practice known as "miss-mixing" is a way for DJs to to prove they are actually mixing songs live in an era when software can substitute for artistry. Those whose performances are suspiciously perfect may be labeled "‘sync button DJs.’”

item.title: The Libyan parliament’s new home is a ferry.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Legislators are taking refuge in a Greek ship anchored in a remote port city, after Islamists and their allies captured Tripoli and Benghazi.

item.title: Alibaba's IPO order book is full.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Chinese internet giant has already received enough orders to cover its entire offering, according to Reuters. The IPO is likely to best Facebook as the biggest tech offering ever, at $21.1 billion, and if underwriters exercise an option to sell additional shares it could raise up to $24.3 billion, making it the most lucrative IPO of any kind.

item.title: Santander's chairman dies.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The board of the the euro zone's largest bank by market capitalization will meet to appoint a new chairman after Emilio Botín passed away overnight. Botín died of a heart attack, aged 79. He joined Santander in the late 1950s, and became the third family member to run the bank; under his watch Santander transformed itself from a small, regional lender into a global player.

item.title: John Kerry lands in Baghdad.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The US secretary of state is in the Middle East to build political, financial, and military support to combat the Islamic State. He will meet with the country’s new Shiite prime minister, Haider al-Abadi, to encourage him to be inclusive towards Sunnis.

item.title: Obama calls for bombing Islamic State forces in Syria.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The US president will make a prime-time address about his plans to expand the fight against the extremist group, but he is still searching for ways to enlist regional allies and avoid helping Syrian president Bashar al-Assad.

item.title: The EU puts the foxes in charge of the henhouse.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The European Commission's new executive line-up makes France responsible for economic affairs and gives the UK oversight of financial regulation.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Former French finance minster Pierre Moscovici will be the economic affairs commissioner, where he is expected to push for less austerity and more growth-friendly policies. Somewhat awkwardly, earlier today France said it will miss its deficit target for next year. The UK's commissioner, Jonathan Hill, was given the financial services portfolio, an important concession to London's powerful financial lobby, as the country wavers over whether it wants to be in the EU at all.

item.title: Filipino Muslims could soon have their own autonomous zone.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: President Benigno Aquino III proposed a self-governing region in the southern island of Mindanao, to be called Bangsamoro. The move, supported by the US and Western governments, is part of a peace deal with the country's largest Muslim insurgent group, after 13 years of negotiations to end a four-decade-long rebellion.

item.title: Carl's Jr. is joining India's "burger revolution."
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: The US fast food chain's parent company signed a development agreement with the capital-based Cybiz BrightStar Restaurants to open 100 Carl’s Jr. burger restaurants in India, with talk of another 1,000 to come.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Sam Chopra, group chairman and founder of CybizCorp, calls India's current hunger for burgers "a parallel phenomena that was witnessed in the pizzas and pasta category a decade back." The chain will also offer Indians vegetarian options.

item.title: Will Obama authorize airstrikes in Syria?
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The US president will speak at 9pm US eastern time about his plans to expand the fight against the Islamic State, as he presses to enlist regional allies and avoid inadvertently strengthening Syrian president Bashar al-Assad's regime. Obama previously told Congress members he did not need them to authorize his strategy, which could include expanded operations in Iraq and potentially Syria.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A new poll shows as many as 71% of Americans would support airstrikes in Iraq and Syria, while another poll shows growing (albeit still minority) support for a more active US foreign policy overall.

item.title: David Cameron is down on his knees.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Ahead of the independence referendum in eight days, the British prime minister appeared close to tears as he told Scots he would be "heartbroken if this family of nations ... was torn apart." Cameron, along with the leaders of the two other major parties, is in Scotland to try to cajole voters out of seceding, after polls showed a possible win for the “yes” vote, and the pound slumped.

item.title: The Ebola death toll jumped by 200 in one day.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The World Health Organization announced that the death toll from the Ebola outbreak hit 2,296, rising by nearly 200 in just a day. There were 4,293 recorded cases as of Sept. 6, but that number doesn't reflect figures for Liberia, which is believed to have thousands more.

item.title: Dollar General takes its Family Dollar bid to the next level.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Dollar General is taking its $9.1 billion Family Dollar takeover bid directly to Family Dollar's shareholders. Dollar General warned it would do so if the revised bid, which offered to pay a $500 million penalty to allay Family Dollar's antitrust concerns, was rejected by the takeover target's management.

item.title: Combatants are stepping back in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Russia has withdrawn more than two-thirds of its troops from Ukraine, according to Ukrainian president Petro Poroshenko, even as Russian president Vladimir Putin continues to deny any involvement in the conflict. An additional wave of European Union sanctions against Russia have been put on hold.

item.title: Toyota is finally embracing Mexico.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The automaker is scouting the country for possible sites to open new factory plants, sources told Bloomberg. Toyota is the only remaining major auto producer globally to not have a full assembly plant in Mexico, which other automakers have flocked have embraced because of attractive trade agreements, cheap labor, and proximity to the giant US market.

item.title: The ozone layer is slowly recovering.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Earth's threatened ozone layer, which is responsible for blocking harmful solar radiation, has been subject to decades of destruction, until now. For the first time in 35 years, the ozone layer is showing its first sign of thickening, according to a new United Nations study. The discovery is a victory for international advocates working together to combat climate change.

item.title: Google's antitrust headache starts all over again.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: A settlement with EU antitrust authorities that took five years to reach—and which rivals thought too soft on Google—won't be finalized (paywall) before the EU shuffles commissioners at the end of October. A new probe into whether Google is abusing its effective monopoly in web search is likely to be more aggressive.

item.title: Could brunch be a golden ticket for McDonald's?
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The maker of the Egg McMuffin has applied to trademark the term "McBrunch," provoking speculation that there's a new front in the fast food breakfast wars. McDonald's applied for the same trademark in 2001 but never used it, and says it isn't testing any kind of brunch concept now, either.

item.title: Obama orders air strikes in Syria.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The US president will expand the US military campaign against the Islamic State, including attacks within Syria. Saudi Arabia has also agreed to provide a base to train moderate Sunni opposition fighters.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
In a primetime address on the eve of the September 11 anniversary, Obama vowed to hunt down IS fighters "wherever they are. ... That means I will not hesitate to take action against ISIL in Syria, as well as Iraq. This is a core principle of my presidency: if you threaten America, you will find no safe haven."
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KvRd17vXaXM

item.title: China's domestic demand falls short again.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Beijing's plan to save the economy by stoking consumer spending is on shaky ground. Consumer prices rose only 2% in August from a year earlier, down from 2.3% in July and well below the government’s target rate of 3.5%; producer prices also fell for the 30th consecutive month.

item.title: Google bought an intelligent spoon company.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Lift Labs makes an eating device for people with Parkinson’s and other tremor-causing ailments; financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. Google co-founder Sergey Brin has a genetic mutation that puts him at risk for the disease.

item.title: The Atlantic hurricane season is eerily quiet.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: For the first time since 2000, there are no named storms in the Atlantic at what is statistically the most dangerous time of the year.

item.title: China is urging the Dalai Lama to respect reincarnation.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: It’s part of a power struggle between Beijing and the Tibetan Buddhist leader. The Dalai Lama said in an interview earlier this week that he does not see the need for a successor; in Tibetan Buddhism's ancient history, the institution of the Dalai Lama only dates back to 1391.

item.title: India’s best tech schools produce more entrepreneurs than the Ivy League
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: Allegations of torture in Thailand.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Human rights groups Amnesty International and Thai Lawyers for Human Rights claim to have evidence that the military tortured detainees after enacting martial law in May. The groups accuse the army of staging mock executions, among other abuses; the junta said it found no evidence of torture.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Much more widespread, says the report, is the "climate of fear and a culture of enforced silence" created by the arbitrary detention of more than 600 people. Human Rights Watch reported on the "enforced disappearance" of an opposition leader last week.

item.title: Scottish banks look south.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: RBS and Lloyds—Scotland's biggest banks—would both move south of the border if Scotland votes to secede next week; some analysts expect them to move to England even if Scots vote to keep the union together. The banks say they are reacting to investor concerns about an independent Scotland: shares in both companies rose in early trading.

item.title: China wants help controlling the internet.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Lu Wei, China’s top internet regulator, called for governments around the world to join together and impose more rules on the internet in order to ensure its continued growth. "Every car has brakes," he told a World Economic Forum meeting in Tianjin. “Freedom and order, they are twins.”

item.title: People are always down about the economy.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/263401/humans-are-always-down-about-the-economy-in-three-charts/

item.title: Good luck with this one, Ghana.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The country will seek to sell at least $1 billion of government debt today at 8.375%, or 539 basis points over US Treasurys. That sky-high yield—double the premium for African bonds in general, and with an unusual 11-and-a-half year maturity—could tempt investors, but they should probably be cagey given the country just asked the IMF for a bailout.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius is not guilty of murder.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: But the 27-year-old South African athlete might still face a manslaughter conviction for killing his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, in 2013. The judge adjourned the court until Friday to finish reading her lengthy verdict.

item.title: The EU and US impose sanctions on Russia.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The US will join the EU in imposing a new set of sanctions on Russia aimed at punishing Moscow for its perceived role in destabilizing eastern Ukraine. The EU's measures, trailed earlier this week and taking effect tomorrow (pdf), will limit the ability of state-controlled oil firms to raise funds in Europe and bar European companies from selling the technology necessary to tap Russia's arctic, deep-water, and shale reserves, while the US will outline details of its next steps tomorrow.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Responding to reticence from Finland, Slovakia, and others, the EU stressed that it stood ready to "amend, suspend, or repeal" the sanctions if the ceasefire in Ukraine proved lasting. These are the details of the new measures (pdf).

item.title: In Japan, Burger King dresses its beef in black.
item.dc:creator: snarulaqz
item.content:encoded: The fast food chain has just introduced a "black burger,"  to be released nationwide in Japan (for a limited time) on Sept. 19. It's a version of an item Burger King sold there in 2012. The buns and cheese are blackened with bamboo charcoal, while the patties are darkened with black pepper and dressed with a squid ink sauce.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_263848" align="alignleft" width="320"] The Kuro Diamond comes with lettuce and tomato[/caption]

item.title: Big banks tell Scotland, "no."
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: RBS and Lloyds—Scotland's biggest banks—are threatening to relocate to London if Scotland votes to secede next week, in fear of financial uncertainty. The announcement comes hours after a poll showed a tiny lead for those in favor of staying in the union. Clydesdale Bank and insurer and asset manager Standard Life are also eyeing a move south.

item.title: The Arab world is joining the fight against IS.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Ten Arab states told US secretary of state John Kerry that they would join the US in its war against the Islamic State, “wherever it is, including in both Iraq and Syria.” Kerry is in Saudi Arabia seeking military, logistical, and intelligence support from Arab states, as well as help winning the goodwill of Arab people toward the cause.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: While the coalition with the US grows, Syrian and Iranian officials have slammed the Obama administration for excluding them. Meanwhile, Russia said military action without a UN Security Council resolution would be a "violation of international law."

item.title: Radioshack airs its woes.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The electronics retailer made its deteriorating finances very public in a filing today, which essentially said the company is running out of cash (paywall). Radioshack may end up in bankruptcy court if things don't improve, but in the meantime it is looking for ways to perk up its balance sheet, perhaps with a sale or a recapitalization.

item.title: The UN peacekeepers captured in Golan Heights are safe.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The 45 Fijian United Nations peacekeepers that were captured two weeks ago by the al-Qaeda-affiliated al-Nusra Front in the Syrian Golan Heights have been released, the UN says. The peacekeepers, grabbed during clashes between rebel and Syrian government forces, appeared unharmed when they arrived in Israeli-held territory. It is unclear whether a deal was struck for their release.

item.title: Scotland is giving Catalonia ideas.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Separatist groups around the world are drawing inspiration from Scotland's independence vote (paywall)—even though pro-unionist Scots have retaken a narrow lead ahead of next week's election. Up to 2 million people demonstrated in the Catalonian capital, Barcelona, yesterday to demand their own secession vote, though Spain is likely to block a proposed Nov. 9 referendum.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: a:3:{s:20:"restored_revision_id";i:264184;s:16:"restored_by_user";i:40000946;s:13:"restored_time";i:1410461988;}

item.title: Argentina has a plan to dodge a US court ruling on its debt.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The country's Congress has approved a proposal to pay back foreign creditors outside the reaches of a US court. The plan has been called illegal by the US judge who banned Argentina from paying back its more recent loans before it settles with the holdout creditors from the country's 2002 default. That ruling forced Argentina into another default in July.

item.title: The Apple Watch keynote really was the Tim Cook show.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/263965/was-apple-watch-keynote-good-enough/

item.title: Arabic gamers can now delve the linguistic complexities of "Guitar Hero."
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: With billions to be made in the Middle Eastern gaming industry, game console makers have finally given Arabic speakers what they've been asking for: Arabic language add-ons for popular games. Sony and Microsoft announced the packs at Games 14 in Dubai, the region’s largest video games convention.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Not every video game is worth translating into Arabic, said Paul Johnson, senior manager at the regional distributor Pluto Games. “You have to be careful over which games you decide to localise,” he said. “Anything that has nudity, sexual themes, drug use and alcohol, obviously is a no-no. They’re not going to localise Grand Theft Auto any time soon.”

item.title: Tech has become a lot cooler at Harvard since Mark Zuckerberg's undergrad days.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/264044/intro-to-computer-science-is-now-the-most-popular-course-at-harvard/

item.title: Yahoo shows some scars from its US privacy battle.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: According to unsealed court documents, the US government threatened to fine the tech firm $250,000 a day in 2008 if it refused an order to hand over large swaths of user data, which the company argued was unconstitutional. Yahoo lost its challenge to the order, and a subsequent appeal.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The defeats in the secretive foreign intelligence surveillance court meant Yahoo was forced to participate in the NSA’s controversial PRISM program, which gave the government extensive access to online communications—the program exposed by whistleblower Edward Snowden and shut down in 2011. In a blog post, Yahoo's general counsel, Ron Bell, says the company fought for today's document release:
We consider this an important win for transparency, and hope that these records help promote informed discussion about the relationship between privacy, due process, and intelligence gathering.
Bell said Yahoo will make the complete 1,500 pages of information available online.

item.title: Big donations for Ebola research.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen gave $9 million to support the fight against the disease that’s ravaging west Africa. Earlier this week the Bill and Melinda Gates foundation pledged $50 million to help stem the outbreak.

item.title: 1905_in_electric-toaster_l-sliced_0
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: GE's first electric toaster, the model D-12.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: /home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/558/39587363/files/2014/09/1905_in_electric-toaster_l-sliced_0.jpg

item.dc:creator: jasonqz

item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz

item.dc:creator: zachseward

item.title: Carl Icahn made inroads into Hertz.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Three of the activist investor’s nominees gained seats on the rental car company’s board, boosting its share prices in after-hours trading. Less than a month ago Icahn became the company’s largest shareholder, and at the beginning of the week he forced out its chairman and CEO.

item.title: Facebook gets a thumbs-down in China.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The social network “cannot” have access to the world’s biggest internet market any time soon, the country’s top internet regulator said on the sidelines of a World Economic Forum event in Tianjin.

item.title: Scotland swung back toward a “No” vote.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: A new YouGov poll showed supporters of maintaining the union have regained a 52-48% lead. The pollster's previous survey was the first to show the pro-independence camp in the lead, so the reversal is significant.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
YouGov president Peter Kellner explained the reversal on the company blog:
Responses to two questions tell us why Yes has now slipped back, albeit only slightly: it remains at a much higher level than at any point up to late August. We regularly ask people how they think independence would affect Scotland’s economy and their families’ own finances. During the Yes surge, optimism rose sharply and pessimism declined. Just one week ago, Scots divided evenly on whether their country would be better or worse off. Now, the pessimists, 48% (up six since last week), clearly outnumber the optimists, 37% (down three). And the proportion who think that they personally would be worse off under independence is up as much as eight points in a week, to 45% - the highest in a series that goes back to last December.

item.title: For the camel who has everything.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: A form-fitting leotard is being developed to help prize animals race faster and stand taller.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Al Shibla, a company previously known for its upmarket camel beauty supplies, is branching out and selling apparel. [caption id="attachment_264183" align="alignleft" width="640"] Does this come in slim-fit?[/caption]

item.title: Uber and Lyft's carpooling scheme is illegal in California.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The state's public utilities commission has ruled that the start-ups are violating the complicated laws regulating car services, dealing a blow to their newly launched ride sharing programs. As Recode notes, both Uber and its bitter competitor Lyft are known for acting first and dealing with regulations later.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius is guilty of "culpable homicide."
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: A judge has ruled that the South African sprinter known as "Bladerunner" killed his girlfriend accidentally, but acted negligently: "A reasonable person, with a similar disability, would have foreseen that the person behind the door would be killed, and the accused failed to take action to avoid this."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Pistorius now faces a maximum of 15 years in prison, although sentencing isn't expected for another six weeks. The athlete was also found guilty of firing a gun in a restaurant on a separate occasion, but was acquitted of pre-meditated murder and a second weapons charge.

item.title: Russia opts for growth over the ruble.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The country's central bank left its benchmark interest rate untouched, as the need to support the stagnant economy trumped pressure to stem rising inflation caused in part by Russia's ban on Western food imports. The economic doldrums were brought on by Western sanctions, which were ratcheted up today by the US.

item.title: A big solar flare hits Earth.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Power grids and satellite transmissions may experience irregularities, but there will be an upside: the aurora borealis will expand. Residents of northern New England, Canada, and the Pacific Northwest should have a good view.

item.title: Scotland swings back toward a “No” vote.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: A prisoner exchange in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Government and rebel forces gave up more than a dozen prisoners each as part of a tenuous ceasefire agreement. Rocket fire was heard from Donetsk soon after the swap had ended, putting the truce in doubt.

item.title: Pakistan says it has nabbed the men who shot Malala Yousafzai.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: The Pakistani schoolgirl and education activist who stood up to the Taliban in her region has become an international celebrity since she was shot in 2012 on her way home from school, at the age of 14. Pakistani army representatives told press that they had arrested members of a small terrorist group called Shura, affiliated with the Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan.

item.title: Rejecting Apple Pay, Wal-Mart will develop its own payment system.
item.dc:creator: bghoshqz
item.content:encoded: As the world's largest retailer, Wal-Mart has access to far more people than own iPhones, and its payment system will be a formidable challenger. Apple says other big chains, like McDonalds and Bloomingdales, have signed up for Apple Pay.

item.title: Total-hires-in-the-US-Total-hires-in-the-US_chartbuilder (1)
item.dc:creator: mattphillipsqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: /home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/558/39587363/files/2014/09/total-hires-in-the-us-total-hires-in-the-us_chartbuilder-1.png

item.dc:creator: mattphillipsqz
