item.title: Ireland's "Dr. No" has died at age 88.
item.dc:creator: msilverbergqz
item.content:encoded: Ian Paisley, the Protestant firebrand and former leader of Northern Ireland’s Democratic Unionist Party, was among the fiercest opponents of self-rule for the province. That made his central role in the 2007 power-sharing agreement with the republican Sinn Fein party all the more surprising, and it helped solidify a durable peace.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In one of his more famous moments,  Paisley heckled Pope John Paul II at the European Parliament (video).

item.title: An activist fund has advice for Olive Garden.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Go easy on the breadsticks, salt the pasta water, sell more booze. That was the gist of a nearly 300-page presentation disclosed by Starboard Value, which is seeking control of Olive Garden owner Darden Restaurants' board. Starboard said the improvements could boost the stock to $86, compared with yesterday's $48.29 close.

item.title: HP is hit with yet another fine.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: A federal judge in California ordered Hewlett-Packard to pay a $58.8 million fine for bribing government officials in Russia in return for a contact with the prosecutor general. HP agreed to pay a total of $108 million in April to settle investigations into other bribes in Russia, Poland, and Mexico.

item.title: Russia wants to retaliate.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: EU sanctions targeting Russian oil production and exploration sank the ruble to a new low as Russia threatened retaliation in response to the new EU and US sanctions, accusing both powers of undermining the truce in Ukraine. Russia will react "calmly, appropriately" to the EU sanctions, according to foreign minister Sergei Lavrov.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Earlier today, Russia's central bank left its benchmark interest rate untouched, as the need to support the stagnant economy trumped pressure to stem rising inflation caused in part by Russia's ban on Western food imports. Russia's economy and currency are in the doldrums due to Western sanctions.

item.title: Markets now see Venezuela as likelier to default than Ukraine
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz

item.title: A sale in the forecast.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: The Weather Channel's private equity owners are considering cashing out and have talked to investment bankers about strategic options for the company, Bloomberg reports. It's possible that Weather Channel will seek separate buyers for its television network and weather data arm. The businesses have an estimated combined value of $3.5 billion.

item.title: The emerging-markets miracle isn't what it used to be.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/264702/will-it-take-30-years-or-300-years-for-poor-countries-to-catch-up-to-rich-ones/

item.title: Electric car technology is off to the races.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: A motor racing championship that begins in Beijing tomorrow could do for electric cars and batteries what Formula 1 did for fuel injection. Formula E, as the new championship is called, was established after the governing body for auto racing made the case for giving electric-car manufacturers a platform in motorsport.

item.title: Obama ramps up the fight against Ebola.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The US president will announce plans tomorrow (paywall) to send portable hospitals, doctors and medical supplies to West Africa, and to conduct healthcare training. Liberia has asked for extra help as the virus threatens to overwhelm the country. Meanwhile, an illicit trade for a serum derived from the blood of Ebola survivors is making the rounds in West Africa, according to the World Health Organization.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: An EU study published last week suggested that the worst-case scenario could result in an additional 77,181 to 277,124 cases by the end of 2014. Here's a chart showing the disease's trajectory in the three most-affected countries through the end of August, with Liberia's looking particularly scary: [caption id="attachment_265613" align="alignleft" width="320"] [/caption]

item.title: ISIL's ranks are growing—but so are its opponents'.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: The CIA now says the Islamic State "can muster between 20,000 and 31,500 fighters across Iraq and Syria," eclipsing previous estimates that put the number at 10,000. But "several" Arab countries have also signed up to the US-led military campaign against IS, as the Obama administration attempts a coalition.

item.title: We're from the hedge fund industry, and we're here to help.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: As the government in Puerto Rico tries to stabilize the island's economy, more than two dozen hedge funds with a financial stake in the outcome are offering their advice, the New York Times reports. The coaching has included tips on the best economic indicators and suggestions for tightening investor presentations.

item.title: NASA unveils a new spacecraft.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: The Orion capsule, which emerged Thursday from its assembly hangar at Kennedy Space Center, will get its first test flight on Dec. 4. That flight and a second, scheduled for 2018, will be unmanned, but NASA expects to have astronauts steering Orion into deep space by 2021. The capsule can seat four.

item.title: US gas prices are making their way down.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/264713/just-as-americans-start-to-see-lower-gas-prices-big-oil-wants-to-sell-us-crude-overseas/

item.title: Radioshack's last stand.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The electronics retailer is considering a $585 million financing package (paywall) led by UBS and Standard General to save itself from a financial death spiral. The commitments—$325 million coordinated by UBS and $260 million from Standard General—are intended to help the Texas-based company stave off bankruptcy court and would replace financing from GE Capital.

item.title: Al-Qaeda's Indian branch raided the wrong ship.
item.dc:creator: amerelliqz
item.content:encoded: The first attack by Al-Qaeda in the Indian Subcontinent was meant to be a 9/11 anniversary attack on an American aircraft carrier in a Karachi port. Instead the jihadist group, established last week, raided what turned out to be a Pakistani Navy ship. No damage was done, and arrests were made.

item.title: Ukraine's shaky ceasefire looks even shakier.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Sunday saw some of the worst fighting (paywall) since the truce went into effect 10 days ago. Over the weekend Russia sent 220 trucks across the border, saying they contained 1,800 tons of aid. Only 40 were checked by Russian's border guard before being waved through, and none were inspected by the Red Cross or Ukrainian officials.

item.title: Very well, the US is now "at war" with the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: A day after secretary of state John Kerry insisted it was merely a "major counterterrorism operation," White House and Pentagon spokespeople have firmly described this conflict as a "war." This is just arguing over terminology, though: While the US seems to have as much trouble describing what it's doing as the world has deciding what to call its jihadist adversary, the actual power to declare war still rests with Congress, not the president.

item.title: A takeover battle is brewing for Heineken.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Dutch brewer Heineken has dismissed a buyout offer from SAB Miller, the world's second-largest beer-maker, amid speculation that Anheuser-Busch InBev, the world’s biggest brewer, is also preparing a bid. Heineken said that its eponymous controlling family intends to keep the company independent.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The beer industry has undergone a period of intense consolidation over the past decade. As Bloomberg reports, "SABMiller itself has long been seen as the final target for AB InBev"; combining the two companies would create a beer giant with a nearly 50% global market share.

item.title: Pennies cost more than a penny to make—because of zinc
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/265406/it-costs-1-6-cents-to-make-one-penny-because-of-the-rising-price-of-zinc/

item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded:
Pope Francis married 20 couples on Sunday, some of whom had already lived together and had children, in the latest sign that the Argentine pontiff wants the Catholic church to be more open and inclusive.

In the first wedding he has performed in his 18-month-old papacy, Francis took each couple through their vows in turn -- including Gabriella and Guido, who already had children and thought such a marriage would be impossible, official broadcasting service Radio Vaticana said.

"The people getting married on Sunday are couples like many others," the diocese of Rome said in a statement. "Some already live together, some already have children."

The ceremony was the first of its kind in the Vatican since Pope John Paul II presided over a wedding in 2000, when he was the leader of the world's 1.3 billion Catholics.

Continue reading the main story

RELATED COVERAGE

  • video

    Pope marries couples who have cohabited, had childrenSEPT. 14, 2014

Francis, who is the first non-European pope in 1,300 years, has expressed tolerance regarding other topics that are traditionally taboo in the Church, asking "who am I to judge?" a gay person "who seeks God and has good will".

item.title: Throwing tomatoes to annoy Putin.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Hundreds of people gathered in Amsterdam to pelt each other with overripe tomatoes (and paid for the privilege). The proceeds from Tomatofest went to Dutch farmers hurt by Russia’s ban on Western food imports. It follows similar moves in other countries hit by the Russian embargo.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C0NpNIowjjo

item.title: China's GDP target is in danger.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Factory output in August rose by a lower-than-expected 6.9% from a year ago, spurring Barclays to cut its 2014 GDP growth forecast to 7.2%, from 7.4%. Premier Li Keqiang now has two choices: ramp up the stimulus or miss the government's GDP target of 7.5%.

item.title: Indiana Jones was not an archeologist.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: In the first scene of "Raiders of the Lost Ark, "where he’s in the temple and he’s replacing that statue with a bag of sand—that’s what looters do,” Tulane's Marcello Canuto told the blog The Last Word On Nothing. "[The temple builders] are using these amazing mechanisms of engineering and all he wants to do is steal the stupid gold statue.” (via kottke)

item.title: David Cameron is having a tough week.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: British prime minister David Cameron vowed confront the Islamic State extremist group with “iron determination” after it murdered British aid worker David Haines, though it is unlikely the UK will officially join any fighting until after this week’s Scottish independence vote. Queen Elizabeth made a rare foray into politics by urging Scots to "think very carefully about the future."

item.title: David Cameron is having a tough week.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The UK prime minister vowed to confront the Islamic State extremist group with “iron determination” after it murdered British aid worker David Haines, while also trying to avoid presiding over the breakup of the United Kingdom. Queen Elizabeth made a rare foray into politics by urging Scots to "think very carefully about the future."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The FT's Chris Giles has a good round-up of the five key economic challenges (paywall) for an independent Scotland. Meanwhile, London's already over-inflated real-estate market could swell even further if Scottish independence goes ahead, reports Bloomberg:
“Whilst it’s all speculation at present, the drop-off in foreign-based buyers could be replaced in part by individuals and companies moving out of an independent Scotland,” said Miles Shipside, a director at Rightmove. “Their funds and target price brackets may not be as high as those of overseas investors, but could they nevertheless put a further strain on the capital’s limited housing supply?”

item.title: An anti-immigrant party makes big gains in Sweden.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Nordic region’s largest economy backed a Social Democrat-led coalition that won 43.7% of the votes, compared to 39.9% for the outgoing right-wing coalition, but the far-right Sweden Democrats won 12.9% of votes, more than double the backing they received in the previous election. "It’s hard to see who is a winner other than that we now have a very large xenophobic party,” said outgoing prime minster Fredrik Reinfeldt.

item.title: Alibaba's triumphal progress continues.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The Chinese e-commerce giant has kicked off the Asia leg of its IPO roadshow. It reportedly raised more than enough interest in the US to complete its currently planned offering, and might price the shares higher as a result. Its debut this Friday on the NYSE could be the biggest US IPO in history.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Alibaba is listing in the US because Hong Kong's stock exchange wouldn't accept its corporate governance structure, which allows the founders to nominate more than half the board. Dealbook has an interesting look at the ties between Alibaba and China's elite as a result of some of the companies it has been buying:
Citic 21CN is part of a shopping spree by Alibaba. Over the past year, the e-commerce giant has spent more than $4 billion on acquisitions, including stakes in a Chinese soccer team, a ride-sharing company and a digital-mapping business. The aggressive deal-making has raised questions about Alibaba’s strategy and whether it is properly vetting the companies.

item.title: Quite a lot of voters in Scotland's referendum won't be Scottish
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/262329/scots-arent-the-only-ones-voting-on-whether-scotland-should-become-independent/

item.title: Netflix enters France.
item.dc:creator: zachseward
item.content:encoded: CEO Reed Hastings called its European expansion (paywall) the "biggest international launch we’ve ever done." Entering France required major concessions to protectionist regulation. Netflix's first original program there will be a political drama, Marseille, that sounds like a French House of Cards.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The company is also launching this week in Germany, Austria, Switzerland, Belgium, and Luxembourg. All told, the new countries are home to 80 million households with broadband internet.
Hastings said he is eyeing expansion to Asian countries, but China is "a way off."
Netflix last reported 13.8 million streaming subscribers in its international markets, compared to 36.2 million in the United States. It isn't yet profitable outside the US.

item.title: The US rallies countries against ISIL in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Syria will be trickier. A summit in Paris has gathered around 30 countries to discuss how to tackle the terrorist movement. Iran was not invited, but US secretary of state John Kerry told reporters after the meeting that he was open to communicating with Iran.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Several Arab countries have offered to carry out airstrikes, while Australia said it would send in troops, but the coalition has not amassed enough bulk for a sustained campaign. “This isn’t going to be ‘shock and awe’ with hundreds of airstrikes,” an American official told the New York Times (paywall), referring to the beginning of the Iraq war in March 2003. “We don’t want this to look like an American war.” UK prime minister David Cameron held back and did not announce any air strikes, even after he vowed to confront the terrorist group with “iron determination” after it murdered the British aid worker David Haines.

item.title: Microsoft buys Minecraft for $2.5 billion.
item.dc:creator: lmiraniqz
item.content:encoded: It's true. Mojang, makers of the beloved computer game that allows players to use their imaginations and build whole worlds—like virtual Lego—is to be acquired by Microsoft. Mojang confirmed the news in a blog post designed to reassure fans, but it stopped short of promising that things wouldn't change, saying only that "stopping players making cool stuff is not in anyone’s interests."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Minecraft's creator, Markus Persson, who has been critical of Microsoft's Windows 8 operating system, will not stay with the company.

item.title: Apple hits a new high with iPhone preorders.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The company said it received record preorder sales of the iPhone 6 and the iPhone 6 Plus: over 4 million in just 24 hours. That's twice the number of iPhone 5 preorders in the first day after its September 2012 release. The increased demand could lead to supply headaches, and some people may have to wait until October for their phones.

item.title: Urban Outfitters takes it too far—yet again.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The remarkably tone-deaf clothing chain hit a new low when shoppers noticed that its "vintage" Kent State University sweatshirt, for sale for $129, was embellished with what looked like a splatter of blood. The university was the site of the Kent State shootings in 1970, in which the Ohio National Guard killed four students during a Vietnam War protest.

item.title: A down-to-the-wire scramble for Scotland.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: UK prime minister David Cameron has traveled to Scotland in a last-minute effort to rally the "no" vote. Opinion polls on the upcoming vote on whether to split the United Kingdom are too close to call, but younger voters appear to favor independence. Queen Elizabeth made a rare foray into politics, urging Scots to "think very carefully about the future."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The FT's Chris Giles has a good round-up of the five key economic challenges (paywall) for an independent Scotland. In London, an already over-inflated real-estate market could swell even further if Scottish independence goes ahead, reports Bloomberg:
“Whilst it’s all speculation at present, the drop-off in foreign-based buyers could be replaced in part by individuals and companies moving out of an independent Scotland,” said Miles Shipside, a director at Rightmove. “Their funds and target price brackets may not be as high as those of overseas investors, but could they nevertheless put a further strain on the capital’s limited housing supply?”
Meanwhile, celebrities such as footballer David Beckham and designer Viviane Westwood are also taking a stand.

item.title: Traffickers capsize a boat carrying hundreds of migrants.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: As many as 500 migrants are feared drowned after human traffickers rammed their boat off the coast of Malta last week, according to International Organization for Migration. The Syrian, Palestinian, Egyptian and Sudanese migrants were headed to Europe when they got into a confrontation with the traffickers, survivors told the organization.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: On Sunday, in a separate incident, around 250 African migrants were feared dead after their boat sank off of the Libya coast. The numbers fleeing conflicts across the Middle East and Africa have swelled of late, with many boarding unsafe smugglers' boats in Libya. So far this year, 2,200 people have died trying to cross the Mediterranean, the IOM estimates, compared to 700 in all of 2013. Including the tragedies of the last two days, the toll would be close to 3,000.

item.title: The clearest indication that domestic investment is sucking wind in China.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/265756/the-single-buried-statistic-that-explains-chinas-slowdown/

item.title: A welding of German and US companies creates an auto-parts giant.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The German car parts maker ZF Friedrichshafen has agreed to buy US-based TRW Automotive Holdings Corp. for $11.7 billion, creating a company with more than $40 billion in combined annual sales. The move, which gives the German manufacturer access to TRW's renowned airbags and collision sensors, makes ZF the world's second-largest auto-parts supplier, giving it new leverage in price negotiations with carmakers.

item.title: How to gamble without risking ruin.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/265746/this-is-what-responsible-gambling-looks-like/

item.title: America Movil wants to slim down in Mexico but grow in Brazil.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The Mexican carrier is courting AT&T and SoftBank for a sale of its Mexico assets that could be worth $17.5 billion. Multi-billionaire Carlos Slim is reducing the carrier's market share in his home country to avoid antitrust regulations. Last week, the company moved to boost its presence in Brazil by signing on with Oi SA to buy the wireless operator Tim Participacoes SA.

item.title: Michael Kors won Fashion Week, at least by this metric.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/265739/who-won-new-york-fashion-week-according-to-twitter/

item.title: Alibaba has raised its IPO price range.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: As a result of strong demand, the Chinese e-commerce giant raised the deal's price range to $66 to $68 a share from $60 to $66, according to told the Wall Street Journal (paywall). The company is in the midst of the Asia leg of its IPO roadshow ahead of what could be the biggest US IPO in history on Friday—and it's already causing trouble for Amazon.

item.title: Ukraine's shaky ceasefire looks even shakier.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: More fighting broke out in Donetsk after six civilians were killed and 25 were injured on Sunday in some of the worst fighting (paywall) since the truce went into effect 10 days ago. Ukrainian president Petro Poroshenko proposed a law that would give Donetsk and Luhansk "special status," granting the regions temporary self-rule for three years.

item.title: A massive pension system says no to hedge funds.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The $298 billion California Public Employees’ Retirement System (Calpers)—the world's fifth-largest pension fund—is quitting hedge funds, saying they’re too expensive and complex for its investment portfolio. Calpers' investment is only $4 billion, but it might inspire others to pull out—or might not (paywall).

item.title: Netflix enters Germany.
item.dc:creator: zachseward
item.content:encoded: The company's European expansion continued after a successful rollout in France. Netflix Germany will be boosted by partnerships with Deutsche Telekom and Vodafone (link in German), which will offer the streaming video service to their cellular customers. But Germans, like the French, won't be able to watch House of Cards because other companies already own the rights.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Netflix is also planning to launch this week in Austria, Switzerland, Belgium, and Luxembourg. All told, the countries have about 80 million homes (paywall) with broadband internet access. Here's a look at the offerings in France (registration required): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e3HnmjWgrhQ

item.title: The world’s two largest beer companies inch towards a tie-up.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Anheuser-Busch InBev is reportedly talking to banks about funding a bid for SABMiller that could be worth up to $122 billion. Together, the companies control a third of the world’s beer supply.

item.title: The US is divided between those who say "uh" and those who say "um."
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The regional breakdown can be detected from Twitter usage. Here's a map of who says what where.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_266225" align="alignleft" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: 7-Up used to contain lithium.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The soda was also marketed as a drink to "dispel hangovers."

item.title: UK leaders woo Scotland.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Conservative prime minister David Cameron, Liberal Democrat deputy prime minister Nick Clegg, and Labour leader Ed Miliband made a new promise for powers for Scotland if it rejects independence. The secession referendum takes place on Thursday.

item.title: The US begins its broadened campaign against the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The United States said its jets bombed an IS military position southwest Bangkok—the first time the US has attacked the Islamist extremist group to directly support Iraqi forces.

item.title: Boeing and SpaceX will each build spacecraft for NASA.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The US space agency will spend $6.4 billion on two contracts to replace the space shuttle and ferry astronauts to the International Space Station. US aerospace giant Boeing will earn $4.2 billion and entrepreneur Elon Musk's SpaceX will be paid $2.6 billion to develop their respective spacecraft. The former company is considered “the least risky option” (paywall), but upstart SpaceX's system is cheaper and doesn't rely on imported Russian parts.

item.title: Hollande’s moment of truth.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The French president’s new cabinet faces a confidence vote. Any major rebellion by Hollande’s Socialist Party could force new elections and open the door to the right-wing National Front.

item.title: Russia's biggest email provider buys its biggest social network.
item.dc:creator: lmiraniqz
item.content:encoded: Mail.ru, Russia's most popular provider of web-based email, said this morning that it had bought the 48% of VKontakte that it did not already own. The Mail.ru group already owns Russia's second-most popular social network, Odnoklassniki. It is also looking to expand outside Russia, particularly in the US.

item.title: What currency trading scandal?
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: In an attempt to pre-empt US and UK regulators' probes into the alleged rigging of currency benchmarks, several big banks have cut off their foreign-exchange dealers' access to customer orders and online chat rooms, Bloomberg reports. The aim is to make it tougher for dealers to collude, manipulate markets, and improperly use client information.

item.title: People aren't downloading apps anymore.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/266280/why-most-people-arent-downloading-apps-anymore/

item.title: Ebola merits more US troops than ISIL.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: US president Barack Obama ordered 3,000 troops to West Africa in an effort to contain the outbreak. The US plan also includes building 17 new healthcare facilities with 100 beds in each, training up to 500 workers a week, and opening a joint command operation in Liberia's capital to coordinate international efforts. China is also sending more medics to Sierra Leone to help with lab testing.

item.title: Ukraine gives its rebels a longer leash.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz

item.title: A volcano threatens the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Authorities are evacuating thousands of people in the danger zone (within a five-mile radius) of Mount Mayon as lava began to trickle out of the crater on Tuesday. The alert level has been raised to critical; scientists predict the volcano could violently erupt within weeks. Some 12,000 families are estimated to live in the danger zone.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Mount Mayon has erupted 50 times in the last 600 years. In 1841, one of its blasts killed 1,200 people.

item.title: UK leaders woo Scotland.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: With polls showing the Scotland independence vote is too close to call, Conservative prime minister David Cameron, Liberal Democrat deputy prime minister Nick Clegg, and Labour leader Ed Miliband promised more autonomy in a last-ditch effort to get Scotland to say "no." The secession referendum takes place Sept. 18.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Banks in Britain have been quietly moving millions of banknotes to Scotland in the event of a "yes" vote. The Independent reports:
Sources told The Independent the moves have been taking place over the past week or so in order to make sure ATMs do not run out on Friday in the event of a panic reaction to a “yes” vote. There have been some suggestions that people will want to move their money to English banks in the event of an independence vote. Bankers stressed there has been no sign yet of any increase in the amount of withdrawals from deposit accounts or ATMs, stressing that there was no need because the Bank of England has pledged to stand behind all accounts for at least 18 months in the event of a “yes” vote.

item.title: Samsung's new "musicom."
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The company is filming six hour-long sitcom episodes in a web-based series starring a fictional Samsung employee. The goal is to portray a "young Samsung" that helps attract younger job candidates. The series, called "Best Future," will be part musical, part sitcom, and features lead characters whose names mean "best" and "future" in Korean.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The series isn't a first for Samsung; it filmed another on its hiring policy and employee philosophy last year called "Endless Energy."

item.title: American families are making less than they did in 1989.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/265980/american-families-are-stuck-in-a-lost-quarter-century/

item.title: François Hollande's government just about survives.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The French president’s new cabinet narrowly won a confidence vote in parliament, 269 to 244. But with abstentions and no-shows putting the result 20 votes short of an absolute majority (paywall), Hollande now lacks support for his planned pro-business policies.

item.title: London's real estate prices just keep going up.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/266539/london-real-estate-prices-remain-deeply-silly/

item.title: China tries to stimulate its economy.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The People's Bank of China will inject 500 billion yuan ($81.4 billion) of liquidity into five state-run banks to encourage lending, following further signs of slowing economic growth. The new measure, similar to the US Federal Reserve's quantitive easing, is expected to target the housing market and small and private businesses.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The catalyst for the liquidity injection is most likely new data out this week that showed industrial production in August grew at its lowest pace since 2008 (paywall). However, the move is less drastic than cutting interest rates, which could worsen China's increasing levels of toxic debt. “It appears that the PBOC finally started to become more aggressive to salvage a sluggish economy,” Liu Li-Gang, chief Greater China economist at Australia & New Zealand Banking Group, told Bloomberg. “However, the use of [strategic lending facilities] also means the cut is not permanent as banks will have to pay it back later.”

item.title: Softbank’s founder becomes the richest man in Japan thanks to Alibaba.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Masayoshi Son’s net worth rose 3.4% to $16.6 billion, according to Bloomberg, surpassing Uniqlo/Fast Retailing chief Tadashi Yanai. Softbank’s 34% stake in Alibaba is a significant driver of his wealth, as the Chinese company’s IPO on Friday is shaping up to be the largest ever.

item.title: A Chinese Uighur scholar goes on trial.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Ilham Tohti, a prominent Beijing-based economist, could face the death penalty if convicted of separatism. China’s increasingly hostile relationship with its Muslim minority is under increased scrutiny after several Uighurs were linked to the extremist group Islamic State.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: "Mr. Tohti is an advocate for Uighur rights and religious freedom ... but he was never an advocate for Xinjiang independence," said Tohti's lawyer this morning before his trial. Continued terror attacks inside Xinjiang and elsewhere in China, however, have led China to maintain a very hard line on the Uighur population.

item.title: The humble club sandwich is a barometer for tourist affordability.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/266936/the-many-layers-of-global-insights-contained-in-one-delhi-club-sandwich/

item.title: The MacArthur "genius grants" are out.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Cartoonist Alison Bechdel, saxophonist Steve Colman, a researcher on police relations with the black community, and an advocate for domestic abuse victims, joined 17 others in receiving $625,000 each to spend however they please. The grants are awarded annually to US citizens or residents to support "the creative potential of individuals," although the selection process is a secret.

item.title: Xi Jinping want Chinese tourists to ditch the instant noodles.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: On a trip to the Maldives, the president of China remarked that Chinese tourists could do more to respect local etiquette (paywall), including reducing their reliance on instant ramen noodles while traveling. On a more serious note, Xi also added tourists shouldn't litter or destroy the local environment—something they have been notorious for in the past.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: “Let me just say here that we ought to teach our citizens to be a bit more civilized when they travel abroad,” Xi said. “Don’t throw water bottles everywhere, don’t destroy people’s coral reefs, and eat fewer instant noodles and more local seafood.”

item.title: It's decision day at the Fed.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The US central bank is expected to announce at 2pm US eastern time that it's cutting bond purchases by an additional $10 billion a month. That would put the two-year-old program of quantitative easing on track to end in October. Could the next step be an interest-rate hike? It all hinges on two words.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The goal of QE—adopted first by the Fed and then some other central banks—was to give the economy an extra boost after interest rates had gone as low as they could go. Did it work? Opinion is divided. Here's some useful reading:
  • The BBC's Kim Gittleson rounds up the evidence on QE.
  • The Economist explains QE. So does the Bank of England, if you like your explainers in video form.
  • Two economists at the conservative (i.e., Fed-skeptic) Heritage Foundation make the case that QE introduced big risks by filling the Fed's balance sheet with toxic assets.
  • A former Fed official's mea culpa: QE was a backdoor bailout for Wall Street (paywall). Reuters' Edward Hadas makes the same point but says "at least QE was a new idea."
  • On the cheerleading side, Ambrose Evans-Pritchard in the Daily Telegraph argues that for all its flaws, QE prevented the pain of budget austerity from being a lot worse.

item.title: Congress gives Obama the go-ahead to arm and train Syrian rebels.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: The US House approved the president's plan to send military trainers and arms to Saudi Arabia to help Syrian rebels fight the Islamic State. Republican Congressional leaders backed the legislation, despite their concerns that the administration's response is inadequate.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Meanwhile, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, US Army general Martin Dempsey, told a Senate committee that if this approach doesn't do the trick, he may recommend that the US send ground forces. A White House spokesman threw water on the idea, saying the US "will not deploy ground troops in a combat role into Iraq or Syria." ISIL has released a movie-trailer-like video (paywall) challenging Obama's vow to "degrade and ultimately destroy" the group, and appearing to threaten to kill US soldiers.

item.title: Chinese millionaires aren't the only ones that want to move abroad.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/266943/do-half-of-chinas-millionaires-really-want-to-emigrate-not-exactly/

item.title: Russia detains a billionaire, sparking fears of a Yukos repeat.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The Russian oil and telecoms tycoon Vladimir Yevtushenkov has been accused of money laundering in an oil deal and placed under house arrest, president Vladimir Putin’s Investigative Committee announced. The move has stoked worries that oligarchs and their property are not safe from the Kremlin.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The arrest reminded many of the Kremlin's prosecution of Mikhail Khodorkovsky, who ran the Yukos oil firm and was once the country's richest man. Khodorkovsky spent a decade in jail and had his companies appropriated by the Kremlin in what he and his supporters say was revenge for challenging Putin. Market watchers—and Khodorkovsky himself—have said the arrest is part of an asset grab by the state-owned oil giant Rosneft, which has been hit by Western sanctions designed to punish Russia for its role in the Ukraine crisis. They say the company is trying to take control of Yevtushenkov's oil company, Bashneft. Rosneft has denied any role. Shares of Bashneft and Yevtushenkov's other company, Sistema (which owns Russia's largest mobile operator MTS among other things) plunged on news of his arrest.

item.title: FedEx predicts a bounteous holiday season.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The US package delivery company surpassed analysts' expectations, earning $606 million in the first quarter, up 24% from the previous year. A rise in online shopping drove the results, which bode well for the peak season ahead.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: FedEx says it will add 50,000 seasonal workers over the holidays, while its rival, UPS, promised to hire up to 95,000, nearly double the 55,000 it hired last year. The two companies are often seen as bellwethers of the country's economy.

item.title: Ebola's devastation may also be financial.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: The outbreak of the deadly virus could drain hundreds of billions from economies in West Africa, particularly through tourism and trade, according to a World Bank report released today. Liberia, Guinea, and Sierra Leone could lose $359 billion in economic output this year, and unless the disease can be contained, its economic results may also spread.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Ebola has infected yet another healthcare provider: This time it's a French staffer from Doctors Without Borders, who is being evacuated to France.

item.title: Apple has launched iOS 8.
item.dc:creator: dfrommerqz
item.content:encoded: The new version of Apple's mobile operating system is a free update for recent iPhone and iPad models. It adds several new features, including changes to messaging, notifications, and sharing, plus third-party keyboards. But read this before you upgrade.

item.title: Weaves were a thing 3,300 years ago.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.content:encoded: Archaeologists discovered an ancient Egyptian woman with over 70 hair extensions on her head, still intact. She is one of hundreds of elaborately coiffed people buried in a cemetery near an ancient city now called Amarna.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_267264" align="alignnone" width="640"] That's a hairdo built to last.[/caption]

item.title: Sony has lost its way, and its all because of smartphones.
item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/267062/why-sony-must-wish-the-smartphone-was-never-invented/

item.title: The doves win, for now.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: The Federal Reserve said that it plans to keep its benchmark interest rate at a record low for the foreseeable future, despite improving indicators in the US economy that had led some to predict an imminent rate increase. Fed chair Janet Yellen has said that a steady reduction of the unemployment rate may overstate the improvement in the job market.

item.title: The Federal Reserve's October farewell.
item.dc:creator: mattphillipsqz
item.content:encoded: The Fed took two incremental—but important—steps toward its goal of eventually exiting from the unconventional monetary policies it put in place during the Great Recession. It said conclusively that it will end its quantitative easing bond-buying programs next month. It also laid out its plans for how, exactly, it would eventually raise short-term interest rates.

item.title: The male dominance of video gaming is over.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/267147/women-gamers-are-beginning-to-outnumber-their-male-counterparts/

item.title: A measles vaccine has killed 50 children in northern Syria.
item.dc:creator: zwenerflignerqz
item.content:encoded: The children—including infants—went into "severe allergic shock" after getting the vaccines, administered by the US-backed forces opposing President Bashar al-Assad. The vaccination campaign, a part of a UN effort to eradicate diseases such as measles, mumps, rubella, and polio that have surged since the country's conflict began, has been suspended while the deaths are investigated.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A doctor who administered the medicine told reporters via a Skype call that improper storage was to blame for the medicine's spoilage, but others suspect tampering. A Beirut-based public health specialist, Fouad Fouad, told the AP that spoiled vaccinations were unlikely to have been the cause, since they are generally harmless.

item.title: Buzz begins for another Apple release.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: The Daily Dot reports that the company will unveil new versions of the iPad and iPad mini at an Oct. 21 event. But a veteran Apple watcher who has called these kinds of things in the past says, "nope," it's not happening. Or at least not then—Apple has staged iPad events the past two Octobers.

item.title: Australia says it foiled a beheading plot.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: More than 800 police officers conducted raids across the country and detained 15 suspects who were allegedly planning to abduct and behead a random Sydney resident on camera in the name of the extremist group. A senior member of IS made "quite direct exhortations" to "conduct demonstration killings" in Australia, said prime minister Tony Abbott.

item.title: US logistics contractors were hacked by China.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: In 2012 and 2013 there were around 50 infiltrations against private companies that move US military personnel and weapons, according to a US senate investigation. Twenty of the attacks were blamed on Chinese government hackers.

item.title: Hyundai made a "Gangnam Style" splurge.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Korean conglomerate successfully bid more than $10 billion on a plot of land in Seoul's exclusive Gangnam district, trumping an offer from Samsung. Hyundai shares fell 4%; the property was appraised at only $3 billion.

item.title: New York City is looking to hire a new blacksmith.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: A Chinese general is accompanying Xi Jinping to quietly conquer India.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Peng Liyuan—the wife of Chinese president Xi Jinping, and a honorary major general in the People’s Liberation Army—has emerged as perhaps the most visible first lady in Asia, and is on center stage during her husband's high-profile trip to India. Despite the charisma of Peng, Xi's visit has taken on an uncomfortable edge due to a Chinese incursion into the disputed Himalayan border between the two countries.

item.title: Scotland votes "No" to independence from the UK.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The "No" votes against breaking up the 307-year-old union between Scotland and Britain won the day by a wider-than-expected 54.2%-45.7% margin. "Scotland has decided no at this stage to becoming an independent country and I accept that verdict," said Alex Salmond, Scotland's first minister, in his concession speech. "Let us not dwell on the distance we have fallen short. Let us dwell on the distance we have travelled.... Let us go forward as one nation."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The "Yes" forces may have come up short in getting out the vote on a day with the biggest turnout in Scottish history. The Guardian reports:
Across the board turnouts were high, often well over 80% ... it was lower than expected in the pro-independence areas of Dundee at 78.8% and Glasgow at 75% but higher in areas more likely to vote no, including 89.6% in Edinburgh and a predicted very high number in the Borders.
Despite the defeat of the independence referendum, the “no” vote will create big changes in the UK. The main political parties have all promised Scotland more autonomy over taxation, spending, and social welfare programs. Berenberg UK economist Rob Wood:
The UK will be different, but it will remain one country for the time being. By promising extra powers to Scotland within the UK, London has helped to keep Scotland in. But Prime Minister David Cameron may have to pay a price for the late promise of more home rule for Scotland.  But the UK has been changed forever by this referendum. The majority of Scot’s have voted to remain in the UK, but not under the old status quo. Indeed, it seems that around 45% of Scot’s backed a split with the UK. The nationalist leaders in Scotland will claim a strong mandate in future negotiations with the UK over future powers to be devolved to Scotland.
The pound surged on news of the "No" vote, hitting a 2-week high of $1.652 against the US dollar and reaching multi-year highs against the euro and yen. https://twitter.com/RichardBarley1/status/512838375603048448

YouGov #IndyRef prediction: YES 46%, NO 54% - http://t.co/huG6uJFiJG

— YouGov (@YouGov) September 18, 2014

The front page of the (4.30am edition) of the Guardian: 'Scotland says no' via @SimonNRicketts pic.twitter.com/OfwISTinD7

— Ben Quinn (@BenQuinn75) September 19, 2014

GBP is still well off its highs for the yr vs USD, but is clearly recovering from its #indyref wobble: pic.twitter.com/8hlxLNmPcW

— Richard Barley (@RichardBarley1) September 19, 2014

I've just spoken to Alex Salmond, congratulating him on a hard-fought campaign. I'm delighted the SNP will join talks on further devolution.

— David Cameron (@David_Cameron) September 19, 2014

item.title: Diet sodas may cause blood sugar spikes.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: A small-scale study found that artificial sweeteners interfere with crucial bacteria in the stomach. Lab mice and humans alike who drank diet soda were at increased risk of glucose intolerance, which can lead to diabetes.

item.title: Early Eurasians were a randy bunch.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: A "sexually prolific" group from what is now northern Russia mated with hunter-gatherers and indigenous farmers to give rise to modern-day Europeans, according to new DNA analysis.

item.title: America’s homebuilders see good things on the horizon.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/267227/you-are-probably-underestimating-the-economic-momentum-in-us-housing/

item.title: A slew of new Kindles.
item.dc:creator: zwenerflignerqz
item.content:encoded: Amazon announced the release of six new or upgraded devices, including a $199 high-end e-reader and a $79 touch-screen tablet. The luxe version, the thinnest-ever e-reader that mimics paper books, is aimed at heavy readers; the low-end version targets nascent e-reader markets like China, Japan, and Germany. The devices begin shipping in October, in time for the holiday rush.

item.title: The Dow and S&P hit all-time highs.
item.dc:creator: zwenerflignerqz
item.content:encoded: The Dow jumped 0.56% to 17,252.8 and the S&P rose 0.44% to 2,010.34, both new records. The markets vaulted off a substantial drop in US jobless claims and the Fed's announcement that interest rates will stay low in the near future.

item.title: Alibaba begins trading.
item.dc:creator: zwenerflignerqz
item.content:encoded: The stock opened at $92.70 a share, 36% above its offering price. A surge in early trading gives the company a market value of roughly $240 billion, larger than the market valuation of energy giant Chevron. The shares are now trading under the ticker "BABA" on the New York Stock Exchange.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: With a multitude of banks underwriting the public offering and fewer "lockup" restrictions that force initial investors to hold their shares for a time before selling, Alibaba's IPO is one of the world's least conventional. The partnership made up of Alibaba's founders will retain power to elect the company board. The governance of the company isn't as top-heavy as other public tech companies like Facebook and Google—whose partners get 10 times votes per share—but it still gives public shareholders the short end of the stick.

item.title: The Islamic State releases a video of a captive British journalist.
item.dc:creator: zwenerflignerqz
item.content:encoded: In a roughly three-minute video posted on social media sites, a man identified himself on-camera as John Cantlie, a reporter who had worked for the Sunday Times, the Sun, and the Sunday Telegraph. In the video, he promises to "convey some facts" about the Sunni Muslim extremist group in future videos to counter Western portrayals.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Meanwhile, the senate voted 78-22 to arm and train moderate Syrian rebels in their fight against IS. Republican senator Rand Paul, one of the most vocal critics of the move, said it "enabled the enemy."

item.title: Microsoft fires 2,100 employees.
item.dc:creator: zwenerflignerqz
item.content:encoded: This is the second round of layoffs in a long-term plan announced in July to cut 18,000 jobs, or 14% of the company's total workforce. The housecleaning is an attempt to streamline after the April acquisition of Nokia's Devices and Services division, which added 25,000 employees to the Microsoft payroll.

item.title: Microsoft's prediction engine thinks Scotland will stick with the UK.
item.dc:creator: zwenerflignerqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/267900/scotland-independence-referendum-prediction/

item.title: Larry Ellison steps down as Oracle's CEO.
item.dc:creator: zachseward
item.content:encoded: The surprise shift is effectively immediately. Ellison, who founded the company, becomes executive chairman of the board and chief technology officer. Two Oracle executives—Safra Catz and Mark Hurd—will jointly fill his slot as CEO in an unorthodox arrangement.

item.title: Health workers treating Ebola were murdered in Guinea.
item.dc:creator: zwenerflignerqz
item.content:encoded: Eight people, including three doctors and three journalists from a missing team of health workers, were found dead near a village in southeast Guinea near where the Ebola outbreak began. The reason for the killings is not known, but villagers have reportedly been distrustful of health workers during the crisis, which has claimed more than 2,600 victims in West Africa.

item.title: The UN Security Council sounds the alarm on Ebola.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Ebola is a "threat to international peace and security," the council said, after its first-ever emergency meeting to deal with a public health issue. An "emergency UN mission" will work with the World Health Organization to combat the disease in West Africa, where the infection rate is doubling every three weeks.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In Oxford, England, the first human subject to trial a vaccination against Ebola has reported no problems after receiving the jab. The drug is being developed by GlaxoSmithKline and the US National Institutes of Health; human trials are set to begin in Africa next month. Meanwhile, eight people, including three doctors and three journalists from a missing team of health workers, were found dead in southeast Guinea near where the Ebola outbreak began. The reason for the killings is not known, but some villagers have reportedly been hostile toward health workers during the crisis.

item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz

item.dc:creator: zmudallalqz
item.excerpt:encoded: That's a hairdo built to last.

item.title: SAP buys into the cloud.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The German business software giant acquired the online travel expenses company Concur (paywall) for $8.3 billion in an effort to expand its web services offerings to corporations. Seattle-based Concur is a rare survivor of the first dotcom boom.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The business-management industry has seen plenty of consolidation of late—earlier this year SAP purchased Fieldglass, which helps companies manage contract employees, and in 2012 it bought business-to-business marketplace Ariba. Concur itself integrated with Airbnb this year to offer its business travelers more hospitality options.

item.title: Rich travelers prefer the aisle seat.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/267961/the-more-people-fly-the-more-they-prefer-the-aisle-seat/

item.title: Germans can get airplane food delivered to their homes for some reason.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Air Food One offers subscribers a weekly meal delivery from Lufthansa's food supplier—this week it's "Arabic seafood" or panserotti with porcini mushrooms. The meals, which are from the business class menu, are priced at under 10 euros ($12.90).

item.title: Russia sanctions force Exxon Mobil to hit pause on Arctic oil drilling.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Just days after new US and EU sanctions were declared, Exxon halted work on a project that aimed to extract an estimated 9 billion barrels of oil from beneath the Kara Sea, sources told Bloomberg. Exxon has eight more days to cease all arctic exploration work with Russia's OAO Rosneft—a partnership that aimed to solve Exxon's falling production rates and modernize Russia's aging extraction operations.

item.title: An early iPhone 6 buyer sees his life flash before his eyes.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Jack Cooksey, the first person in Perth, Australia to buy Apple's latest smartphone, was showing it off to a TV reporter when it went crashing to the ground.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YbehPQfu3K0
Luckily for Jack, the iPhone 6 survived.

item.title: Telefónica bets big on Brazil as Vivendi retreats.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Spanish telecoms group bought the Brazilian broadband company GVT from France's Vivendi, in a cash- and stock-based deal worth $9.3 billion. The move will make Telefónica the dominant telecom operator in Brazil, where it reaps one-fifth of its total revenue, and which is growing much faster than the company's stagnant home market.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The deal represents perhaps the final big sale for Vivendi in its rocky two-year restructuring, which has seen it sell all three of its telecom businesses as well as its videogame division. French mogul Vincent Bollore, who became Vivendi's chairman in June, now presides over a restructured one-time conglomerate that now consists mainly of the Universal Music Group and pay-TV company Canal Plus.

item.title: China fines GlaxoSmithKline nearly half a billion dollars.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: A court found the British drug company guilty of bribery, fined it a record $491.5 million, and jailed executives including country director Mark Reilly—though Reuters reports he may be deported instead.

item.title: France carries out its first air strikes against the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: President Francois Hollande said fighter jets "completely destroyed" a logistics depot used by the extremist group, also known as ISIL, in north-eastern Iraq. He added that France would not attack Syria, and confirmed that it has no intention of putting troops on the ground in the region.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Choosing not to strike Syria may not be an option for very much longer. On Thursday, Iraqi prime minister Haider al-Abadi urged Western forces to focus their attacks on his neighbor as ISIL fighters retreat there. Twenty-one Kurdish villages have reportedly been captured by the group.

item.title: Many of the iPhone shoppers in line outside Apple stores in New York and Tokyo are Chinese.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: With the release of the iPhone 6 and 6 Plus delayed in China because of regulatory hurdles, as many as 5 million iPhones could be smuggled back into China (where they were made) before it's released there. China is Apple’s second largest market by revenue.

item.title: France begins air strikes on the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: zwenerflignerqz
item.content:encoded: French jets destroyed an ISIL depot in northeast Iraq in the strikes, which mark the entrance of France into the air campaign begun by the US in August. Earlier this week, 25 countries signed a statement of support for Iraq at a meeting in Paris, though none of them committed to specific military action.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Yesterday, ISIL released its latest video of a captive British journalist. In the roughly three-minute video posted on social media sites, a man identified himself on-camera as John Cantlie, a reporter who had worked for the Sunday Times, the Sun, and the Sunday Telegraph. In the video, he promises to “convey some facts” about the Sunni Muslim extremist group in future videos to counter Western portrayals.

Meanwhile, the US Senate voted 78-22 to arm and train Syrian rebels in their fight against ISIL. Republican senator Rand Paul, one of the most vocal critics of the move, said it “enabled the enemy.”

item.title: An Ebola lockdown in Sierra Leone.
item.dc:creator: zwenerflignerqz
item.content:encoded: Health workers will go door-to-door during a three-day lockdown, trying to find and educate Ebola patients who have avoided care due to fear or suspicion of doctors. Some experts warn that the plan might backfire if so many hidden cases emerge that they overwhelm treatment centers.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
In its first-ever emergency meeting to deal with a public health issue, the UN Security Council called Ebola a “threat to international peace and security.” An “emergency UN mission” will work with the World Health Organization to combat the disease in West Africa, where the infection rate is doubling every three weeks.

In Oxford, England, the first human subject to trial a vaccination against Ebola has reported no problems after receiving the jab. The drug is being developed by GlaxoSmithKline and the US National Institutes of Health. Human trials are set to begin in Africa next month. Meanwhile, six have been arrested in the killing of eight people, including three doctors and three journalists from a team of health workers, who were found dead in southeast Guinea near where the Ebola outbreak began. The reason for the killings is unclear, but some villagers have reportedly been hostile toward health workers during the crisis.

item.title: This is no way for a respectable currency to behave.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/268410/bitcoin-is-plunging-again/

item.title: The Earth turned up the heat this summer.
item.dc:creator: zwenerflignerqz
item.content:encoded: Globally, it was the hottest summer on record, warmer by 0.71 degrees Celsius than in 1998, previously the hottest summer, according to the US National Climatic Data Center. If the mercury stays high over the next few months, 2014 could replace 2010 as the hottest year on record.

item.title: Scotland's first minister resigns.
item.dc:creator: zwenerflignerqz
item.content:encoded: Alex Salmond stepped down after the votes against breaking up the 307-year-old union between Scotland and Britain won the day by a wider-than-expected 55%-45% margin. "For me as leader my time is nearly over," he said, "but for Scotland the campaign continues."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The "Yes" forces may have come up short in getting out the vote on a day with the biggest turnout in Scottish history. The Guardian reports:
Across the board turnouts were high, often well over 80% ... it was lower than expected in the pro-independence areas of Dundee at 78.8% and Glasgow at 75% but higher in areas more likely to vote no, including 89.6% in Edinburgh and a predicted very high number in the Borders.
Despite the defeat of the independence referendum, the “no” vote will create big changes in the UK. The main political parties have all promised Scotland more autonomy over taxation, spending, and social welfare programs. Berenberg UK economist Rob Wood:
The UK will be different, but it will remain one country for the time being. By promising extra powers to Scotland within the UK, London has helped to keep Scotland in. But Prime Minister David Cameron may have to pay a price for the late promise of more home rule for Scotland.  But the UK has been changed forever by this referendum. The majority of Scot’s have voted to remain in the UK, but not under the old status quo. Indeed, it seems that around 45% of Scot’s backed a split with the UK. The nationalist leaders in Scotland will claim a strong mandate in future negotiations with the UK over future powers to be devolved to Scotland.
The pound surged on news of the "No" vote, hitting a 2-week high of $1.652 against the US dollar and reaching multi-year highs against the euro and yen. https://twitter.com/RichardBarley1/status/512838375603048448

GBP is still well off its highs for the yr vs USD, but is clearly recovering from its #indyref wobble: pic.twitter.com/8hlxLNmPcW

— Richard Barley (@RichardBarley1) September 19, 2014

item.title: Alibaba's IPO is the biggest in US history by almost $4 billion
item.dc:creator: zwenerflignerqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/268394/heres-how-ridiculously-big-the-alibaba-ipo-is/

item.title: Growing wasabi outside of Japan is extremely difficult but ridiculously lucrative.
item.dc:creator: snarulaqz
item.content:encoded: The sinus-clearing root sells for up to $160 per kilogram, according to the BBC. Figuring out how to cultivate it on a commercial scale in North America has been a rewarding challenge for farmers in Canada and Oregon—though they must guard their trade secrets vigilantly.

item.title: Nicolas Sarkozy is back in action.
item.dc:creator: zwenerflignerqz
item.content:encoded: The former French president announced on his Facebook page that he would return to politics, joining the race to lead the right-leaning UMP party. Sarkozy's return may actually help the man who defeated him, Francois Hollande, whose popularity is at 13%.

item.title: Worst-case Ebola projections get even worse.
item.dc:creator: zwenerflignerqz
item.content:encoded: A model created by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention predicted there could be 550,000 or more cases of the virus if aid and intervention are not ramped up. Anticipating the infection's spread has proven challenging; a World Health Organization spokesman said WHO's prediction last month of 20,000 cases is already outdated.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Sierra Leone is under a three-day lockdown, during which health workers will go door-to-door trying to find and educate Ebola patients who have avoided care due to fear or suspicion of doctors. Some experts warn that the plan might backfire if so many hidden cases emerge that they overwhelm treatment centers.

In its first-ever emergency meeting to deal with a public health issue, the UN Security Council called Ebola a “threat to international peace and security.” An “emergency UN mission” will work with the World Health Organization to combat the disease in West Africa, where the infection rate is doubling every three weeks.

In Oxford, England, the first human subject to trial a vaccination against Ebola has reported no problems after receiving the jab. The drug is being developed by GlaxoSmithKline and the US National Institutes of Health. Human trials are set to begin in Africa next month. Meanwhile, six have been arrested in the killing of eight people, including three doctors and three journalists from a team of health workers, who were found dead in southeast Guinea near where the Ebola outbreak began. The reason for the killings is unclear, but some villagers have reportedly been hostile toward health workers during the crisis.

item.title: The Islamic State returns hostages to Turkey.
item.dc:creator: laurenalixb
item.content:encoded: The terrorist group released 49 hostages that were seized from the Turkish consulate in Mosul in June, in what president Erdogan referred to as a "pre-planned operation." Turkey has yet to join the military coalition against IS for fear that it would jeopardize the lives of its captives.

item.title: This week the markets took their cues from optimism over the US economy
item.dc:creator: laurenalixb

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/268698/markets-clearly-focused-on-a-british-breakaway-this-week-just-not-scotland/

item.title: New Zealand elects its prime minister for a third term.
item.dc:creator: laurenalixb
item.content:encoded: John Key's National Party won 48% of the vote on Saturday after Key led the country to record levels of prosperity. Growth is projected to fall in coming years though as export prices drop and monetary conditions tighten.

item.title: Afghanistan finalizes a power-sharing deal.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Following a stalemate since disputed elections earlier this year, the two presidential candidates have resolved their differences. Ashraf Ghani, the certified winner, becomes president and his defeated rival, Abdullah Abdullah, gets to nominate a chief executive with powers similar to those of a prime minister.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
According to Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index, Afghanistan ranks 175th out of 177 nations in experts' perceived levels of public corruption, below Iraq and Sudan and edging out just North Korea and Somalia. The index is a reminder that countries are beset with "abuse of power, secret dealings and bribery."
https://twitter.com/JohnSaeki/status/513960102684925952/photo/1

item.title: Siemens buys into the US fracking boom.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Europe's largest engineering company is paying $7.6 billion for Dresser-Rand Group, a US manufacturer of oil and gas compressors and turbines. Siemens CEO Joe Kaeser said the company was late to take advantage of the US shale gas boom, but is planning more acquisitions in the sector.

item.title: Alibaba's IPO is now the largest in history.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Bankers working on the Chinese internet giant's public offering have exercised the "green shoe" option (paywall) to purchase additional shares, raising the total proceeds of the offering from $21.8 billion to $25 billion, according to the Wall Street Journal. Alibaba shares rose 38% on their first day of trading on Friday, giving the company a market capitalization of more than $230 billion—bigger than Facebook and Amazon.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: a:3:{s:20:"restored_revision_id";i:269076;s:16:"restored_by_user";i:45805036;s:13:"restored_time";i:1411354569;}

item.title: Iran wants a quid pro quo.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Iranian officials told Reuters that it would work with the United States to defeat IS but only if they received more flexibility on the country's uranium enrichment program. Western negotiators said Iran often attempts to tie its uranium talks to other issues, but that they would resist linking them.

item.title: Yemeni rebels seized the capital.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Houthi rebels took control of government buildings and military bases in Sana after the Yemeni military reportedly capitulated, leading to a UN-brokered peace deal to create of a new government. The Houthis are  Shiite tribal group that some governments in the region claim are backed by Iran.

item.title: Starbucks is testing beer-flavored lattes.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The "Dark Barrel Latte," currently available on a trial basis in some US outlets of the coffee chain, reportedly tastes like Guinness. It is served with whipped cream and caramel sauce—but contains no actual beer.

item.title: Investors shun oil money, seek to go clean.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: A group of 650-odd investors, including the Rockefellers, have pledged to take their combined $50 billion of fossil fuel investments and convert them into clean fuel funding. Their gesture, along with yesterday's nearly 400,000 thick wall of protestors in Manhattan, aims to send a message to the more than 120 world leaders attending with Tuesday's United Nations summit on climate change.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Here's how the march looked from above: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KuSWN_EG6CE China now emits more greenhouse gases than the United States and the European Union combined—and, for the first time, emits more than the EU on a per capita basis. But it may be the next few years, as China's anti-pollution measures take effect, that could matter the most. Globally, 2014 was the hottest summer on record, warmer by 0.71°C than the previous record in 1998, according to the US National Climatic Data Center. If the mercury stays high over the next few months, 2014 could replace 2010 as the hottest year since record-keeping began.

item.title: Hyundai directors were kept in the dark.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Korean conglomerate did not seek board approval for a massive $10 billion real estate deal in Seoul's posh Gangnam district, according to Reuters. The purchase at three times the appraised value for the land—and billions more than a rival bid from Samsung— has raised concerns about the company's corporate governance.

item.title: China now emits more greenhouse gases than the United States and the European Union combined.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/269078/chinas-carbon-emissions-have-hit-a-new-record-but-its-the-next-few-years-that-matter-most/

item.title: Tesco's £250 million accounting mistake.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The UK's largest grocer overstated expected profits by £250 million ($408 million)—the latest in a series of missteps that has resulted in five straight years of sales decline. Four executives including the company's UK managing director have been suspended; Tesco shares dropped by as much as 12%.

item.title: It's getting tricky to run EMC
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The data storage giant is under pressure to consider merging with a rival such as Dell, Oracle, HP or Cisco, according to The Wall Street Journal. Activist shareholders want EMC  to restructure ahead of its CEO's retirement early next year.

item.title: Apple fanboys admit that Steve Jobs was wrong about huge phones
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: Big iPhones break records at Apple.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It took just three days for Apple to move 10 million units of the new larger iPhones, and that's despite them not being available in China. Now not everyone is a fan of the 5.5 inch 6 Plus, but it seems to be the model that's most difficult to find.

item.title: When China slows down, the world slows down.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Investors across the world are showing a lack of confidence in China's manufacturing sector. The Shanghai Index is down. The Nasdaq, S&P500, and Dow Jones are down. And Australia's currency is at a seven-month low. The other shoe is expected to drop on Tuesday when HSBC releases its "flash" data for Chinese manufacturing in September (paywall).

item.title: US home sales hit slump.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: After five months of rising existing-home sales, the National Association of Realtors says the boom is over. Sales in August were down 1.8% compared to July, and down 5.3% year over year. At least the average second-hand home now goes for $219,800, up 4.8% from a year ago, and the 30th consecutive month of growth.

item.title: Microsoft hits reset on China Xbox launch.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Two days before the Xbox One was scheduled to launch in China, Microsoft has mysteriously decided to pull the plug. The console was supposed to be the first foreign gaming machine to launch in the People's Republic since the turn of the century. Meanwhile, the Xbox One is slated to launch in India in just a few hours, where it'll be exclusively available via Amazon.

item.title: Amazon Germany is hit with a two-day strike.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Workers at five of Amazon's processing centers in Germany (there are nine in total) are striking on Monday and Tuesday because they want to be classified as retail employees and not logistics workers. That small but important distinction costs workers several hundreds of euros a month in wages.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This isn't the first time Amazon Germany has faced striking employees. Last Christmas, over 1,100 employees tried to speak up about what they called "low wages, permanent performance pressure and short-term contracts".

item.title: Ukraine holds hands with Poland and Lithuania.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Ukraine's defense minister signed an agreement in Warsaw to form a brigade known as "LitPolUkrBrig," to strengthen regional security. Based in the Polish city of Lublin, roughly 3,800 soldiers will come from Poland itself, another 545  from Ukraine, and between 150 and 350 from Lithuania. Given the ongoing ceasefire violations by separatists, Ukraine may need all the help it can get.

item.title: The Lion King becomes the most successful production ever.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: With $6.2 billion in ticket sales, it just surpassed Andrew Lloyd Webber's Phantom of the Opera to become the most successful piece of entertainment. The Phantom may have brought twice as many people into theaters, but 75 million people paid more to see Simba.

item.title: Putin's love of big cats influences a children's TV show.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: To mark the 50th anniversary of the popular Russian children's program "Goodnight Little Ones," the show's producer, Alexander Mitroshenkov, decided to add a character. Would it be a wolf? A monkey? A giraffe? A horse? All solid choices, but nope, he went with a tiger. Asked why, Alexander pointed to Putin, and then it all made sense.

item.title: No more Burger-King-style tax moves?
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The US is cracking down on tax inversions (paywall), whereby a US company reduces its effective tax rate by merging with a foreign one and moving its headquarters abroad. New rules from the US Treasury would complicate or disqualify deals like Burger King's acquisition of Canada's Tim Hortons last month.

item.title: The SEC makes someone very rich.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The US financial regulator announced a $30 million reward—double the 2013 record of $14 million—to a tipster who helped it uncover a “difficult-to-detect” fraud. It’s the 14th such award since the SEC launched its program two years ago, and the fourth to someone outside the US.

item.title: Ukraine withdraws its big guns.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: President Petro Poroshenko said the ceasefire with pro-Russian rebels is holding, and that the fighting that continues is being waged only by small-time and independent groups. Kyiv will maintain its buffer zone in the east with checkpoints while fighting the remaining rebels.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Just a week ago Ukraine's defense minister signed an agreement to form a brigade with Polish and Lithuanian troops, to strengthen regional security. The force will comprise of around 4,000 soldiers that could respond to threats such as an increasingly belligerent Russia.

item.title: The US and its Arab allies begin airstrikes in Syria.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Pentagon and five Sunni Arab allies deployed bombers, fighters, armed drones, and cruise missiles on Monday against the Islamic State's de facto capital of Raqqa, Syria and its forces along the Iraqi border. The strikes also killed 30 al-Qaeda-linked militants known as "the Khorasan group," according to Syrian human-rights observers; the US said the Khorasan fighters were planning an attack against the US and Western interests.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Here's video from the USS Arleigh Burke firing Tomahawk cruise missiles into Syria: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H9034BawdX4&sns=tw Iranian president Hassan Rouhani said on Tuesday that the strikes on Syria were illegal (paywall) because the Syrian government wasn't consulted. Rouhani is just as opposed to ISIL as the US, but there is currently no cooperation between the two countries. Separately, Israel said it downed a Syrian military jet that crossed into Israeli air space in the Golan Heights. Syrian mortars and shells have fallen in the Israel-controlled area throughout the three-year Syrian civil war, but this is the first time Israel has downed a Syrian jet since 1985.

item.title: Here are all of the countries the US has bombed since 9/11
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: Islamic terrorists kidnap a French hostage.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A group linked to the Islamic State took a 55-year-old man in Algeria, and threatened to kill him unless French president François Hollande ceased air strikes in Iraq. The French and Algerian governments have been working together to try to free the hostage.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: On Friday last week French jets "completely destroyed" an Iraqi logistics base used by IS, and the French government has strongly backed the fight against the group. The French government refers to IS using its Arabic acronym "Daish" (paywall), which the group finds highly offensive.

item.title: China’s manufacturing picks up a bit of steam.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
