item.content:encoded: The HSBC/Markit flash purchasing managers’ index for September ticked higher, suggesting that manufacturing activity is expanding. The new data should ease fears that the economy is sputtering despite the government’s “mini-stimulus.”

item.title: Syria is the seventh country bombed by the US since 9/11.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/269630/here-are-the-seven-countries-the-united-states-has-bombed-since-911/

item.title: Ukraine withdraws its heavy artillery.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: President Petro Poroshenko said he would move the country's large weapons from its conflict-ridden eastern regions because the ceasefire with pro-Russian rebels is mostly holding, and that any continued fighting is being waged by small independent groups. The move is a part of a nine-point deal (paywall) agreed on by both sides to de-escalate the conflict.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Russian president Vladimir Putin is not attending the UN's current assembly in New York despite the Ukraine situation being high on the agenda. Foreign minister Sergei Lavrov is representing Russia instead.

item.title: Alibaba could buy Yahoo for free.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The newly flush Chinese tech giant would need to pay $7 billion in cash and a block of shares—but once it owns Yahoo, it would get them all back anyway, plus some other stuff, notes Bloomberg's Matt Levine. Why won't this happen in real life? Because Yahoo executives are unlikely to admit that their company is essentially worth nothing.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Levine explains:
If you are a management team and board of directors and someone comes to you and says, "I want to buy your company for nothing," then your inclination will be to say no. Your company has to be worth something! Like, you're coming to work every day, doing stuff. Concluding that the stuff you're doing is worth nothing, or negative $8 billion depending how you count, is a little too much like staring into the abyss for most corporate executives.

item.title: Ferrari is recalling 3,000 cars to stop drivers getting trapped in the trunk.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The luxury sports car maker realized that if you somehow get stuck in the trunk of its 458 sports car, you can't get out. The $230,000 car does have a release within the trunk, but it "only allows the lid to be opened just slightly, far enough to prevent suffocation and allow someone to call for help," according to CNN.

item.title: Xiaomi’s new revenue stream is selling stuffed animals.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi expects to sell some 2 million of its bunny mascots this year. The revenue may be tiny for the fast-growing company, but the branding and customer loyalty opportunities are nothing to shake a carrot at.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
And yes, there is a CGI movie too:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=COF0-TlJBy4

item.title: Israel downs a Syrian fighter jet.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The plane had entered Israeli air space according to its military, potentially marking an escalation in tensions between the two countries. Throughout the three-year Syrian conflict so far mortars and shells have fallen in Israel-controlled Golan, but this is the first time Israel has downed a Syrian jet.

item.title: Jimmy Choo takes a step toward an IPO.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: JAB Luxury, the holding company that owns the upmarket British shoe maker, plans to float at least 25% of the business on the London Stock Exchange. Jimmy Choo could be valued at $1.14 billion, and is likely to tout its strong potential for growth in Asia as it tries to tempt investors.

item.title: A moderate Chinese Uighur scholar gets life in prison.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Ilham Tohti, an economics professor who set up a website to promote peaceful dialogue between China's minority Uighur and majority Han ethnic groups, was convicted of "separatism" by a Chinese court. Human rights groups deplored the verdict, and the US embassy said his arrest "silenced an important Uighur voice that peacefully promoted harmony and understanding among China’s ethnic groups."

item.title: Jack Ma's buying the drinks tonight.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Alibaba's co-founder has become China's richest person, with $25 billion to his name, according to Hurun Reports. Ma surpassed Wang Jianlin, head of the real estate giant Wanda, who has a respectable $24.2 billion. Also impressive is Xiaomi co-founder Lei Jun in 10th place, despite his selling smartphones at essentially zero margin.

item.title: Philips to split in two.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Dutch firm's lighting and healthcare units soon will become separate companies, a procedure that's estimated to take 18 months to complete at a cost of roughly 50 million euros a year until 2016, after which Philips will recoup 300 million euros in savings. Competitor Siemens spun off its lighting unit, Osram, last year.

item.title: Chinese torture trade quadruples.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: According to Amnesty International, more than 130 Chinese companies are currently exporting devices classified as "tools of torture," up from 28 companies a decade ago. Said instruments, such as spiked batons, are "intrinsically cruel" and should be banned (pdf), the group said. Africa and the Middle East look to be the biggest buyers.

item.title: Liberia is getting paid to prevent deforestation—but probably not enough.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Norwegian officials told the BBC that the country will give Liberia $150 million in an attempt to eliminate deforestation by 2020. But the illegal timber industry is a $100 billion market, according to Interpol, so Norway may have to up the ante.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In a similar gesture, France has pledged $982 million to help countries that are experiencing the most devastating effects of climate change.

item.title: Ebola is on the verge of exploding.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The US Centers for Disease Control estimates that by the end of this month, there could be 21,000 people infected (paywall) with the Ebola virus in Liberia and Sierra Leone. Assuming nothing is done, that will swell to between 550,000 and 1.4 million by the end of January. There are currently some 5,800 cases registered, but officials think the real figure is more than double that.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In related news, 164 nurses from Britain's National Health Service have volunteered to travel to West Africa to tackle the Ebola virus.

item.title: Cadillac ditches Detroit to woo more global elites.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: General Motors wants to up the 112-year-old luxury brand's cachet and attract more foreign consumers, so it's relocating 120 Cadillac employees to a shiny new headquarters in lower Manhattan's SoHo neighborhood in Q2 2015. Johan de Nysschen, Cadillac's new president as of August, said he wants to put "distance" between Cadillac and the rest of General Motors.

item.title: Albania has a pot problem.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The country's interior ministry says it has destroyed $8.2 billion worth of marijuana this year, the equivalent of 60% of the country's GDP. Half of that was captured in June during a five-day raid in the southern village of Lazarat, which is known as Albania's drug capital. Italian authorities say Lazart is capable of producing $6 billion of pot every year.

item.title: Samsung ends notebook sales in Europe.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Korean tech giant will reportedly stop selling laptops and Chromebooks in the region, despite reports that the PC market is bouncing back. Separately, a Samsung executive promised that the company's mobile business would bounce back "due to its strong fundamentals and technological prowess."

item.title: Xbox does a double take on China.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: After Microsoft mysteriously pulled the plug on the launch of the Xbox One in China without explanation, the company today confirmed that the Xbox will come this month after all, albeit one week later and with a limited selection of 10 titles.

item.title: Hollywood isn't giving enough screen time to working women
item.dc:creator: qzroya
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_269942" align="alignnone" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: Line is putting the breaks on going public.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The company behind the popular social-messaging app has decided to press pause (paywall) on its much-anticipated IPO plans, favoring a focus on global expansion instead. No one knows the real value of booming social apps like WhatsApp and Line. For investors in one of the fastest growing segments of the consumer internet, the answer will have to wait.

item.title: People around the world think CEOs should make much, much less
item.dc:creator: qzroya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/269972/people-worldwide-think-ceos-should-make-a-tiny-fraction-of-what-they-do/

item.title: Pfizer is trying again for a tax inversion.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The US drug company has expressed interest in acquiring Actavis, a smaller rival with a market value of $63.6 billion that recently moved its headquarters to Ireland for tax purposes, according to Bloomberg. The Obama administration is trying to restrict tax inversion deals, but is not blocking them completely.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Earlier this year Pfizer offered up to $114 billion for UK-based AstraZeneca in an attempt to move its headquarters to the UK to reduce its effective tax rates. The deal was met with political opposition stemming from skepticism over whether Pfizer would maintain jobs at British plants.

item.title: All the charts tell the same story: China’s economy looks weak.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/269859/all-the-charts-tell-the-same-story-chinas-economy-looks-weak/

item.title: A Scotland spin-off that worked, sort of.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Royal Bank of Scotland, which is 80%-owned by the British government, floated 25% of its stake in Citizens Financial for $3 billion. But the partial IPO of the US retail and commercial bank didn't go perfectly: shares sold for $21.50 per share, below the anticipated $23-$25 range.

item.title: Starbucks puts its money on green tea frappuccinos.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The coffee-shop chain will spend $913.5 million buying the 61% of its Japanese business it doesn’t already own from public shareholders and Sazaby League, which formed a joint venture with Starbucks in 1996. The chain thinks it can drive growth in Japan by focussing on ready-made beverages, which is already a popular market sector.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Starbucks gets more than 6% of its revenue from Asia, and has plans to expand its store footprint throughout the region. It also recently purchased non-coffee brands such as Teavana in part to diversify its offerings to a market that traditionally drinks tea.

item.title: US regulators investigate Pimco.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into whether the bond giant inflated the rate of returns for a fund aimed at small investors, according to the Wall Street Journal (paywall). The probe is reportedly assessing whether the company provided misleading information about fund values or performance—which is illegal even if it's unintentional.

item.title: BlackBerry hopes it'll be hip to be square.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The troubled Canadian smartphone brand is launching a 4.5- by 4.5-inch-screen handset that it hopes will revamp its popularity as the phone of choice for business users. BlackBerry is holding three events around the world to publicize the launch—in Toronto, London, and Dubai.

item.title: “Mohammed” is the most popular baby name in Israel.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Israeli government was forced to backtrack after initially releasing a list with only Hebrew names, thereby ignoring the 21% of the population that is Arab.

item.title: A new species of mushroom has been discovered in a London supermarket.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The mushrooms weren't growing wild—they were found in a packet of dried porcinis using DNA testing.

item.title: Some iPhone 6 Plus owners are bent out of shape.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Their devices have developed a pronounced bend in the middle, suggesting a possible structural flaw. Unlike phones that are supposed to flex as a design feature, the iPhone is not meant to be bendy.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=znK652H6yQM

item.title: India's probe makes it to Mars on the cheap.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The spacecraft, carrying cameras and a methane gas sensor that could detect conditions favorable for life, cost a mere $74 million—a tiny fraction of the cost of other Mars missions by the US, EU, and Japan. The Mangalyaan ("Mars craft" in Hindi) will send data back to Earth for six months, when it will run out of fuel.

item.title: TNT Express blew up its guidance.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Dutch shipping and logistics company said it no longer expects to meet its 2015 forecast of an 8% profit margin, and is setting aside €50 million ($64 million) to settle an antitrust case with French authorities. The firm offered no new profit guidance: shares fell 9% in early trading.

item.title: Assessing the impact of the US airstrikes in Syria.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The bombing campaign by the United States and its Arab allies—but mostly just the US—is suspected to have killed leaders of the Islamic State (paywall) as well as a senior member of the Khorasan Group, an Al Qaeda-linked terrorist group deemed to be potentially more dangerous to the West. Al-Nusra, a Syrian group closely allied with Khorasan, said in a statement that its leader was also killed in the bombings. President Obama reiterated this morning that ISIL must be "degraded and ultimately destroyed."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The targeting of multiple militant groups has sent the media into an explainer frenzy: Here's a good round-up of the aims and differences between the groups that have been acknowledged so far. For some interesting perspective on the Syrian strikes, consider this: Roughly 250 bombs were dropped in one night, the same number of bombs the US dropped on Sunni terrorists in Iraq between Aug. 8 and Sep. 10.

item.title: Paypal adds bitcoin support.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: PayPal has teamed up with BitPay, Coinbase, and GoCoin to allow North American merchants to collect their payments using the virtual currency. The news sent the price of bitcoin up by more than 10%, to $443.69. Some say Apple forced PayPal's hand on this, but the bitcoin processors say PayPal had been working with them for months.

item.title: Rocket prices its shares for an October IPO.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: When Rocket Internet goes public on Oct. 9 in Frankfurt, the German technology incubator expects its shares to trade at between 35.50 to 42.50 euros. That would give it a market cap of $7.8 billion, and make it Germany's largest IPO in a decade. Who knew that cloning American internet companies could be so lucrative?

item.title: China's steel industry is refusing to slow down.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: China makes half the world's steel, a feat that's only possible with government subsidies, but is the country making too much (paywall)? The price of steel bars is down 18% year-over-year, due to a 40% collapse (paywall) in price of iron ore, and output has increased by 4%. Mill operators are struggling to pay off their debt and find places to store excess inventory.

item.title: China's central bank may soon have a new boss.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Zhou Xiaochuan has been in charge of the People's Bank of China since 2002, making the 66-year-old the longest-serving chief of the world's soon-to-be largest economy. Rumors say he'll be replaced (paywall) as early as next month by Guo Shuqing, an ex-banker turned governor of Shandong provence. Chinese officials are required to retire at 65.

item.title: London's iconic cabs slow to a crawl to protest Uber.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Over a thousand taxi drivers in London caused a traffic jam around Trafalgar Square and Westminster by intentionally driving slow to protest unlicensed cabs. The cabbies say that the cars on the app-enabled service Uber should require licenses because their system is virtually identical to a taxi meter, calculating a rate based on distance driven.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A similar protest took place in June of this year, when an estimated 4,000 cabbies participated, according to Transport for London.

item.title: Walmart turns into a bank next month.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Green Dot Bank, launched just a year ago, is partnering with the American retail giant to offer checking accounts and a MasterCard debit card beginning in October. Walmart stores will act as bank branches for the bank's mobile banking platform GoBank, allowing customers a walk-in service to deposit cash and open accounts.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The physical presence that Walmart offers may give Green Dot, known for its prepaid payment cards, an advantage over its online-only competitors, such as Simple and Moven.

item.title: Japan bulks up its Russian sanctions.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Western sanctions against Russia have sent the ruble to lows never seen before, but Japan has been relatively mild with its punishments—until today, that is. In a bid to show solidarity with its G7 counterparts, Japan has placed restrictions on arms exports and banned (paywall) Russian banks from issuing securities in the country.

item.title: India asks Coke and Pepsi to put fruit juice in soda.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The 5% juice that Prime Minister Narendra Modi wants the companies to mix into their soda won't improve anyone's health, but the plan could help drive income to India's farmers—and reduce the millions of dollars worth of spoiled fruit that's thrown out because of a lack of cold storage.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: India has had a tumultuous relationship with soft drink companies. Coca-Cola pulled out of India in 1977 after a change in regulations would have required it to reveal its much-vaunted "secret formula" to work with an Indian company. It returned in 1993 after the law was changed. Soda was banned in several Indian states nearly a decade ago after the Center for Science and Environment published research showing that pesticide levels in a sample of 57 drinks were 24 times the country's recommended safe levels.

item.title: London will become a city that never sleeps—on the weekend.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Staying out until the wee hours of the night will be a lot easier in London come September 2015. Transport for London says it'll be launching 24-hour weekend underground service in a year's time. The city's mayor, Boris Johnson, says the move will add 2,000 jobs and $590 million to the local economy.

item.title: How Japan's maternity-leave policy hollows out its workforce
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/266841/economic-case-for-paternity-leave/

item.title: GM's salaries broke the rules.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: When the US Treasury bailed out General Motors, it stipulated that GM executives should have their salaries capped at $500,000. According to a recent analysis of the government's bailout program, TARP, 16 executives' salaries violated the decree, running up to $1.7 million a year—and the Treasury itself signed off on these inflated salaries.

item.title: The bubble pops for Chinese iPhone smugglers.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Apple’s new smartphone hasn’t been released yet in the mainland, which sent the gray market price surging to almost $1,500 over the weekend. But a glut of supply from Hong Kong has since driven prices down to about $980, hurting smugglers who had stockpiled the devices; the same model costs HK$5,588 ($720) in Hong Kong's Apple store.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A new version of Apple's iOS software was meant to fix a series of bugs from the iPhone 6 launch, but ended up creating more problems. Before Apple pulled the update, it caused some iPhones to lose cellular phone service and access to the devices' fingerprint scanners.

item.title: India’s Mars mission was cheaper than "Gravity."
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: It cost just $74 million to send the Mangalyaan spacecraft to Mars—thanks in part to these women—versus $100 million to make a movie about Sandra Bullock as an astronaut adrift in Earth orbit.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
This scene was pretty awesome, though:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C4pcg7bXgmU

item.title: Harvard names a new $36-billion man.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The university named Stephen Blyth, head of public markets at the school's investment company, as the new head of the world's largest endowment. The fund, which plans to increase its exposure to private equity and real estate in 2015, posted a return of 15.4% in fiscal 2014—the kind of outsized gains that have led some to call for the end of Harvard's non-profit status.

item.title: Obama hits the Islamic State where it hurts.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: US warplanes launched airstrikes targeting small IS oil refineries in Syria, an attempt to cut off some of the $2 million in daily oil sales that the extremist group uses to fund its operations. Despite the bombings, IS conquered new territory in a Kurdish area in northern Syria, near the Turkish border.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Caliphate Soldiers of Algeria killed French tourist Herve Gourdel, who was kidnapped on Sunday in retaliation for France's involvement in air strikes on Syria. French president François Hollande, who confirmed Gourdel's death, said the "operations against the Islamic State will continue."

item.title: H&M says it's too hot to shop.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: An unusually warm September caused shoppers to put off spending on autumn clothing, the Swedish retailer said, as sales grew only 7% compared with an average 16% in the six months before. Third-quarter pre-tax profits were up almost 20% on the year to 7 billion crowns ($972 million): shares slid 3.1%.

item.title: Ikea prepares the ground in India.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Swedish retail giant signed deals with two Indian states ahead of plans to open stores in Delhi, Mumbai, Bangalore, and Hyderabad, although no timeline was offered. In 2012 the Indian government lifted a long-standing ban on foreign companies setting up wholly-owned subsidiaries.

item.title: Mario Draghi predicts a euro zone bump.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The bloc will see "modest growth" in the second half of the year, the president of the European Central Bank told a Lithuanian business daily (in Lithuanian). Sanctions against Russia (and Moscow's counter-sanctions) have had a limited impact, he said, but it is up to national governments to "use any leeway to make fiscal policies more growth-friendly."

item.title: China discovered nearly $10 billion in fraudulent trade.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Export and import documents have been "faked, forged, and illegally re-used," the nation's foreign exchange inspection department said. The investigation covered 24 cities and provinces nationwide, including Qingdao, where a metal trading fraud has exposed banks to huge potential losses.

item.title: Why is Google declining "right to be forgotten" requests?
item.dc:creator: lmiraniqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/270954/what-google-is-telling-people-who-want-to-be-forgotten/

item.title: British police arrest nine men on terrorism charges.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: The men picked up in a series of raids of homes, businesses, and community facilities include Anjem Choudary, a high-profile radical Muslim preacher who has appeared on CNN. Choudary, 47, and the others aged 22 to 51 are accused of being members of a proscribed organization, supporting a proscribed organization, and encouraging terrorism.

item.title: US jobless claims unexpectedly rise.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The two-week running average of the number of people seeking unemployment benefits has risen by 12,000 to 293,000, the Labor Department said. Looking at the four-week average, however, benefit seekers are still declining in numbers. The more troubling news is that just 142,000 jobs were added last month, down from a 12-month running average of 212,000.

item.title: China splurges on Spanish goods.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Spanish prime minister Mariano Rajoy is in Beijing holding meetings with Chinese premier Li Keqiang. The two countries announced an agreement on $4 billion worth of business deals, ranging from fashion to telecommunications.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Chinese investments in foreign countries hit $90.2 billion last year, up 17% from a year prior. Li also asked the Rajoy to help reduce the time it takes Chinese people to obtain visas to Spain. "We hope to have more pragmatic cooperation with Spain, and look forward to expanding the number of people traveling between the two countries," he said.

item.title: A new software bug is said to be worse than Heartbleed.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: "Bash" is a word you may be hearing a lot in the coming days. It refers to the command line terminal that makes Linux and Unix systems run. A quarter-century-old security flaw in the line, also known as the "Shellshock" bug, may make your phone, your (Apple) computer, and the servers that online services use vulnerable to this newly discovered avenue of attack.

item.title: Sierra Leone quarantines another million people.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: With the death toll from Ebola approaching 3,000, Sierra Leone has placed three additional districts in the country's north and south under quarantine to contain the virus. More than a third of the country's 6.1 million people are now under medical lockdown, and the number of Ebola cases is only expected to increase.

item.title: Barbra Streisand is in it for long haul.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: People, Streisand's first album, topped the charts in 1964. Since then, the artist has had at least one No. 1 album in each and every decade—six, if you're counting—which is a first for any singer. Just to offer some perspective: Partners, her latest album, hit the top of Billboard's chart after selling only 196,000 copies. Kids nowadays stream.

item.title: The US attorney general is stepping down.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Eric Holder, 63, has tendered his resignation. He'll remain in his post until president Obama elects a successor that must then be confirmed by the US Senate. News of Holder's resignation perhaps shouldn't come as a shock, given that he told The New Yorker back in February that he'll be leaving office "sometime this year."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Holder came to his decision during a conversation with president Obama during Labor Day weekend, according to NPR, which cites two sources "familiar with the decision."

For further reading:

  • The Wall Street Journal has a handy timeline of Holder's actions in office.
  • The LA Times begins the speculation on Holder's replacement, and the difficulty Obama may have in confirming his nominee.
  • The Guardian asks how much Holder can "get done on race" before he steps down.

item.title: The EU is set to greenlight Facebook's WhatsApp purchase.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Since announcing its agreement to buy WhatsApp for $19 billion back in February, Facebook has been sitting on its hands, waiting for government officials to approve the deal. The US gave Zuck the thumbs-up in April, and now Reuters is reporting that the EU will soon announce their "unconditional clearance" of the takeover.

item.title: The bubble pops for Chinese iPhone smugglers.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/271170/the-price-of-a-gray-market-iphone-6-in-china-is-plummeting/

item.title: Rival Palestinian factions reconcile.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Fatah and Hamas will bury the hatchet in the name of progress for Gaza. The two reached a "comprehensive agreement" during negotiations in Egypt, stipulating that Fatah leader Mahmoud Abbas and the Palestinian Authority will take control of the strip, including civil administration duties. The factions will merge their security forces to man the territory's border crossings.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The estimated repair bill following Israel's 50-day attack on the territory is $7.8 billion. The conflict killed more than 2,100 Palestinians, mostly civilians, as well as 67 Israeli soldiers and six civilians in Israel. The unity government's inclusion of Hamas, classified by the US, Israel, and other countries as a terrorist group, could deter donors attending a conference in Egypt next month seeking to raise reconstruction funds for Gaza. A Fatah representative said the Palestinian Authority will seek membership in UN organizations, including the international criminal court, "to enable our people to hold Israel accountable for the war crimes it has committed."

item.title: Captured Islamic State fighters say subway attacks are in the works.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Iraqi prime minister Haidar al-Abadi told a group of reporters covering the United Nations General Assembly that security forces in Baghdad have captured American and French ISIL fighters who claim the militant group is planning attacks on public transport systems in New York and Paris.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The AP reports:

Asked if the attacks were imminent, he said, "I'm not sure." Asked if the attacks had been thwarted, he said, "No, it has not been disrupted yet... this is a network."

"Today, while I'm here I'm receiving accurate reports from Baghdad that there were arrests of a few elements and there were networks from inside Iraq to have attacks ... on metros of Paris and U.S.," al-Abadi said, speaking in English. "They are not Iraqis. Some of them are French, some of them are Americans. But they are in Iraq."

item.title: Vice adds $11 billion to Spain's GDP.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Drug trafficking, prostitution, smuggling, and illegal gambling made up 0.9% of Spain's economy—9 billion euros ($11.4 billion)—last year, according to the country's National Statistics Institute. For the sake of comparison, crime in Italy is said to contribute $230 billion to the country's GDP. Of course, none of this economic activity is being taxed.

item.title: Commercial drones get a lift.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: US regulators cleared several Hollywood movie studios to use the flying robots, the first time that corporations can legally use them in the lower 48 states (they were previously authorized for monitoring oil pipelines in Alaska). The Federal Aviation Administration's ruling is an encouraging sign for companies like Amazon and Google, which are also pursuing their own drone programs.

item.title: Islamic State executioner "Jihadi John" is identified.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The FBI has not released the name of the Islamic State member responsible for beheading three hostages in Syria, but said it discovered the man's identity after working with other intelligence agencies. "John" is likely UK-born, and has already threatened to kill a fourth hostage.

item.title: Where in the world is Kim Jong-un?
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The totalitarian leader of North Korea failed to appear at a parliamentary meeting on Thursday, continuing an unusual three-week absence from state media, which acknowledged he was suffering from "discomfort" as he "keeps lighting the path for the people, like the flicker of a flame." One expert on North Korea's leadership thinks Kim might be suffering from gout.

item.title: Cows actually really hate cowbells.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The 5.5 lb (2.5 kg) bells are as loud as a jackhammer, and the animals eat less grass when they’re wearing them.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
But the bells do sound lovely, whether it's in the Swiss Alps...
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KYGgWqiv8AU
...or the recording studio.
http://vimeo.com/91715361

item.title: Narendra Modi arrives in the US under the shadow of a human rights lawsuit.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: India's new prime minister is set to begin a five-day swing through New York and Washington, DC, including a huge gala at Madison Square Garden. But just before Modi's arrival, a US federal court issued a summons in a lawsuit connected with 2002 riots in his home state of Gujarat, where he was chief minister; the suit claims he committed crimes against humanity and sanctioned extra-judicial killings and torture, among other allegations.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Tune into Quartz India for a livestream of Indian prime minister Narendra Modi‘s 9/28 speech at Madison Square Garden in New York City, starting at 11 am EST and 8:30 pm IST. We’ll take your comments on our Facebook page.

item.title: Narendra Modi has a court summons waiting for him in New York.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Indian prime minister is set to begin a five-day swing through New York and Washington, DC, including a huge gala at Madison Square Garden. But just before his arrival a US federal court issued a summons in a lawsuit connected with 2002 riots in his home state of Gujarat, which claims he committed crimes against humanity and sanctioned extrajudicial killings and torture.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Tune into Quartz India for a livestream of Modi‘s Sept. 28 speech at Madison Square Garden in New York City, starting at 11 am EST / 8:30 pm IST. We’ll take your comments on our Facebook page.

item.title: The US is preparing a new nuclear proposal for Iran.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Diplomatic sources told the Associated Press that US negotiators may allow Iran to keep nearly half of its uranium enrichment program intact, in exchange for other constraints on building a nuclear weapon. The two longtime adversaries recently found themselves facing a common enemy in the extremist group the Islamic State.

item.title: Intel went to China for a piece of the smartphone business.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The US computer chipmaker agreed to pay $1.5 billion for a 20% stake in two mobile chip manufacturers backed by a Chinese government-affiliated private equity firm. The deal could help Intel's long-frustrated attempt to gain a foothold in the global smartphone industry, and boost China's own semiconductor industry.

item.title: The Bond King leaves his castle.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Bill Gross is leaving the investment firm he founded in 1971, Pacific Investment Management Company (Pimco), to join competitor Janus Capital Group. Pimco has been under SEC investigation for months about falsifying the performance of several funds in a bid to lure investors. Shares in Janus rose 43% on the news. Dan Ivascyn will replace Gross at Pimco.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Gross's departure followed conflict with other Pimco executives that led some to threaten to resign if he didn't leave, according to anonymous sources cited by the Wall Street Journal. ""I look forward to returning my full focus to the fixed income markets and investing, giving up many of the complexities that go with managing a large, complicated organization," Gross said in a statement.

item.title: Flights in and out of Chicago halted.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A fire at an air traffic control center in Aurora, Illinois has grounded nearly 1,800 flights at Chicago's O'Hare and Midway airports. Police say an employee who was discovered in the basement of the control tower suffering from self-inflicted wounds is to blame.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Nearly 1,800 flights have now been canceled.

item.title: "Airplane mode" no longer needed in Europe.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The European Aviation Safety Agency has declared that passengers can leave their mobile electronics powered on for the duration of flights, including take-off and landing. It's estimated that Europe's airlines will need as much as eight months to implement the new rules.

item.title: Smartphone encryption ruffles the FBI's feathers.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: FBI director James Comey is livid that the latest version of Apple's mobile operating system uses a form of encryption that makes it nearly impossible for law enforcement to retrieve sensitive data. Google's Android OS soon will add similar functionality. Comey says he's contacted Apple and Google and is awaiting a response.

item.title: Australia has a resettlement plan for asylum seekers.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The country's immigration minister signed a deal to pay Cambodia $35 million over four years to take in an untold number of refugees denied asylum in Australia. Human rights advocates are concerned.

item.title: No more Hungarian gas for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: After Russia stopped supplying Ukraine with natural gas back in June over a pricing dispute, Hungary, Poland, and Slovakia stepped in to fill demand. Today, however, Hungary changed its mind. Meanwhile, the European Union is brokering talks in Berlin to address Ukraine's gas needs for the coming winter.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Further talks between Russia and Ukraine are expected to take place next week. During today's negotiations, Guenther Oettinger, the the European Commission's commissioner for energy, said Ukraine is open to paying Russia $2 billion by the end of October and then a further $1.1 billion by the end of the year.

item.title: French cigarettes to lose their sex appeal.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: With 73,000 people dying every year in France from smoking-related illnesses, the government has announced plans to introduce plain packaging for cigarettes, in an attempt to make "children born today the first 'non-smoking' generation in 20 years." Australia tried a similar move in 2012; the impact on existing smokers is questionable.

item.title: The UK will join the battle against ISIL.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: After seven hours of fierce debate, the UK parliament voted—524 votes to 43 votes—to engage Islamic State forces in Iraq. Bombings could begin as early as Sunday. Earlier today, Belgium and Denmark also agreed to join the coalition. The former will deploy six F-16 fighter jets. The latter will send seven.

item.title: Activist investor wants to see Yahoo buy AOL.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Starboard Value has purchased a stake in Yahoo—size undisclosed—which it intends to use to try to force the company to acquire AOL. Starboard says there are potentially $1 billion in synergies the two can share between their businesses. Yahoo's stock is up over 4% on the news; AOL is up almost 3%.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: AOL CEO Tim Armstrong, when asked about the potential of a Yahoo acquisition in 2012, said the idea was "probably not in the cards," but now that Alibaba has gone public, would he change his mind? Speaking about Alibaba, it could technically buy Yahoo for essentially nothing, thought why would it is something worth pondering. Business Insider has the complete letter Starboard sent to Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer and its board of directors. Mayer says Yahoo will "review Starboard's letter carefully and look forward to discussing it with them."

item.title: Canada and Europe detail their new friendship.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A comprehensive trade agreement promises to boost trade between the two partners by 20%—if the treaty gets finalized. Germany is fretting, however, because of a clause that allows corporations to sue nations. It's unclear whether Germany has the legal authority to shoot down the deal.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Canada accounted for 1.7% of total external EU trade in 2013, making it Europe's 12th largest trading partner.

item.title: Foreign ownership of Russian media companies is capped at 20%.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The legislation passed by Russian parliament goes into effect in 2016, with compliance phased in through February 2017. (The current ownership maximum is 50%.) This could spell the end for Forbes' Russian edition; its editor told the Guardian that the publication's German publisher wouldn't want to sell to a Russian owner.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Russia's largest independent broadcasting company, CTC Media, is 38% owned by the Swedish Modern Times Group.

item.title: Goldman Sachs bans its bankers from betting on individual stocks.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Employees used to require approval to make such gambles, but now the whole idea of buying and selling individual stocks is out, along with investments in activist or event-driven hedge funds, according to Bloomberg. It's a favor, really, as targeted portfolios rarely beat the market.

item.title: The gap between Facebook and Google and everyone else is gradually widening.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz

item.title: Catalonia gets closer to its own referendum.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The president of the separatist-minded region of Spain has signed a decree calling for a vote on independence, possibly on Nov. 9. The national government in Madrid calls any attempt at a Scottish-style referendum illegal, and is likely to take the dispute over the vote—which Catalonians call a "consultation"—to Spain's Constitutional Court.

item.title: The Narendra Modi show continues.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: After speaking at the UN and wowing the crowds at Madison Square Garden, the Indian prime minister is set to meet 11 CEOs from companies including Google, PepsiCo, and Goldman Sachs. He then sits down for dinner with US president Barack Obama, although Modi will be continuing his 9-day religious fast (paywall).

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Here is his UN speech in Hindi, which Modi prefers to speak and has encouraged Indian diplomats to use: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u9pRzOZCxEc

item.title: No more cheese for Dear Leader.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Kim Jong-un is apparently suffering from gout brought on by a fondness for cheese, smoking, and whisky. North Korea has admitted its leader suffers from an "uncomfortable physical condition” but said no more. A source told South Korea's news agency that Kim also has "hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia, obesity, diabetes and high blood pressure."

item.title: Pro-democracy protests paralyze Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: kevinjdelaney
item.content:encoded: Following several days of tense clashes with police, organizers launched a civil disobedience campaign aimed at blocking Hong Kong's financial center. The protestors are demanding free elections for Hong Kong's next leader, while Beijing plans to limit the candidates to Chinese government loyalists.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Occupy Central movement marks an escalation of Hong Kong's simmering discontent with Chinese rule. You can follow the South China Morning Post's updating report on the protests here. Here's a video from Friday of Occupy Central co-organizer Benny Tai discussing whether Hong Kong will ever have genuine democracy. "If you have no demand for democracy, I think no one will give you democracy," Tai said. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CWKsz6WzU6w&feature=youtu.be Instagram has been blocked in mainland China, presumably a government effort to limit access to photos from the Hong Kong protests.

item.title: SoftBank sweet talks Dreamworks Animation.
item.dc:creator: kevinjdelaney
item.content:encoded: The Japanese telecom company is in talks the studio that made Shrek and Madagascar acquire for $3.4 billion, according to the Hollywood Reporter. After regulatory concerns sidelined Softbank's attempts to buy more mobile carriers like T-Mobile, the company is now focusing on acquiring content companies (paywall)—specifically video game and movie makers—to entice mobile subscribers.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Hollywood Reporter says DreamWorks Animation CEO Jeffrey Katzenberg would commit to staying with the company for five years. Former top Google executive Nikesh Arora, who is just joining SoftBank to set up a new internet and media unit, is playing a role in the discussions, according to the Hollywood Reporter. (Representatives of the companies have declined to comment.) For a look back at one of DreamWorks Animation's key franchises, here's the 2001 trailer for Shrek. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jYejzdBwvY4

item.title: Facebook Messenger is actually a monster hit
item.dc:creator: jasonqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/271596/facebook-messenger-is-actually-a-monster-hit/

item.title: At least 30 feared dead in Japanese volcano eruption.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Rescuers are searching for survivors at Mount Ontake, following a violent volcanic eruption yesterday at the popular hiking spot. Japan, no stranger to violent seismic activity, hasn't had any fatalities from eruptions since 1991.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Dramatic photos and video from survivors show how quickly the mountain was enveloped in smoke and ash: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7Ea3uED1Zgc

item.title: Air France pilots end their two-week strike.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The work stoppage led to widespread flight cancellations and cost the French flag carrier €20 million ($25 million) per day. The pilots' union isn't happy with new contract talks (paywall), but says that ending its strike will allow negotiations to take place "in a calmer climate."

item.title: Europe retains the Ryder Cup.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The continent's team reached the 14.5 points needed to win when Welshman Jamie Donaldson, a rookie at 38 years old, beat Keegan Bradley. The US team has not won an away contest since 1993 and Europe has now won eight of the past 10 contests.

item.title: France's far right party makes electoral gains.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The Front National will enter the upper chamber of the French parliament for the first time. Though the Senate doesn't have much power, the vote on Sunday saw the chamber swing to the right in yet another blow to socialist president Francois Hollande following the return of one-time nemesis, Nicolas Sarkozy.

item.title: Apple could face a big fine in Brussels.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The Financial Times reports (paywall) that the European Union will rule that a special tax deal with Ireland amounts to illegal state aid, saddling Apple with a large fine to recoup lost revenues. The European Commission opened up an investigation into Apple's dealings with Irish tax authorities in June, along with Starbucks and Fiat.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Apple CFO Luca Maestri told the Financial Times: “We know that we didn’t do anything that was against the law and we are very confident that through the investigation it will be shown that there was no selective treatment in our favor at any point in time."

item.title: We’re arriving at the endgame for BlackBerry.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/272530/blackberry-endgame/

item.title: The CIA has its own secretive Starbucks.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Langley, VA outlet—known only as "Store Number 1" on receipts—forswears loyalty cards and writing customers' names on their cups due to secrecy concerns. “But I have no idea what they do,” said one background-checked barista. “I just know they need coffee, a lot of it.”

item.title: Alibaba extends its shopping spree.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The newly-flush Chinese internet giant will spend $459 million on 15% of Beijing Shiji Information, an technology company that caters to hotels. Alibaba hopes to build its own travel business and recruit hotel customers to its e-commerce platform.

item.title: Italian tax authorities are investigating Prada's married co-CEOs.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Hong Kong-listed fashion house said in a statement that Miuccia Prada and her husband Patrizio Bertelli are the targets of "an ongoing examination ... regarding the accuracy of certain past tax filings." Italian tax officials, who last year won a tax fraud case against designers Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana, are reportedly looking at Prada Holding’s "alleged tax evasion over the 10 years the holding company was in Luxembourg," according to the Financial Times (paywall).

item.title: UBS claims its focus on wealth management is paying off.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Swiss bank said it only took two months to pile up profits of 731 million Swiss francs ($769 million), which is already more than analysts expected for the entire third quarter, after it scaled back on investment banking to focus on fee-based wealth management services. But as one analyst noted to Bloomberg, “This is better than expected but then expectations aren’t very high any more."

item.title: US hits new targets in Syria, civilian deaths claimed.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The US-led coalition bombed the entrance to a major Syrian gas plant controlled by the Islamic State, after previously targeting only small oil refineries. The US-led forces also destroyed a grain silo in the north of the country, possibly by accident, and killed a number of civilians, according to the UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights.

item.title: China's censors are working to keep its citizens in the dark.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Despite the attempt at an information blackout, it's obvious that mainland internet users are interested in what is happening in Hong Kong. Before censors tightened their reins on Weibo, "Hong Kong" was a trending topic. On FreeWeibo, a website that publishes deleted Weibo posts, "Hong Kong" and "Occupy Central" were the two top searches today. https://twitter.com/JoeXu/status/516372867798548480 "They are our brothers and sisters. They're Chinese," said a 28-year-old pharmaceutical researcher in Chengdu who would only give his surname, Li. "How the government treats them is how they will treat us."
http://qz.com/272690/chinese-censors-are-trying-to-erase-hong-kongs-pro-democracy-movement/

Hong Kong and Instagram getting blocked all top trending on weibo before taken down pic.twitter.com/TYNKp4hTmZ

— Joe Xu (@JoeXu) September 28, 2014

item.title: A bloodless transfer of power in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Ashraf Ghani, a former finance minister and World Bank technocrat, has been sworn in as president. He will share power with his bitter rival, Abdullah Abdullah, who takes the new position of chief executive office. Their first order of business: Give US troops permission to stay in the country past 2014.

item.title: How to turn a tractor into a tank.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Kurdish fighters may not have the most advanced military equipment, but their resourcefulness—plus a couple of buckets of paint—has resulted in the creation of battle-hardened vehicles that look like they were ripped from the 1979 film "Mad Max." Luckily for people in and around the Syrian city of Kobane, these battle-bots are being supported by US-led airstrikes.

item.title: Microsoft beats Sony and Nintendo to the punch in China.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Xbox One became the first video-game console to enter the market after China ended a 14-year ban. The first machines were sold in Shanghai, for 4,299 yuan ($699).

item.title: Unlike the Scots, Catalans may not even get an independence vote.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy wants Catalonia's plan to vote for independence on Nov 9 declared illegal. According to the country's 1978 constitution, important matters must be agreed upon by all Spanish citizens, not just the 16%—7.5 million people—who make up Catalonia. As an independent region, Catalonia's economy would be larger than Portugal's.

item.title: Look for self-driving BMWs speeding along the Great Wall.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The German auto-maker is bringing its prototype autonomous vehicles to Beijing and Shanghai for testing in collaboration with Baidu. The partnership between BMW and China's largest search engine was inked just a few weeks ago; there's no word on when the intelligent driving machines will go on sale.

item.title: Solar could be bigger than fossil fuels by 2050—if we really try.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: According to a report from the International Energy Agency, electricity generated from photovoltaic systems and solar thermal collectors could generate 16% and 11% of the world's energy needs by 2050, respectively, together surpassing fossil-fuel sources. But that will only come about if the right policy programs and incentives are put in place.

item.title: Dilma Rousseff pulls ahead.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Brazil's president has clawed back a nine-point lead over surprise challenger Marina Silva according to a new poll from the MDA firm. Some recent polls have given the lead to Silva, who took up the baton only weeks ago after a plane crash killed her running mate. The first round of voting is on Oct. 5.

item.title: The SoftBank-DreamWorks deal might not happen.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: According to The Wall Street Journal (paywall), talks between the Japanese wireless firm and the Hollywood movie studio have “cooled”, sending the latter’s stock down as much 8% in after-hours trading. Rumors of the deal only began swirling on Saturday.

item.title: Argentina gets slapped down again.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The US judge who ruled against the country in its dispute with foreign bondholders declared it in contempt of court (paywall) for trying to circumvent his ruling. He hasn’t set a punishment yet, though it’ll probably be small compared with the debts Argentina owes.

item.title: Apple can finally sell the iPhone 6 in China.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Regulators approved the new smartphones for sale after mysteriously withholding a crucial license for several weeks. But if the price of gray-market iPhones is anything to go by, demand is not exactly sky-high.

item.title: Hong Kong's streets are eerily quiet.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Pro-democracy protests have turned the center of the city into a car-free zone, after a night without any significant confrontations between demonstrators and police. The size of the crowd is smaller this morning, but is expected to swell again in the evening, ahead of tomorrow’s National Day holiday celebrating the founding of China. You can follow the action from the "Umbrella Revolution" here.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Protestors are stockpiling supplies as they prepare for an extended stay. They have demanded that the city's chief executive, Leung Chun-ying step down by October 1, and warned that if he didn't they would remain on the streets for several more days. Here's a scene from last night: https://twitter.com/AFP/status/516646317129744384

Demonstrators hold up cellphones in a display of solidarity during a protest in Hong Kong #Photo by Xaume Olleros pic.twitter.com/EmFASrwkRM

— Agence France-Presse (@AFP) September 29, 2014

item.title: Turkish tanks do battle with the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Shells fired from by the extremist group in Syria landed inside Turkey, killing two soldiers and wounding five others, prompting Turkish tanks to return fire. President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has acknowledged that Turkey "can't stay out" of the US-led campaign against IS.

item.title: Netflix is making an original movie—but it won’t come cheap
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The video streaming company will work with The Weinstein Company to produce a sequel to "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon," the first of several films that will premier simultaneously on Netflix and in Imax theaters. But shelling out for a Hollywood-scale production will be a heavy lift financially, since it will only provide a few hours of entertainment compared to an episodic series like "House of Cards."

item.title: The world has just half the animals it had 40 years ago.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A London Zoological Society study revised its previous estimate that animal populations fell 30% in 40 years, stating that they declined by an average 52% instead. The main threats to numbers are habitat loss and degradation, said the WWF, an animal protection group that collaborated on the report.

item.title: Brazil’s markets fear four more years of Dilma Rousseff
item.dc:creator: jasonqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/273145/brazils-markets-are-spooked-by-the-thought-of-four-more-years-of-dilma-rousseff/

item.title: The EU details its case against Apple's Irish tax deals.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: A letter to Irish officials (pdf) about the country's allegedly illegal aid to the electronics giant reveals the minutes of meetings between Apple and Irish tax officials, which the commission cites as proof that Apple and Ireland worked to "reverse engineer" financial results in order to lower the firm's tax bill. The probe could saddle Apple with a multi-billion-euro fine.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The commission also published the letter it sent to Luxembourg (pdf, in French), in a similar case on the tax treatment of automaker Fiat's financial services arm. The EU is also investigating the Netherlands' tax deal with Starbucks, although details of that case have not yet been revealed.

item.title: Thailand’s answer to a grisly double murder is ID wristbands for tourists.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The grisly killings of two English tourists on the Thai island of Koh Tao remain unsolved after nearly three weeks, so the country's tourism minister is proposing the wristbands—and eventually "some sort of electronic tracking device"—to improve safety. But it’s unclear how such an elaborate system would ever be implemented, or how it would have saved the lives of Hannah Witheridge, 23, and David Miller, 24, who were murdered on a beach in Koh Tao.

item.title: Euro zone inflation is at a five-year low.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Consumer prices rose by only 0.3% in September, as expected, a fraction of the ECB’s target of about 2%. Separately, German unemployment unexpectedly ticked higher in September, and the UK’s second quarter GDP growth was revised upward to 0.9%.

item.title: Out with the new Windows, in with the old.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Microsoft will unveil a new version of its operating system today, codenamed Threshold. It will most likely roll back many of the changes of the previous version, which the world largely rejected, and aim to be more enterprise-friendly.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Some Windows 8 users were kind enough to complain that the update was simply ahead of its time for its touchscreen capabilities and tablet-like interface: plenty more were happier to point out the similarities between it and some sights that are best forgotten.

item.title: The EU details its tax case against Apple in Ireland.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A letter to Irish officials (pdf) about the country’s allegedly illegal aid to the electronics giant reveals the minutes of meetings between Apple and Irish tax officials, which the commission cites as proof that Apple and Ireland worked to “reverse engineer” financial results in order to lower the firm’s tax bill. The probe could saddle Apple with a multi-billion-euro fine.

item.title: ExxonMobil strengthens Putin’s hand against the West.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The oil giant asked and received a delay to sanctions to allow it to safely wind down a drilling project in the Russian Arctic. But in that time it discovered a massive oil and gas field, which gives Russian president Vladimir Putin extra incentive to maintain his defiant stance over the Ukraine.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Last week Putin wrote to Ukrainian president Petro Poroshenko threatening to reduce Ukraine's access to Russian markets if it goes ahead with a long-planned trade agreement with the EU. With a billion new barrels of oil coming to him, these are precisely the kind of moves Putin could now make while trying to wait out Western sanctions.

item.title: EBay and PayPal to part ways.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: After years of justifying staying together, eBay announced that it will split from payments provider PayPal next year. Ebay CEO John Donahoe will step down once the auction and payments businesses become separate publicly-traded companies.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: "When you look forward, eBay will be less than 15% of Paypal's business three years from now and we can achieve many of the benefits of the synergies through arms-length commercial relationships," Donahoe told CNBC.

item.title: EU sanctions on Russia will stay put.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Despite the progress made since Russia and Ukraine signed a ceasefire agreement on Sept. 5, an EU spokeswoman said that more needs to be done before sanctions can be lifted. Yesterday was the bloodiest day of fighting since the peace deal was reached—seven Ukrainian troops were killed near Donetsk airport.

item.title: Netflix is making a movie—its first.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: "House of Cards" and "Orange is the new Black" have won numerous awards, but Netflix has greater ambitions. The streaming service, in partnership with the Weinstein Company, will release a sequel to the 2000 film "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon". In Aug. 2015, Netflix's 50 million users will get to choose whether they want to see it at home or on the silver screen.

item.title: Catalonia scraps independence vote marketing blitz.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: When the Catalonian government scheduled a Nov. 9 referendum on its sovereignty, the Spanish government asked the constitutional court to intervene. Sure enough, it did, prompting Catalonia to stop publicizing the referendum (paywall) for fear of defying the court's ruling. Private individuals, however, are still free to beat the independence drum.

item.title: Kenya magically becomes a middle-income country.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: After Kenya's statistics agency rebased GDP figures and tweaked an Excel spreadsheet, the economy "grew" by 25% to an annual GDP of $55.2 billion last year versus a previously reported $44.1 billion. The World Bank now considers the African nation to be a "middle-income" economy instead of a "low-income" one. Even with per capita GDP now $1,246, however, poverty levels remain at 45.9%.

item.title: The UK finally joins the battle against the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Royal Air Force said its jets destroyed an armored truck and a "heavy weapon position" in Iraq. Kurdish forces said the attacks helped them win control of an area near the Iraq-Syria border.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Not surprisingly, the Islamic State is capitalizing on its home turf advantage. When ISIL fighters receive word of an imminent airstrike, they tear down their camps and simply relocate. They also issue orders to curtail the usage of military-grade vehicles and mobile phones, to be less conspicuous.

item.title: Sweden's sewage has an explosive secret.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The pipes that run under the homes of Stockholm's 700,000 residents are being retrofitted with sensors that can detect the chemicals bomb makers use to manufacture their explosives. Members of the UK's Ministry of Defence and the US Department of Homeland Security have taken an interest in the project, which is known as "Emphasis".

item.title: Microsoft demos Windows 10—mysteriously skips Windows 9.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Starting tomorrow, Microsoft will offer an early version of the operating system that it plans on delivering in mid-2015. Windows 10 strips away many of the Windows 8 features that drove users to buy tablets instead of upgrading their current PCs.

item.title: Ebola reaches the US...
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: An unnamed man was diagnosed with the Ebola virus in Dallas, Texas, after coming to the US from Liberia. The head of the US Centers for Disease Control said he has “no doubt we will stop this in its tracks," and indeed it is almost impossible for the disease to spread in the United States—but shares of drug firms spiked anyway.

item.title: Nigeria gets its Ebola outbreak under control.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: All known Ebola patients in the country are now being treated and no new cases have been reported for a month. Senegal has also not had any new cases for a month, and its only patient has recovered from the virus.

item.title: w
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

item.title: Reddit taps celebrities and Silicon Valley for funding.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The social media site raised $50 million from rapper Snoop Dogg and actor Jared Leto along with venture capitalists  Marc Andreessen and Peter Thiel, valuing it at a reported $500 million. Investors will also give 10% of their shares to Reddit users, who monitor the site and perform crucial maintenance tasks.

item.title: Who is paying for America's $1.2 billion election cycle?
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/273071/the-1-2-billion-and-counting-of-2014-us-political-spending-in-charts/

item.title: Caffeinated underwear is pulled from US shelves.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The bras, girdles, and leggings were supposed to aid weight loss, but turned out to be decaf. Misled consumers will receive about $1.5 million in refunds.

item.title: Hong Kong protests enter a fourth night.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Protesters booed the Chinese flag and jeered champagne-sipping city leaders at a ceremony for China’s National Day—a holiday that resulted in bigger crowds but no confrontations with police. Hong Kong and Beijing officials appear to be waiting the protests out, rather than cracking down or bending to demonstrators’ demands.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Wall Street Journal (paywall) reports that Hong Kong's government is now open to meeting with protesters, but only if there are no preconditions to such a meeting. The protest's organizers said they are not going to back down from their demand that Hong Kong Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying resigns. The protestors have gotten a lot of positive press for their politeness, but there was some confrontation when Falun Gong activists—detested by the Beijing government—wanted to march through an area occupied by democracy protestors. The pro-democracy camp eventually turned away the Falun Gong group to avoid association.

item.title: A networking app from the Hong Kong protests is also a hit in India.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Firechat lets smartphone users communicate without an internet connection, or share connectivity where it's scarce. Hong Kong pre-democracy protesters are using it to pre-empt a government internet crackdown, but in India it is helping to make the most of the country's rickety communications infrastructure.

item.title: Adidas kicks off a shareholder charm offensive.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: As hedge funds prepare to push for management changes, the world's second-largest sportswear maker will return €1.5 billion ($1.9 billion) to unhappy investors over the next three years through share buybacks, dividends, and other means. Adidas has issued three profit warnings already this year.

item.title: Ukraine’s ceasefire is barely holding.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Separatists have repeatedly shelled Ukraine army positions and tried to storm the Donetsk airport, according to the Kyiv government. The US ambassador says Russian forces and equipment are still in Ukraine, and the border is unsecured.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Shelling even hit a Donetsk school, killing a parent, a teacher, and two other adults—no children were killed according to preliminary reports. The IMF cut Russia's GDP forecast by half—to 0.5%—citing "geopolitical uncertainties," which is a polite way of saying the situation in Ukraine.

item.title: France will hit its twice-delayed deficit target, it swears.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The slow European recovery has caused France to delay—yet again—its goal of reducing the public deficit to below 3%. It had aimed to reach EU-mandated debt levels by 2013, but now says it'll only be able to do that in 2017. It will have to cut 50 billion euros from projected public spending between now and then.

item.title: India and the US will blast off into space together.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: NASA and India's Space Research Organisation (ISRO) signed a pair of agreements yesterday that will see the two nations working together to launch an Earth-monitoring spacecraft by 2020 and to form a joint mission planning team that will be responsible for researching Mars. India could certainly teach NASA a thing or two about budget space travel.

item.title: Germany wants to put blinders on Google's all-knowing eye.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: If you use multiple Google services, Google aggregates the data you leave strewn across its platforms to form a profile pegging your sex, age, relationship status, and even finances. Hamburg's data protection authorities have told Google they want it to modify its privacy policy so that this profiling is under users' control.

item.title: Bank CEOs can finally make ends meet again.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Bank CEO compensation levels have recovered and reached the heights of pre-crisis levels, according to a new report from the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The heads of European institutions even saw their salaries increase compared to 2008. None of this should be too surprising—where there's a will, there's a way.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The IMF recommends tying executive pay more closely to risk, to dampen the risk-taking that contributed to the global financial crisis.

item.title: Women snackers are driving the $374-billion global snack industry.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/273864/whos-snacking-where-on-what-eating-habits-by-gender-and-region/

item.title: That convenient Wi-Fi on planes could blank out cockpit screens.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The US Federal Aviation Administration is has ordered airlines to replace Honeywell-made cockpit displays that don't seem to get along with Wi-Fi signals and cellular devices. The screens, which can blank out with interference, are in in 1,326 planes—Boeing 737 and 777 models—and must be replaced over the next five years at a cost of $13.8 million.

item.title: Pepsi sweetened with stevia is launching as an Amazon exclusive.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Pepsi True will look and taste like regular Pepsi, but it'll be sweetened with a combination of sugar and the herbal sweetener stevia instead of high-fructose corn syrup. True will eventually be on grocery store shelves, but not the big chains. The new concoction will be 40 calories lighter than the original, though the health-conscious should probably still stick to water.

item.title: Despite coalition bombings, ISIL forces are set to capture Kobani.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: ISIL fighters are just a kilometer away from the entrance of the Syrian town on the border with Turkey, which is being defended by Kurdish forces. This comes in spite of the UK successfully destroying multiple targets this week and the US-led bombing of three oil refineries that were funding ISIL to the tune of $3 million per day.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Turkey's parliament is due to vote on whether to augment the firepower currently being supplied by the US and its allies.

item.title: Art-fancying will soon be a seven-day-a-week activity in France.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Starting next year, the Louvre, the Palace of Versailles, and the Musée d'Orsay will be open every day, instead of just six days a week. Combined, the three attract 19.7 million visitors a year—larger than the entire population of the Netherlands. The move will boost the local economy, but will it help France pay its bills?

item.title: You're not the only one who has dropped your phone in the toilet.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/274368/theres-a-good-chance-youre-reading-this-on-a-damaged-mobile-device/

item.title: Viagra could damage some men's vision.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Sildenafil, the active ingredient in Viagra, can cause temporary vision problems for anyone, but for the one in 50 men who carry a mutated gene linked to retinal degeneration, the drug may do more harm. Mice with the gene who took slidenafil experienced vision damage for two weeks and their eyes showed early signs of cell death.

item.title: Fumbles force the US Secret Service director to resign.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: First there was the fence-jumper incident. Then the revelation that an armed security contractor—an ex-convict—rode an elevator with president Barack Obama. Director Julia Pierson stepped down after a grilling on Capitol Hill yesterday from members of both parties, who questioned her agency's competence. She'll be replaced by a retired Secret Service man, Joseph Clancy.

item.title: The Texas Ebola patient is identified as a mid-40s man from Monrovia.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Government officials in Liberia have revealed the identity of the man being treated in Dallas for the first US case of the Ebola virus. His name is Thomas Eric Duncan and he lives in the country's capital, where he worked for a company that helps FedEx get its packages through custom controls.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Duncan, who arrived in the US on Sept. 20, went to hospital with symptoms on Sept. 26 but was sent home, despite telling them he had recently arrived from Liberia, where the disease is spreading rapidly. He returned two days later and is now in intensive care at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital in Dallas. Health officials are monitoring at least 12 to 18 people have been had contact with Duncan in the US, including three members of the ambulance crew that transported him to the hospital and five children who returned to school after being exposed to Duncan. Before leaving Liberia, Duncan helped transport a pregnant neighbor with the disease to hospital, riding with her in a car and helping to carry her in, the New York Times reports (paywall). She later died.

item.title: The six companies that make 50% of the world’s beer.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/274568/the-family-trees-of-the-five-companies-that-make-50-of-the-worlds-beer/

item.title: The odds of scoring a US diversity visa are not in your favor.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/273868/if-you-have-a-high-school-diploma-and-come-from-these-countries-you-can-enlist-in-a-lottery-for-a-us-green-card/

item.title: Hyundai workers return to the factory floor.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Staff voted by a slim 51.5% margin to end to a strike that was expanded after Hyundai paid $10 billion for a trophy plot of land in Seoul's Gangnam district. The company's workers, who will each receive payments of 8.9 million won ($8,400), have gone on strike for all but four of their union's 27-year history.

item.title: Hong Kong's protests could get messy
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Now in their fifth day, the pro-democracy protests that have shut down much of central Hong Kong may shift from the festive atmosphere of the past few days to a political showdown. Student activists set today as a deadline for the city's chief executive to step down and vow to storm government buildings if he does not.

item.title: Hong Kong's protests could get messy
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: Now in their fifth day, the pro-democracy protests that have shut down central Hong Kong may transition from the festive atmosphere of recent days to political showdown. Student activists have set the end of today as the deadline for the city's chief executive to retire, and vow to storm government buildings if he does not.

item.title: The Hong Kong cops are preparing their riot gear.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Pro-democracy demonstrators who have shut down central Hong Kong for five days are calling for CY Leung, the city’s chief executive, to step down. He has refused, but he's said Chief Secretary Carrie Lam will hold negotiations with the protestors and discuss potential constitutional reform. Beijing is pledging its support for Leung and police are warning of serious consequences if protesters don't stand down.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Protest leaders on Twitter are warning that the police are mobilizing with tear gas, batons, and other crowd control gear. https://twitter.com/tomgrundy/status/517608543730425858 https://twitter.com/krislc/status/517605380147253248 https://twitter.com/george_chen/status/517609324206882816 The South China Morning Post reports on its live blog:
