Crowds getting worked up in Tamar, outside CY Leung's office behind the PLA barracks, after they spot police officers bringing in dozens of boxes labelled "batons" and others marked "flammable" and "corrosive". Suspecting they are weapons or riot gear, protesters shout "shameless" and "explain". Police supplies are trickling in through a narrow path between anti-protest metal fences and the stone wall of the barracks. Officers are bringing them into the government offices one by one. As angry protesters surge forward, police struggle to maintain the supply line.
Here's the latest statement from Hong Kong's government: https://twitter.com/varsitycuhk/status/517613475627925505/photo/1

Student leader Agnes Chow says police are amassing, asks protesters to tell friends to come #Occupycentral pic.twitter.com/hLjnGRYg6y

— Tom Grundy (@tomgrundy) October 2, 2014

NOW at Police Headquarters #UmbrellaRevolution pic.twitter.com/trn8husmc0

— Kris Cheng (@krislc) October 2, 2014

Asked if Hong Kong Police will fire tear gas at protesters again, HK police spox: "won't rule out the possibility", if they ignore warnings.

— George Chen (@george_chen) October 2, 2014

item.title: Zara throws in with Alibaba.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: One of the world’s largest fashion retailers agreed to sell its apparel via Tmall, an Alibaba platform that takes a commission on sales. Despite Zara being one of the most popular brands in China, its Zara.cn site failed to make an impact.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Although Zara will need to concede between 0.5%-5% of its sales revenue to Alibaba, a huge rise in visibility may not be the only benefit the retailer has in mind: it may also force Tmall to finally push imitators, such as Zara Kara, off the platform.

item.title: Netflix gets Adam Sandler.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The actor's Happy Madison production company will produce four feature films that will premiere exclusively on the streaming service. Netflix has had a successful run making top-of-the-line TV dramas like "Orange is the New Black," but now it seems to be making a foray into action movie sequels and lowbrow comedies; most of Sandler's latest films have tanked at the box office and been savaged by critics.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Sandler issued the following statement:
When these fine people came to me with an offer to make four movies for them, I immediately said yes for one reason and one reason only... Netflix rhymes with Wet Chicks. Let the streaming begin!!!!
Netflix may be calculating that whatever the comedic or financial shortcomings of his recent oeuvre, Sandler remains a global box office draw with billions in lifetime box office sales. The company said that audience data shows that Netflix users watch his films again, and again, and again. And check out the love he gets on his Instagram: http://instagram.com/p/toudlYqQH5

item.title: Is China finally choosing reform over growth?
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The central government said it would begin capping local governments' borrowing levels to encourage accountability (though it didn't specify the amount of the quota) and to prevent officials from taking on more debt through off-balance sheet financing vehicles. The move could mean a short-term drop in infrastructure spending and is unlikely to help China reach its annual GDP growth target of 7.5%.

item.title: Rocket Internet's IPO misfires.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The German technology incubator's shares fell 12% on their first day of trading in Frankfurt. Rocket—sometimes accused of cloning other online business ideas—priced the €1.6 billion sale at the top end of its expected range, giving the company an initial value of €6.7 billion ($8.5 billion).

item.title: Beer's family tree.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/274568/the-family-trees-of-the-five-companies-that-make-50-of-the-worlds-beer/

item.title: The European Central Bank tries to save the day (again).
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The ECB left its rock-bottom interest rates unchanged, as expected, but market watchers were anyway more interested in president Mario Draghi's press conference, where he revealed details of a bond-buying plan. The ECB has hinted that it could boost its balance sheet by up to €1 trillion ($1.26 trillion) in hopes of jumpstarting the euro zone’s moribund economy.

item.title: Strife is battering the Ukrainian economy.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The World Bank has revised its estimates for the country's economic prospects. Instead of shrinking 5% this year and then growing 2.5% in 2015, it now says the economy will shrink by 8% this year and a further 1% next year. The revision was due to the fighting between government forces and Russia-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine—which continues despite a ceasefire agreement.

item.title: The Angry Birds have come to roost.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In a note published by Rovio Entertainment CEO Mikael Hed, he admits that the company behind the addictive online and mobile game Angry Birds has been "building our team on assumptions of faster growth than have materialized." Thus, 130 employees in Finland—16% of its workforce—are being let go. Hed will step down in January and hand the slingshot to Pekka Rantala.

item.title: Elon Musk tweets about an elusive "D".
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The CEO of Tesla and SpaceX tweeted an image of a car in a dimly lit garage with a large "D" painted on the garage door. Under the text: "Oct. 9—mark your calendars."—which could allude to an upgrade or new vehicle. Tesla is currently selling the Model S, will soon sell the Model X, and plans an affordable Model 3 for 2017.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/517486950589014016

About time to unveil the D and something else pic.twitter.com/qp23yi59i6

— Elon Musk (@elonmusk) October 2, 2014

item.title: US jobless claims just keep on falling.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: For the third week in a row, the number of people seeking US unemployment benefits has fallen, approaching their lowest level in years. The latest figure from the labor department has claims falling by 8,000 to 287,000 during the final week of September. Investors were expecting an increase to 298,000 due to other economic indicators suggesting lagging growth.

item.title: Ukraine rebels take another stab at Donetsk airport.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Despite a Sept. 5 ceasefire that increasingly looks irrelevant, rebel forces in eastern Ukraine say they have captured 95% of the government-held airport in Donetsk. An AP reporter said Ukraine may have already lost control of the facility, which would help resupply the rebel fighters.

item.title: The diseases that kill children around the world
item.dc:creator: qzroya

item.title: Warren Buffett is now a car salesman.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The second richest person in America—according to Forbes—has purchased the Van Tuyl Group, an independent chain of 78 car dealerships with locations in 10 US states. Details of the transition weren't disclosed. Buffet will rename the group Berkshire Hathaway Automotive, though the $8 billion business will still be operated by Larry Van Tuyl.

item.title: Apple sweetens its employee perks.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In an effort to compete with Facebook and Google hiring and hold onto its 98,000 employees, the iPhone and iPad maker is upping the HR ante. That means longer parental leave, reimbursement for college classes, a more expansive donation-matching program, and pampering at an in-house zen palace health spa.

item.title: The most popular university major in the US leads to the least fulfilling work
item.dc:creator: qzroya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/275139/the-most-popular-university-major-in-the-us-leads-to-the-least-fulfilling-work/

item.title: You too can live like New York mayor Bill de Blasio.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The former Brooklynite has been living in Gracie Mansion since July, so it's about time he put up his three-story townhouse in Park Slope up on the market. Living there will cost you only $4,975 a month, but you'll have to ditch all pets and smoking habits.

item.title: Bob Iger will be sitting pretty at Disney for a while.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Disney CEO is settling into two more years on the job, having extended his stay once already. His new departure date is June 2018. The market's still not sure what to make of the decision.

item.title: Turkey approves the use of force against ISIL.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The country's military is cleared to fight in both Iraq and Syria against the extremist group, and allied nations will be able to conduct campaigns from Turkish soil. The Syrian town of Kobani—which sits on Turkey’s border—is on the verge of being captured by ISIL, spurring an exodus of refugees.

item.title: Wall Street hates nice people.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: GoPro’s shares fell by nearly 9% after investors discovered the company’s founders donated $500 million worth of company shares to charity.

item.title: Hong Kong's government workers just got the day off.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: They can't get to work because pro-democracy demonstrators are barricading government buildings. Quartz's Heather Timmons is on the scene.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
https://twitter.com/HeathaT/status/517843214338752512
https://twitter.com/HeathaT/status/517833137087193088
https://twitter.com/HeathaT/status/517820464412889088

HK govt rep outside HQ just announced that all public servants have the day off (b/c people can't get in) #OccupyCentral won this round

— Heather Timmons (@HeathaT) October 3, 2014

HK govt employees who can't get to work now milling around outside #OccupyCentral pic.twitter.com/tJXDEXhQpq

— Heather Timmons (@HeathaT) October 3, 2014

"Imagine" banner at #OccupyCentral pic.twitter.com/MBSjPv9qMg

— Heather Timmons (@HeathaT) October 2, 2014

item.title: Another Hong Kong showdown.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Minutes before the deadline that protestors gave chief executive CY Leung to resign, Leung refused to relinquish power but offered demonstrators a chance to begin talks with his deputy, chief secretary Carrie Lam. No date was given for the meeting, which Hong Kong's CEO said would only apply to only one of the student groups involved: it seems Leung has played a Machiavellian maneuver to try to urge protestors to go home, lest they lose this opportunity.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Some scuffles broke out among protestors who argued over whether or not to remove barricades, but most government buildings remain closed as activists await a confirmed date (live feed) to speak with Lam.

item.title: JPMorgan's data breach turns out to be absolutely enormous.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: A cyberattack exposed the personal information of 76 million households and 7 million businesses; the bank previously said only 1 million were affected. The hacker attack, now among the largest ever, gained access to names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails, putting customers at risk for further fraud attempts

item.title: As Hong Kong's protestors clash, negotiations are delayed.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Around the city, chaotic scuffles erupted between pro-democracy protesters, people opposed to protests, and police, in what appeared to be an organized attack on three different protest areas. Scheduled talks have been postponed because the protest leaders say the government isn't protecting them.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Protesters unhappy with chief executive CY Leung's refusal to step down last night had barricaded the government's offices, forcing the city to declare another day off. Several foreign reporters were asked to leave, and at least one was stuck by a man opposed to the protest. “We’re going to protest until the government takes responsibility, until the chief executive resigns, and until we really have universal suffrage,” said a protester named Lucas, 24, who was stationed outside, wearing a raincoat and a mask. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BB8ZGN2dwJ4 After several small but tense scuffles, it became clear that the protesters wouldn’t budge. A government representative came out with a megaphone and announced that all public servants have the day off. Then the workers that had already entered the building were let out single-file: https://twitter.com/HeathaT/status/517845918180065280 The blockade clearly angered some of the workers. “Why do you have the right to protest and I don’t have the right to go to work?” one grey-haired woman, who said she was a cleaner, screamed at the protesters.
{{unknown}}

Workers file out of Hong Kong govt HQ past protesters pic.twitter.com/S7eczXCCl8

— Heather Timmons (@HeathaT) October 3, 2014

item.title: Anti-occupiers are tearing down tents and starting fights in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: People opposed to the pro-democracy protests that have paralyzed Hong Kong for nearly a week have taken matters into their own hands—starting a series of chaotic scuffles with protesters and dismantling the pro-democracy demonstrators' makeshift shelters.

item.title: China is driving a global clean-energy rebound.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/275577/china-is-driving-a-global-renewable-energy-rebound-but-it-might-not-last/

item.title: The US sees sturdy job growth.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: The US economy added 248,000 jobs in September, and the unemployment rate fell to 5.9%, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Here are two simple charts breaking down how the country's employment and job creation look.

item.title: Long lost Sherlock Holmes silent film discovered in French vault.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The catchphrase "elementary" wasn't the creation of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, it came from US actor William Gillette. Movies starring Gillette were thought to have been lost forever, but staff at the Cinémathèque Française has found a 1916 silent film showing what's said to be a quintessential portrayal of Holmes.

item.title: Sweden will recognize the Palestinian state.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Nordic country has become the first major European nation to announce plans to do so. The United Nations recognized Palestine back in 2012 as an observer, but the rest of the world has been slow to react for numerous reasons. Now, more than 130 countries recognize Palestine—around 70% of the UN.

item.title: The US is now screening 50 people for Ebola.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The US Center for Disease Control's director Tom Frieden is "confident that we can contain any spread of Ebola," but says it isn't going to be easy. US officials originally said some 100 people are being evaluated for potential exposure to the virus, but that number has now been halved to just 50—of those, 10 are at "high risk" for developing the disease.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: On the other side of the pond, Germany began treating its second Ebola patient, an unnamed male Ugandan doctor who was seeing Ebola patients in Sierra Leone.

item.title: Europe finally approves Facebook's WhatsApp acquisition.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: With much fanfare in February of this year, Mark Zuckerberg announced that he wanted to buy the popular chat application WhatsApp for $19 billion. US regulators granted his wish just two months later, and with that the wait for the European green light began. It's now over.

item.title: The Islamic State is attacked by a suicide bomber.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A female Kurdish fighter reportedly carried out the attack outside of Kobani, the embattled Syrian town near the Turkey border that is close to being overrun by the extremist IS, which itself often uses suicide bombers. About 160,000 residents of the area have fled across the border to Turkey.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The UK is also beefing up its forces, with prime minister David Cameron announcing that two additional Royal Air Force (RAF) jets will soon join the six already deployed in Cyprus. Four missions have been executed thus far, with eight targets successfully destroyed in five locations. A video showing British citizen Alan Henning being beheaded was released by ISIL, to which David Cameron responded: "We will do all we can to hunt down these murderers and bring them to justice." Canada is said to be the latest member to join ISIL strikes—at request of the US—though it's just a rumor at this point. Parliament hasn't voted on the matter yet.

item.title: New iPads are allegedly less than two weeks away.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Re/code's John Paczkowski is reporting that Apple will hold an event on Oct. 16 to unveil "updates to its iPad line" along with new iMac desktop computers and a new version of its Mac OS X operating system. Apple has not confirmed the report. Earlier this week, Bloomberg said a new gold-colored iPad is in the works.

item.title: The "mancession" is over.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/275676/all-the-key-charts-from-todays-robust-us-jobs-report/

item.title: A new Bond novel turns the British spy into boy racer.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Ian Fleming estate has granted a 59-year-old novelist, Anthony Horowitz, the rights to dream up a new chapter in the life of one of popular fiction's most famous action heroes—James Bond. Currently known as "Project One," the book will place the debonair Brit in the world of motorsport in the 1950s. Look for it on shelves in September of 2015.

item.title: Russian doctors should crack a smile once in a while.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The last person you want to look bored or grumpy is your doctor. But that appears to be a common complaint in Russia, which is why Veronika Skvortsova, Russia's minister of health, has decreed the following: "The smile of a medical professional is the formula for success in curing the patient."

item.title: Yahoo is spending that Alibaba money on chat apps.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Two separate reports on Friday suggest that Yahoo is investing some of the money it made off the Alibaba IPO into messaging apps. The first, from TechCrunch, has Yahoo allegedly spending "single-digit millions" on MessageMe. The second, from the Wall Street Journal, says Yahoo has purchased a stake of an unknown size in Snapchat, at a $10-billion valuation.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
After Snapchat turned down a $3-billion cash acquisition offer from Facebook last year—and with the company doing just fine on its own—some observers are saying they'll believe that a Yahoo deal is in the works only when the ink is dry.

https://twitter.com/danprimack/status/518110711655190528

FWIW: With Snapchat in particular, no investment is really done until it's done.

— danprimack (@danprimack) October 3, 2014

item.title: The last guy as good as Obama at cutting unemployment? Reagan.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/275878/obama-is-just-as-good-as-reagan-at-cutting-unemployment/

item.title: Brazil is one step closer to its next president.
item.dc:creator: zachseward
item.content:encoded: Incumbent Dilma Rousseff won the most votes in Sunday’s first-round election, and pro-business candidate Aécio Neves surged ahead Marina Silva to finish second. A runoff between Rousseff and Neves will take place on October 26.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: https://twitter.com/ShastaCNN/status/518402260439945216 And no selfies either—taking photos in a voting booth is illegal in Brazil.

No hanging chads here. In #Brazil elections electronic voting machines mean results within hours of polls closing pic.twitter.com/Q6hHleTvnz

— Shasta Darlington (@ShastaCNN) October 4, 2014

item.title: Hong Kong faces an ultimatum.
item.dc:creator: zachseward
item.content:encoded: The city's chief executive gave protestors until the morning of Monday, Oct. 6, to clear the streets, or he will "take all necessary actions to restore social order." This evening, tens of thousands of people have gathered at the protest's epicenter for another rally. Follow the hashtag #OccupyCentral.

item.title: "Baby Doc" is dead.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The former dictator of Haiti, Jean-Claude Duvalier, has died of a heart attack at the age of 63. He was only 19 when, in 1971, he inherited the title of "president for life" from his father. The younger Duvalier's cruel reign was finally ended by an uprising in 1986.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In a series of tweets, the country's current president, Michel Martelly, was surprisingly cordial: "Despite our squabbles and our differences, we salute the departure of a true son of Haiti," he wrote in French. "Love and reconciliation must always overcome our quarrels. May your soul rest in peace."

item.title: Time is an illusion down under.
item.dc:creator: zachseward
item.content:encoded: The beginning of daylight saving time in some—but not all—parts of the country means there are five Australian time zones for summer, instead of the usual three. Sydney is now "half an hour ahead of Adelaide, one hour ahead of Brisbane, one and a half hours ahead of Darwin, and three hours ahead of Perth." Got it?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_276223" align="alignleft" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: HP is splitting in two.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The company plans to separate its PC and printer business from its hardware and services operations next year. The split—increasingly common in a tech industry being reshaped by new competitive threats—could unleash another round of deal-making, including the combination of the HP hardware business with data storage giant EMC.

item.title: Hong Kong protests limp into their second week.
item.dc:creator: htimmonsqz
item.content:encoded: The Hong Kong government let a dwindling number of protesters remain in place on Monday morning, after a small path was cleared to allow government workers to return to work. Hong Kong government officials and student protest leaders met for the first time on Sunday night, but the talks have not yielded any concrete results.

item.title: Samsung bets on smartphones—just not its own.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The South Korean tech giant, facing sharp declines in profits from its smartphone division, is investing 15.6 trillion won ($15 billion) in a new semiconductor factory to build chips for mobile devices. Samsung's own devices are getting squeezed by Apple and low-margin Chinese competitors—but much of the industry uses Samsung's chips.

item.title: Snapchat and Square close in on new funding.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Yahoo is preparing to invest around $20 million (paywall) into Snapchat, according to the Wall Street Journal, in a deal that would value the messaging app at $10 billion. And Square, an electronic payments start-up that is facing new competition from Apple and a standalone PayPal, secured $150 million in new venture capital funding that values the company at $6 billion.

item.title: The US is mulling greater airport screening for Ebola.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Centers for Disease Control is studying whether enhanced screening would justify the disruption of air travel. Meanwhile, Thomas Duncan, the first person to be diagnosed with Ebola in the US, is "fighting for his life" due to a shortage of the few experimental drugs for the disease.

item.title: Joe Biden sticks both feet in his mouth.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The US vice president called the crown prince of Abu Dhabi to take back remarks that the United Arab Emirates had funded Al Qaeda fighters in Syria. On Saturday, Biden apologized to Recep Tayyip Erdogan for claiming Turkey's president had admitted to allowing potential ISIL recruits to cross into Syria.

item.title: The World Bank sees China slowing.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Estimates for the country's growth were lowered to 7.4% for this year, 7.2% for 2015, and 7.1% for 2016. The previous estimates were 7.6% for 2014 and 7.5% for both 2015 and 2016. Cement production is proving to be a reliable tracker for China's economic growth—certainly better than the housing market.

item.title: A Norwegian couple win the Nobel for medicine.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: May-Britt and Edvard Moser, who won for their work on the the brain's "inner GPS," become only the fifth married couple ever to win Nobels. They will share the $1.1 million prize with British-American John O’Keefe.

item.title: FCC takes a pause to think about Comcast-Time Warner Cable mega-merger.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The $45 billion marriage was meant to be open for public comment and debate until Oct. 8, but that portion of the review has now been pushed back to Oct. 29; the agency expects its review of the deal to be done by Jan. 2016. If it goes through, some fear the combined entity would possess a vast regional hegemony.

item.title: Facebook's WhatsApp acquisition is now complete.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Originally announced in February, it was to be a $19 billion transaction. Due to Facebook's recent stock performance—investors are always keen on increased ad revenue—the deal, finally cleared by European Union regulators, is now worth $21.8 billion.

item.title: The first child born from a transplanted womb is named Vincent.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The mother is an unnamed 36-year-old Swedish woman, one of nine who receive a womb transplant win January. She had been unable to conceive because of a condition known as Müllerian agenesis. The womb donor is the baby's godmother.

item.title: Politicians aren't fans of the Ukrainian trash bucket challenge.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Apparently inspired by the ALS Ice Bucket Challenge Ukrainian activists are literally throwing politicians into dumpsters—often making them sit in filth for as long as 30 minutes—in order to protest against corruption. As with any internet sensation, there's a hashtag you can follow.

item.title: John Galliano, fashion's controversial showman, is making a comeback.
item.dc:creator: javinsqz

item.title: Ebola infected someone outside of Africa for the first time.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A female nurse in Madrid tested positive for the disease, after working in a hospital there that was treating an Ebola victim. All the previous victims, including Thomas Eric Duncan, have contracted the disease in Africa.

item.title: Here's the real reason digital currency advocates should be worried about bitcoin.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/276841/falling-prices-arent-the-real-reason-to-worry-about-bitcoin/

item.title: Mark Zuckerberg was forced to install WhatsApp to buy Oculus.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Brendan Iribe, CEO of the virtual reality headset company Oculus, doesn't have Facebook—nor Facebook Messenger—on his phone. And since Iribe is based in Irvine, Calif., and not Silicon Valley, Bloomberg says Zuckerberg, after offering $19 billion for WhatsApp, finally resorted to installing the app on his phone to communicate with Iribe about the deal.

item.title: Samsung's profits are dropping like a stone.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The South Korean tech giant said its third-quarter operating profits would fall by 60%—even worse than most analysts expected—due to intense competition in the smartphone market, which is eating away at the company's market share and forcing heavy discounting and marketing expenditures. Samsung expects quarterly operating profits of 4.1 trillion won ($3.8 billion)—less than half of what analysts expected as of January.

item.title: Glencore tried to merge with Rio Tinto.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Anglo-Swiss firm approached Rio Tinto this summer with a merger proposal that would have created the world's largest mining company, but was turned down in August. Glencore is now gauging Aluminium Corporation of China's interest in a deal; the state-owned company controls 9.8% of Rio Tinto.

item.title: Prince should have used a fact-checker.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Doves, though they have tear ducts and can produce "mournful-sounding calls," cannot cry.

item.title: Vladimir Putin got a Hercules-themed art show for his birthday.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The paintings show the Russian president battling a seven-headed sanctions hydra, grappling with a terrorist, and more.

item.title: Hong Kong protesters agree to negotiations.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The pro-democracy Federation of Students and government representatives said "substantive" talks would go ahead this week. The student group warned that protests would continue in three key areas of the city unless progress was made, though their numbers have been dwindling in recent days.

item.title: Three scientists win a Nobel for making the world a little brighter.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Isamu Akasaki, Hiroshi Amano, and Shuji Nakamura won the Nobel Prize for physics for their discovery of how to produce blue light from semi-conductors, which allowed for the creation of white-light LEDs. Nakamura was awarded just $200 for his invention at the time—until he sued.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Nobel prizewinner Nakamura sued his former employer after getting just $200 for his invention. He's now a US citizen http://t.co/YiDe71mH15

— Hiroko Tabuchi (@HirokoTabuchi) October 7, 2014

item.title: Brussels is going after Amazon.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The European Commission is launching a formal investigation into the tax relationship between the online retailer and Luxembourg. Brussels alleges Luxembourg improperly offered Amazon preferential tax rates for a decade. The EU is also investigating Apple in Ireland—where it pays 2% in tax.

item.title: Recession fears are haunting Germany.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: After the biggest monthly drop in industrial output in over five years, some economists are admitting the possibility of a recession for the euro zone's biggest economy, though some are still dismissing it (paywall). That would be bad news for the euro zone's overall recovery.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
How did Europe's powerhouse get into this parlous state? The FT's Stefan Wagstyl has a good overview (paywall):
The slowdown in Germany is not just about Ukraine. The concerns of German executives also take in emerging markets’ weakness in countries such as Brazil, plus the growing competitive threats from China and an industrially-resurgent US. At home they worry about high energy costs, skilled labour shortages, crumbling infrastructure and bureaucratic hurdles. Business also dislikes Chancellor Angela Merkel’s recent economic policy, especially the mandatory minimum wage and a costly increase in early retirements.

item.title: The EU is sniffing around Amazon's taxes.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The European Commission is investigating suspicions that the easy tax terms the e-retailer has enjoyed for 11 years in Luxembourg could break EU antitrust rules. Apple is facing a similar type of investigation for its agreements with the Irish government, and even Starbucks is being held accountable for its Dutch deals.

item.title: Somalia gets its first ATM.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Cash dispensers are taken for granted almost everywhere in the world, yet Somalia had never seen one—until today. Visa, MasterCard, and American Express are accepted, though you can only withdraw US dollars, seeing as how the local shilling is pretty much worthless (paywall).

item.title: US job openings hit a 13-year high in August.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: According to a report published by the US labor department on Tuesday, there were 4.84 million open jobs to fill in the US in August, up from 4.61 million the previous month. The good news is economists were only expecting 4.7 million job openings. The bad news: Hiring in August dropped to 4.6 million from 4.9 million in July.

item.title: The US and Turkey are squabbling while Kobani hangs in the balance.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: As ISIL forces continued to push into the Kurdish Syrian town of Kobani, US officials are frustrated that Turkey's military isn't playing a bigger role. Turkish president Recep Tayyip Erdogan acknowledged that the town was about to fall, but said Turkey would not get more deeply involved unless the US agreed to give more aid to Syrian rebels.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Turkey's president says more than 200,000 refugees have fled the fighting and that ground forces—an unknown number of troops and tanks—are standing by should the battle spill over into its territory. But as Benny Avni writes in Newsweek, there are reasons to doubt Turkey's motives for joining the battle against the Islamic State.

[T]he Kurds, who live in the areas ISIS contests, suspect that beyond fighting ISIS—who are, like the Turks, Sunni Islamists—Erdogan's hidden aim is to stem the growing importance of Kurdish fighters and politicians in the coalition... Close scrutiny of last week's legislation shows that Turkey's reason for joining the war may be as much to suppress Kurdish separatists as to destroy ISIS.

item.title: Wal-Mart scraps health benefits for part-timers.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Starting in Jan. 2015, the last remaining Wal-Mart employees getting health insurance while working less than 30 hours a week—which totals about 30,000 people—will lose their coverage. The company says it expects healthcare-related costs to swell to $500 million this fiscal year, from a previous estimate of $330 million.

item.title: Yum Brands takes a food safety hit.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The owner of KFC, Pizza Hut, and Taco Bell said earnings per share would only grow 10% this year, compared to a growth projection of at least 20% previously. Sales in China, where it is the largest foreign restaurant chain operator, fell 14% in its third quarter after a food safety scandal hit one of its suppliers.

item.title: Samsung's smartphone business is disintegrating
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/276918/samsungs-phone-business-seems-to-be-falling-apart/

item.title: Face-touching is likely to blame for Spanish Ebola.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Spanish health officials say it's possible that the nurse infected with Ebola accidentally touched her face with an infected rubber glove. Meanwhile, the nurse’s husband is trying to save their dog from being euthanized by the Spanish government to prevent contagion, sparking an outpouring of support on social media.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
The World Bank published a report on Wednesday that says Ebola could cost West Africa's economy $33 billion in damages.
It is far from certain that the epidemic will be fully contained by December. Over the medium term... both epidemiological and economic contagion in the broader subregion of West Africa is likely.

item.title: The bidding war for Allergan gets complicated.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The manufacturer of Botox has turned down repeated takeover offers from Valeant Pharmaceuticals and hedge fund manager Bill Ackman, but might be willing to consider a bid of at least $200 per share from Activis, sources told Reuters. Valeant and Ackman are considering raising their offer for Allergan by $4.5 billion (paywall), to $191 per share.

item.title: Amazon goes before the US Supreme Court for its worker stop-and-frisks.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Its workers are forced to stand in line for up to 25 minutes to be searched for stolen goods, and are suing the company for not paying them for their time. The Obama administration—which has plenty of federal employees who go through similar checks (paywall)—has sided with Amazon.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Amazon has a surprising ally in its legal battle against its hourly workers: The Obama administration, which filed an amicus brief defending Amazon's policies. That is most likely because the federal government requires many of its employees to go through security screenings (paywall), and does not want to pay them for the time it takes.

item.title: Which Ivy League students are defaulting on their loans?
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/276801/here-are-the-us-colleges-whose-students-have-the-toughest-time-paying-back-loans/

item.title: Breaking up ain't hard to do.
item.dc:creator: lmiraniqz
item.content:encoded: Symantec is considering splitting itself into two companies—one that sells security software and one that sells computer storage, according Bloomberg. Symantec follows in the footsteps of recent splitter-uppers HP and Ebay/Paypal.

item.title: Hong Kong's chief executive was accused of corruption.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: CY Leung received a secret £4 million ($6.4 million) payout from an Australian engineering company while serving as Hong Kong's top government official, according to the Sydney Morning Herald. Leung, who is already facing calls to resign from pro-democracy protesters, claims the payments were not made in exchange for any future services.

item.title: China's economy is bigger than America's—kind of.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: As widely predicted: The International Monetary Fund estimates that the size of the US economy was $17.4 trillion in 2014—just short of China’s economy, at $17.6 trillion. Based on purchasing power—which is debatable as a worthwhile metric—China's economy was less than half the size of the US economy in 2005; by 2019, the IMF expects it to be 20% bigger.

item.title: IKEA is now selling insurance with a side of meatballs.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Last week, the Swedish furniture–and more recently home electronics—company started offering child and pregnancy insurance (paywall) in its native Sweden under the "Omifall" brand. The goal is to eventually be able to offer insurance to the 59 million IKEA shoppers that also carry a loyalty membership card.

item.title: UPS wants you to pick up your own packages.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: UPS is hopping on the bandwagon already used by delivery giants like Amazon and Google: it's offering lockers customers can visit at their convenience to collect packages. For now, UPS's lockers will only be available in Chicago and New York.

item.title: Chemistry's Nobel Prize went to better microscope inventors.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Shining artificial light on the world's smallest particles and using the best optics available to see them has one problem: the wavelength of light is bigger than the particles, which dulls the view. Two Americans and one German solved that by inventing a microscope that uses molecules which are naturally fluorescent.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
http://youtu.be/UCJ6oQSdxN0
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L4bel_-cddY

item.title: 21 Kurds have died protesting Turkey's inaction against ISIL.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Kurdish minorities in cities across Turkey are furious that their government is refusing to participate in the fighting currently taking place in the Syrian town of Kobani, just across the Turkish border. Turkey's president has troops and tanks ready, but he has refused to use them. Fresh US-led airstrikes are helping the Kurds fight ISIL, but not enough to prevent the town's capture.

item.title: US airports now screening for Ebola.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Despite the World Health Organization discouraging airport screenings related to Ebola, the US has decided to do just that. People arriving onto US soil from Liberia, Sierra Leone, and Guinea will have their temperature checked. You can be carrying Ebola and be asymptomatic, but don't tell that to your friendly TSA officer.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The TSA says the new measures will be put in place as early as this weekend.

item.title: Mexican workers might want to consider some needed R&R.
item.dc:creator: qzroya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/277965/the-worlds-second-richest-man-thinks-we-should-all-be-working-less/

item.title: Chinese government finds 150,000 ghosts on its payroll.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Amid a government clampdown on corruption and frivolous spending, the official People's Daily reports that the Chinese government has removed tens of thousands of people from state payrolls who were still being paid after leaving their posts. China says profligate spending on fancy cars and expensive dinners, discouraged by president Xi Jinping, has dropped by nearly $9 billion in the past year.

item.title: Apple is unveiling more toys next week.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The company that brought you the iPhone and the iPod has scheduled its second product unveiling this fall for Oct. 16. It's widely expected that a new iPad will be presented—possibly in a golden hue—along with new Mac computers.

item.title: Stock markets jump for joy.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Asian and European stocks rallied and the Dow Jones Industrial Index had its best day of 2014 after the US Federal Reserve signaled it would keep rates low a while longer. The IMF, on the other hand, didn't like that idea.

item.title: Australia-Timezones-Daylight
item.dc:creator: zachseward

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: a:5:{s:5:"width";i:650;s:6:"height";i:550;s:4:"file";s:105:"/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/558/39587363/files/2014/10/australia-timezones-daylight2.png";s:5:"sizes";a:0:{}s:10:"image_meta";a:11:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:0;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:11:"orientation";i:0;}}
/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/558/39587363/files/2014/10/australia-timezones-daylight2.png

item.title: Ebola may become a worldwide pandemic.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Tom Frieden, the director of the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, compared the disease's spread to AIDS on Wednesday. The US will begin screening people at major airports as early as this weekend, testing the temperature of people arriving from Liberia, Sierra Leone, and Guinea—though some Ebola carriers are asymptomatic.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The UK will also screen people traveling via Gatwick, Heathrow, and on Eurostar from countries with widespread infection. Thomas Duncan, a Liberian man who was diagnosed with the virus after flying to the US, has died in Dallas despite being treated with an experimental drug, bringing the Ebola death toll to 3,879. The World Health Organization's death toll does not include Excalibur, a 12-year-old dog belonging to the Spanish nurse who contracted Ebola in Madrid. He was euthanized by Spanish authorities on Wednesday as a precaution to prevent any further transmission of the disease, despite a worldwide campaign to save him. Around 200 employees tasked with cleaning airplane cabins at New York's La Guardia Airport are on strike because they fear they might catch the Ebola virus.

item.title: Gap's CEO is stepping down.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Glenn Murphy was tasked with improving the company's image and supply chain back in 2007, but his impact has been about as exciting as the design of Gap clothes (paywall). He's handing the overalls to Art Peck, Gap's head of digital. Investors don't seem that pleased; the stock is down eight points.

item.title: You aren't America’s favorite store when your finances look like this.
item.dc:creator: qzroya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/278260/the-perilous-position-of-what-once-was-americas-favorite-store/

item.title: Google's newest autonomous vehicle is a camel.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Google Maps Street Views now include 360° shots of the Liwa Oasis in the Arabian desert, thanks to a dromedary named Raffia.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4pVCToDTbT4

item.title: PC sales may have bottomed out.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Lower prices on laptops and a market saturated with tablets and smartphones have eased the rate at which PC demand is falling globally, and have even led to sales growth in the US, according to market research firms Gartner and IDC. Gartner said third-quarter shipments to the US grew 4.2% (paywall) versus the previous year, and IDC said they rose 4.3%.

item.title: Brazilian politics make strange bedfellows.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The Brazilian Socialist Party, which failed to secure a place in the runoff elections later this month, threw its weight behind pro-business challenger Aecio Neves in his attempt to unseat incumbent president Dilma Rousseff.

item.title: Another controversial police shooting in Missouri.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Protesters gathered in St. Louis, about 30 miles from the town of Ferguson, after a white off-duty white police officer shot and killed a young black man on Wednesday night. A police spokesperson claimed the officer was returning fire after being shot at by the 18-year-old; relatives of Vonderrit Myers insisted he was unarmed.

item.title: More bad news for the German economy.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Exports plunged by 5.8% in August from the month before—the biggest drop since 2009; earlier this week factory orders and industrial production also fell sharply. The figures will put pressure on chancellor Angela Merkel to focus more on promoting economic growth instead of emphasizing fiscal austerity.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_278601" align="alignnone" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: Lego ditches its less-than-awesome Shell deal.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The world's biggest toy company said it will not renew an agreement to sell toys in Shell gas stations after coming under pressure from a Greenpeace viral marketing campaign—but not before criticizing Greenpeace for creating "misunderstandings" about the way the company operates.

item.title: Talks between Hong Kong student protesters and the government are nixed.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: Chief Secretary Carrie Lam said it was “impossible to have a constructive meeting” with leaders of the waning protest. Hours earlier, student leaders had tried to reinvigorate the occupation and announced a new wave of civil disobedience. The announcement that tomorrow's sit-down is cancelled may end up intensifying the unrest.

item.title: Carl Icahn is gently suggesting that Tim Cook buy back even more Apple stock.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In the activist investor's open letter to the CEO of the company that makes the iPhone, he says Apple's current share price is half where it should be. In April, Apple authorized $90 billion of share buybacks (paywall), up from $60 billion a year ago. Icahn—who owns $5.3 billion in Apple stock—wants that number to go higher. Fast.

item.title: US jobless claims hit an eight-year low.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits is down for the week ending Oct. 4 by 1,000, to 287,000. This is the fourth week in a row that number has been under 300,000—something not seen since 2006. Data released last week by the US Labor Department has the unemployment rate pegged at 5.9%.

item.title: Ben Bernanke likes to role-play.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: During testimony given by the former US Federal Reserve chairman on Thursday about the 2008 AIG bailout, it was revealed that he used the name "Edward Quince" when emailing colleagues at the height of the financial crisis. No reason was give as to why this was done, nor what significance—if any—that particular name had.

item.title: France continues to dominate the world, at least by this measure.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/278683/with-modianos-nobel-prize-the-french-continue-to-dominate-the-literary-world/

item.title: One plan to save the world: Pee in the shower.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Students Debs Torr and Chris Dobson want to convince the 15,000 students at the University of East Anglia to urinate in the shower in the morning instead of using and flushing the toilet. Doing so would conserve enough water to "fill an Olympic-sized swimming pool 26 times over," says Dobson.

item.title: You'll soon be able to window-shop at Amazon.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Wall Street Journal reports that the e-commerce giant's first brick-and-mortar store will open in time for holiday season this year on 34th Street in Manhattan, across from the Empire State Building. It will resemble a warehouse, reportedly, with a small inventory for same-day delivery in New York, product returns, and pickups.

item.title: Tesla's "D" is a semi-autonomous all-wheel-drive car.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Master showman Elon Musk unveiled a faster version of the Tesla Model S sedan, powered by two separate electric motors. The company also introduced "a suite of driver aid features" that uses sensors to read and adjust to speed limit signs, and can change lanes with the flick of a turn signal.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The carefully managed hype build-up for the Tesla "D" models was spoiled slightly when USA Today blew the press embargo on the news. The paper quickly pulled its story offline, but it was preserved by the all-seeing eye of Google's web cache.

item.title: China is looking for a Siberian tiger that defected from Russia.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: "Kuzia" crossed across the border from Russia in search of food, several months after president Vladimir Putin released him into the wild. Chinese officials said they would try to protect the animal and possibly even release cattle for it to feed on—though as Reuters noted, "China's insatiable demand for tiger products" for use in traditional medicine has driven the animals to the brink of extinction.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Here's Putin releasing Kuzia and two other tigers into the wild in May:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GkSpJGp1DbA

item.title: Microsoft’s chief executive puts his foot in his mouth.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Speaking at a conference on women in technology, Satya Nadella said underpaid women shouldn’t ask for raises and instead depend on “good karma.” He later apologized for his remark, calling it “completely wrong"—not to mention the fact that the Indian-born CEO seems to have adopted a distinctly Americanized concept of "karma."

item.title: Barack Obama is trying to close Gitmo again.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The US president is preparing to override a congressional ban on bringing prisoners to the United States from the detention facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, according to the Wall Street Journal (paywall). Obama tried and failed to close the facility during his first term.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Last week US federal judge Gladys Kessler ordered three hours of footage showing a Guantanamo Bay inmate being force-fed to be released to the public. The inmate was on a hunger strike for better conditions at the prison, and his testimony was the first to be heard by a federal judge.

item.title: The Noble Peace Prize just got timely.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The $1.1 million joint award to Malala Yousafzai—the young Pakistani activist who was shot by the Taliban for attempting to attend school—and Indian child rights advocate Kailash Satyarthi comes as India and Pakistan are engaged yet again in deadly violence over the disputed territory of Kashmir. Twenty-three civilians have been killed in shelling by both sides, the highest number in more than a decade.

item.title: Kim Jong-un was a no-show.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The North Korean ruler skipped the anniversary of the country’s ruling party, fueling speculation about his health. A source told Reuters that Kim was “in firm control of his government but hurt his leg taking part in a military drill.”

item.title: Roughly 100 evil geniuses exist.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: That's what the head of Europol's Cybercrime unit says. All those computer hacks we hear—and don't hear—about are being perpetrated by a "rather limited group of good programmers," mainly in Russia. And the "internet of things" that everyone's talking about these days "widens the attack surface a bit."

item.title: Microsoft's CEO tries removing foot from mouth.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: After saying that women shouldn't ask for raises—they should just rely on "karma" rewarding them in the end—Satya Nadella apologized, both on Twitter and via email, saying he was "completely wrong" to make the statement. The initial remarks came at a conference on women in the workplace.

item.title: OPEC oil production hits a new high—despite the glut.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Oil prices haven't been this low—less than $90 a barrel—since 2010, yet that doesn't seem to be stopping OPEC countries from pumping it out of the ground. Production reached 30.47 million barrels a day in September—higher than in the summer of 2013—with a slowdown not expected until late next month.

item.title: Jamie Dimon reappears after his battle with cancer.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The last time JP Morgan Chase's chief was heard from in public, it was on a conference call back in July, shortly after he was diagnosed with throat cancer. The Wall Street Journal now reports that Dimon finished his treatments last month, and will be giving a talk at the Institute of International Finance (paywall) on Friday.

item.title: Russia inserts itself between Moldova and the European Union.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: One of Europe's poorest countries, Moldova wants to enter into a trade deal with the euro zone, but during a summit in Belarus, Russian president Vladimir Putin argued that such an agreement shouldn't be made without his approval. Russia pulled the same move with Ukraine last month, delaying its European pact until 2016.

item.title: Spain now has an Ebola crisis committee.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Last week, a nursing assistant in Spain became the first person to catch the Ebola virus outside of Africa. Since then, 14 people she'd been in contact with have been quarantined. Now Spain's prime minister has established a panel of scientific advisors to deal with the "complex and difficult" situation.

item.title: The Ebola death toll crosses 4,000.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: There's a $600 million hole in the UN's budget to battle the virus, and unfortunately, not every country is as adept as Nigeria in dealing with the disease on such constraints. As alarming as the 4,033 deaths so far is the almost 8,400 confirmed cases. Africa's poor infrastructure is only hampering containment and treatment efforts.

item.title: Is the chip industry headed for a downturn?
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Semiconductor stocks fell on Friday (paywall)—part of a generally bloody week in the markets—after Microchip Technology issued an earnings warning. Though it's no giant, the Arizona-based chipmaker is seen as an industry bellwether. Still, the problems may not be generalized; all eyes will be on Intel earnings on Tuesday, which are expected to be healthy.

item.title: Russian sanctions go galactic.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Some of the food sent to astronauts on the International Space Station has been hit by Russia's retaliatory sanctions against Europe. Contraband candy and dried fruit from family members can be sent via foreign supply vehicles but is banned from traveling on the Russian Soyuz, the only manned spacecraft that goes to the station.

item.title: Let's play "Global Financial Crisis."
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The US and UK will on Monday hold the first transatlantic "war game" simulating a meltdown (paywall) at a large American or British bank, reports the FT. Senior officials and representatives from big banks will gather to plot out who would have to talk to whom.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://youtu.be/KXzNo0vR_dU?t=1m22s

item.title: There is definitely a second NSA leaker.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: Citizenfour, a new documentary about Edward Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who spilled a vast trove of US secrets, confirms what American officials have thought for months: Another source, more senior than Snowden was and possibly inspired by him, has been providing material to the journalists Snowden worked with.

item.title: There's another queue at Heathrow—for Ebola screenings.
item.dc:creator: gguilfordqz
item.content:encoded: The UK’s health secretary announced that Ebola screenings are set to begin in one of the world's busiest airports, despite the health ministry initially dismissing them as "a pointless endeavor," and health secretary Jeremy Hunt warned that people shouldn’t be surprised if a “handful” of Ebola cases are found. Five US airports will also start screening this week—if you refuse, you could face a three-week quarantine.

item.title: 400,000 evacuated in Eastern India as cyclone hits.
item.dc:creator: gguilfordqz
item.content:encoded: Parts of the states of Odisha and Andhra Pradesh were cleared of people as Cyclone Hudhud tore through the area, and at least eight people have been killed. In general, fewer people are dying (paywall) from such events as Indian officials are better prepared with each passing year.

item.title: A St. Louis protest ends in arrests.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Police in riot gear arrested at least 17 people who had gathered for a spontaneous sit-in at a convenience store to protest the killing of a black teenager last week by a white police officer. Rallies also took place in nearby Ferguson to criticize police accountability after the killing of another black teenager there in August.

item.title: Turkey opens its military bases.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: American forces will be able to use Turkish military sites to train moderate Syrian opposition forces and “engage in activities” in Iraq and Syria, after facing weeks of criticism for not doing more to combat Islamic State fighters, some of whom are on the brink of capturing a Syrian town on the Turkish border.

item.title: The reading level of US presidential speeches is falling.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Either presidents are trying to appeal to a broader voter base, or they’re getting dumber.

item.title: Software can detect your emotional state as you type.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: That means we’re another step closer to achieving emotional AI.

item.title: Pandora Media’s growing pains are starting to hurt.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/279574/pandora-medias-growing-pains-are-starting-to-hurt/

item.title: A French economist wins the Nobel for "taming powerful firms."
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Jean Tirole, a 61-year-old economist from the Toulouse School of Economics, has won the Nobel Prize in economics. His work on "how to understand and regulate industries with a few powerful firms" is topical, given worries about how internet giants like Amazon and Google might abuse their market power to stifle competition and innovation.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences published a summary of Tirole's work for the general public (pdf) as well as experts in the field (pdf). The Guardian has a good summary of the economics prize, which was first awarded in 1969.

item.title: Bill Ackman’s fund lists with a whimper.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The activist investor known for big bets on Herbalife, Allergan, and other companies saw shares of his fund, Pershing Square, fall by as much as 10.8% on their first day of trading in Amsterdam. The outspoken hedge fund manager said proceeds from the IPO—around $3 billion—will help him take aim at other firms.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: "The stock is down, which is good," Ackman told reporters. "If it went up we'd have sold it too low."

item.title: Au revoir to the UK's stake in Eurostar.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The British government is putting its 40% holding in the high-speed rail service linking London and the continent, up for sale. No matter who buys the stake—which is valued at around £300 million ($482 million)—the service will still be run by the majority owner, state-run French railway SNCF.

item.title: The Russian ruble won't stop falling.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The currency is setting yet more record lows against the dollar today, despite the central bank spending $6 billion of its reserves to stem the slide in recent days. Central bank chief Elvira Nabiullina revealed the figure during a speech to lawmakers, amid signs that locals are starting to hoard dollars, euros, and other firmer currencies.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: [caption id="attachment_280215" align="alignnone" width="640"] [/caption]

item.title: Gaza's reconstruction efforts get a $5.4 billion boost.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: More than 50 countries have pooled together the resources that the Palestinian Authority needs to rebuild Gaza after its 50-day bombing by Israel earlier this summer. Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas had only asked for $4 billion.

item.title: North Korea wants the US to collect its dead soldiers.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Over 8,000 American soldiers went missing during the 1950s Korean War. Excavation to find their remains was halted in 2005, when the US pulled out, citing a lack of security. Now Pyongyang is asking the US to return and collect the remains of an estimated 5,300 troops.

item.title: Somalia now has a bank that can move money internationally.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The SWIFT banking system that financial intuitions use to wire funds to one another has a new member today—the International Bank of Somalia is the first bank in the country to offer access to international markets. Just last week, Somalia also got its first ATM.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In further good news on the Somali front, the country now has a postal service and—for the first time in its history—zip codes.

item.title: Oil prices continue to slide on strong supply and weak demand
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Global oil prices have now fallen below $90 a barrel and could fall further, but oil analysts are split as to how long the decline will last.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/278945/oil-prices-have-plunged-through-another-psychological-barrier/

item.title: ...pushing gasoline prices below $3 a gallon in some US states.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: American drivers are paying on average $3.26 a gallon ($0.86 per liter), with some states charging less than $3. That's down 46 cents from its peak in May, and down 13 cents year over year. The last time gas was this cheap in America was Nov. last year.

item.title: 113-year old forced to fib about her age to join Facebook.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The social network won't let you input a birth year before 1905, so Anna Stoehr had to tell a white lie in order to open an account. But young people are much more likely to lie about their age to get on Facebook.

item.title: The Pentagon has a plan to deal with climate change.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: US defense secretary Chuck Hagel detailed the 20-page report (pdf) at a conference in Peru, saying: "Climate change is a global problem. Its impacts do not respect national borders. No nation can deal with it alone." Solutions were light, but areas that need to be monitored—such as bases in Virginia at risk of flooding—were highlighted.

item.title: Robot snakes are coming—thanks, Carnegie Mellon.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Researchers analyzing the movement patterns of sidewinder rattlesnakes have created a robotic serpent that can "climb on inclinations of up to 20 degrees." Next challenge: auditioning for 'Snakes on a Plane II.'

item.title: Kim Jong-un is back.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The North Korean leader reappeared on state-owned media after a six-week absence, touring a new residential housing complex while walking with a cane (and with a still impressive head of hair). As the Associated Press' Foster Klug noted, the media circus around his absence shows even when Kim was nowhere, he was everywhere.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
https://twitter.com/cctvnews/status/521817682400645121/photo/1
https://twitter.com/nknewsorg/status/521915727952232448

More shots emerge: Kim Jong Un swimming via @KCNAWatch pic.twitter.com/Zk92SkMCe0

— NK NEWS (@nknewsorg) October 14, 2014

item.title: The US rethinks Ebola.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The infection of a nurse in Dallas who treated an Ebola patient is forcing health authorities to weigh new safety protocols, including possibly relocating patients to one of the four US hospitals that has a secure biocontainment unit.

item.title: Iliad lost interest in T-Mobile US.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The low-cost French telecom company became the third suitor to drop plans to acquire the US mobile carrier. Deutsche Telekom, which owns 66% of T-Mobile US, may prefer to sell its stake after US regulations are loosened, sources told Reuters.

item.title: Hong Kong police clear protest barricades, again.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Hundreds of officers removed barriers and tents from a major road in the city's central business district. On Monday, the removal of barricades presaged violent attacks on the demonstrators by masked men. Quartz's Heather Timmons is reporting from the scene.

item.title: Italy is enlisting its army to grow marijuana.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: It's legal for medicinal use, and the government hopes the military can bring costs down.

item.title: More grim news for the euro zone.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: A welter of woeful data was released today, with industrial production across the region dropping sharply, Italy and Spain stuck in deflation, and a key index of economic sentiment in Germany dropping near a two-year low. Finance ministers have been meeting in Luxembourg (pdf) to debate how to kickstart growth in the moribund monetary union.

item.title: 'Tis the season to spend less.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Sales of luxury goods worldwide will rise by 2% this year, the slowest pace since 2009, according to Bain. The consultants blamed slowing spending in China, pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong, and sanctions on Russia. The news came as Burberry became the latest high-end firm to reveal “some softening in growth from Chinese consumers."

item.title: Catalonia calls off its independence vote, sort of.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The restive Spanish region will not hold a referendum on secession next month, its leader said. The controversial vote, which the national government says is illegal, will instead be a "big survey" that won't use the region's official electoral roll. Spain's prime minister called the watered-down plan "excellent news."

item.title: Citigroup is shutting branches in 11 countries, including Japan.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The bank is continuing its pivot away from consumer banking and back to business clients, it announced as it delivered third-quarter results, which beat revenue estimates. JP Morgan, whose results accidentally came out early on a third-party website, beat estimates too.

item.title: Our thirst for oil is waning.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The International Energy Agency says world oil consumption this year will only increase by 650,000 barrels a day—half what it was predicting in June and the lowest in five years. With the price of oil hitting fresh lows today, Europe on the brink of recession, and China's domestic economy slowing down, next month's OPEC meeting will be closely watched.

item.title: Out with Ireland's "double Irish," in with the "knowledge box."
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: An infamous corporate tax rule used by the likes of Apple, Google, and Facebook will be phased out by 2020. But Ireland is already preparing a new way for global firms avoid taxes on intellectual property with a scheme called the "knowledge box."

item.title: Mark Zuckerberg donates $25 million to the fight against Ebola.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The money will go to the US Centers for Disease Control, where it will be used to fight the disease at its source: Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone. Last month, Bill Gates pledged $50 million to the cause, but the United Nations says it still needs $600 million.

item.title: Questions are being raised about the Waldorf changing hands.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The $1.95 billion purchase of New York's Waldorf Astoria hotel by a Chinese insurance company is ruffling some feathers in Washington. US officials fear that the property, which frequently hosts diplomats and heads of state, might see the installation of spy equipment included in the plans for a major renovation.

item.title: Manifest Destiny is still a popular American pastime
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/280635/mark-zuckerberg-is-the-latest-tech-giant-to-buy-part-of-an-island/

item.title: South Korea may have to junk its entire national ID system.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It's been compromised to such an incredible degree—80% of the population, including the president, have had their details stolen via credit-card companies—that the country of 50 million people is considering giving every adult a fresh new ID number. A decision is expected this year.

item.title: When Finns are in trouble, they call in the Swedes.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Finland is faltering, as its paper industry and Nokia-centric tech sector steadily lose ground to rivals. Following a credit rating downgrade, Finnish prime minister Alexander Stubb swallowed his regional pride and commissioned former Swedish finance minister Anders Borg to produce a report with advice for getting back on track.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: "Sweden has managed to set a good example as regards responsible public finances and the economy's growth rate," Stubb said.

item.title: A British-accented parrot lost for years returned to his California owner.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: He now speaks Spanish and calls out for a man named Larry.

item.title: Ugly scenes in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Forty five people were arrested for illegal assembly, barricades were torn down, and pepper spray was used against protestors who refused to move from a busy road in the early hours of Wednesday morning. One handcuffed opposition party member was allegedly beaten by police for four minutes.

item.title: Converse cracks down on copycats.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The shoe maker responsible for the Chuck Taylor sneaker, a high-top basketball shoe introduced in the US in 1917, is taking action against companies in Canada, Australia, Italy, Japan, and China for allegedly selling imitations of its classic design. The sneaker lost popularity as a sports shoe in the 1970s, but later found life as the shoe of rockers, hipsters, and punks.

item.title: New Ebola cases may reach 10,000 per week by December.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The disease is still accelerating in Sierra Leone, Guinea, and Liberia, and the World Health Organization warned that the current infection rate of 1,000 per week could increase tenfold by December 1. Separately, Doctors Without Borders said 16 of its staff have been infected with the virus, and nine have died.

item.title: Renewed PC demand gives Intel a lift.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The chipmaker’s fourth-quarter revenue forecast of $14.7 billion was better than analysts were expecting, as PC sales demand grew. But Intel’s mobile and communications division is still struggling: it reported third-quarter revenue of just $1 million and an operating loss of $1.04 billion.

item.title: A flag-carrying drone causes havoc at a soccer game.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Serbia was hosting Albania in a Euro 2016 qualifying match when a drone flew in with a "Greater Albania" banner, provoking a brawl involving players, team officials, and spectators. The match was canceled.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: This video shows the whole rather frightening scene unfolding.

item.title: AbbVie reconsiders its proposed Shire takeover.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The US drugmaker said it needs to weigh the "fundamental financial benefits" of a £32 billion ($51 billion) takeover of its UK rival, in light of new rules aimed at preventing American companies from headquartering abroad in order to avoid taxes. Shire's share price fell 27% on the announcement.

item.title: Airbus receives its largest-ever order.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Low-cost Indian carrier IndiGo placed an order for 250 short- to medium-haul A320s—the biggest order by number of planes in Airbus’s history. The total value of the deal, which would be worth $25.7 billion at list price, was not disclosed.

item.title: US retail sales fall, but Americans sure do love their gadgets.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Economists were expecting a 0.1% fall in retail sales in September, but the number came in at 0.3% instead. This followed a 0.6 percent August gain. Sales of "core" items—things that aren't cars, food, clothes—fell 0.2%. Sales did jump, however, in the electronics department: 3.5%. That new iPhone may actually be helping the economy.

item.title: Bank of America posts unsurprisingly terrible numbers.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The bank agreed to fork over $16.6 billion to settle its case with the US Department of  Justice and six US states in August (related to toxic mortgage securities), so it isn't shocking that third-quarter profits came in at just $168 million, down from $2.5 billion a year ago. Revenues were down 1%, to $21.4 billion.

item.title: Investors are making a mad dash for the world’s safest bonds right now.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/281361/global-markets-are-genuinely-freaking-out-right-now/

item.title: A second health worker in Texas has Ebola.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Dallas hospital that treated the Ebola patient Thomas Duncan before he died said an employee tested positive after reporting a high fever. Nurses at the hospital say they received flimsy protective gear and were not properly trained to handle the highly contagious virus.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The CDC says the health care worker in question was on a flight on Monday—Frontier Airlines' Flight 1143 from Cleveland to Dallas-Fort Worth—and that anyone who was onboard should contact it immediately: 1-800-CDC-INFO. The disease is still accelerating in Sierra Leone, Guinea, and Liberia, and the World Health Organization warned that the current infection rate of 1,000 per week could increase tenfold by December 1. Separately, Doctors Without Borders said 16 of its staff have been infected with the virus, and nine have died.

item.title: Asia catches Wall Street's whiff of fear.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A momentary panic in financial markets sent stocks plunging and US Treasury yields down below 2%, though the Dow recovered about two-thirds (paywall) of what it lost. It seems fears of a global slowdown are finally hitting home—Japanese stocks were down more than 2% in morning trading, part of a broader Asian sell-off.

item.title: Bono achieves self-awareness
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The U2 frontman admitted to having "a touch of megalomania" after forcing the band's new album on iTunes users.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Bono attributed the misguided decision to release the album that way to a "drop of megalomania, touch of generosity, dash of self-promotion, and deep fear that these songs that we poured our life into over the last few years mightn't be heard."

item.title: Malaysia detains 14 people that it says were trying to join ISIL.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Three of them were allegedly leaders of a cell trying to recruit Malaysians to fight in Syria, including one who managed a Facebook page to attract followers. Since April, 36 people have been arrested for trying to join the Islamic State, and another 30 people are known to have succeeded, according to Malaysian authorities.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: In related news, ISIL is said to be planning an attack on the Ein Al-Assad military airbase in Iraq. And the Pentagon has officially declared a name for the US-led campaign against ISIL in Syria and Iraq: "Inherent Resolve."

item.title: A nuclear fusion reactor that could fit in the back of a truck.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Lockheed Martin says that within a decade, it should be able to make a 100-megawatt reactor that measures just 10 feet by 7 feet—10 times smaller than what's possible with today's technology. A working prototype isn't expected for another five years, however, so don't clear out your truck bed just yet.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://youtu.be/UlYClniDFkM

item.title: HBO is breaking the cable bundle.
item.dc:creator: zachseward
