item.content:encoded: The premium network will start selling access to its internet service, HBO Go, without requiring a subscription to pay TV. Corporate parent Time Warner announced the move at a presentation for investors, hours before rival Netflix was set to report quarterly earnings.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: https://twitter.com/twxcorp/status/522399084511244288

In 2015 @HBO will launch standalone HBO service in the US, will work with current partners & explore models with new partners

— Time Warner (@twxcorp) October 15, 2014

item.title: The US budget deficit hits a six-year low.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Standing at just $483.4 billion, according to the latest figures from the US Treasury Department, this is the smallest deficit as a share of the economy since president Barack Obama took office in 2007. The deficit peaked in 2009 at $1.4 trillion. The Congressional Budget Office said earlier this year that the deficit is likely to start growing again in 2016.

item.title: Workers' attitudes to women bosses have changed since the 1950s, but not a whole lot.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/281349/americans-prefer-male-bosses-even-though-women-are-better-for-business/

item.title: Russia sanctions get more bite.
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz
item.content:encoded: The UK has decided to block a Russian-owned investment fund's €5 billion ($6.4 billion) purchase of a German energy firm with gas fields in the North Sea, the FT reports. (paywall). That's even though LetterOne's owner, Mikhail Fridman, is not one of the oligarchs who is facing sanctios for his ties to the Kremlin.

item.title: Hong Kong protests get a second wind.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A video allegedly showing police beating a pro-democracy politician brought more protestors to the streets, where they attempted to occupy a key road and block a police station. Hong Kong police responded with more pepper spray.

item.title: The richest 1% owns half the world's wealth.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: And if you have a $798,000 in cash and assets, consider yourself one of them.

item.title: Netflix and HBO step into the ring.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Time Warner will offer an online-only subscription to HBO in the US, in an attempt to reach the 80 million homes that have broadband but not cable. The long-anticipated move is a direct threat to to Netflix's online video dominance, and was also a well-timed blow: Netflix released mediocre results for the third quarter and a poor forecast for the fourth, sending its stock down by more than 20%.

item.title: A feverish Ebola sufferer was cleared to fly.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Amber Vinson, the second nurse diagnosed with Ebola in Texas, was erroneously told by US health officials she could fly to Ohio, potentially exposing 132 fellow Frontier Airlines passengers to a risk—albeit low—of contracting the virus. Later today, Dallas will vote on whether to implement a state of disaster in light of the Ebola infections.

item.title: AbbVie put a final nail in the coffin of its Shire deal.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The US drugmaker will advise shareholders to vote against buying its Irish counterpart Shire, after new US tax laws made the $55 billion deal less attractive. The deal initially would have allowed AbbVie to avoid US taxes by moving its headquarters to Ireland.

item.title: The World Health Organization plays down Ebola fears.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Strong health care systems make the chance of a serious outbreak in the US and Europe unlikely, the WHO said, despite isolated cases in cities like Dallas. Separately, the UK sent an additional 91 medics to Sierra Leone to tackle the outbreak there.

item.title: Some bad-ass Dutch bikers are fighting ISIL.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Members of the "No Surrender" gang are reportedly fighting alongside the Kurdish militia near Mosul. Westerners fighting alongside the extremist Islamic State group may be prosecuted by their governments, but fighting against ISIL is apparently ok with the Netherlands.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: https://twitter.com/KoerdenNL/status/520328498632986624

Ron uit Nederland heeft zich bij de Koerden aangesloten om het IS ongedierte te bestrijden. Respect! pic.twitter.com/xES1nmJg8h

— Koerden in NL (@KoerdenNL) October 9, 2014

item.title: Airbnb is largely illegal in New York City.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Nearly three-quarters of the Airbnb listings in the city violate zoning and other laws, according to a report by the state attorney general, with large-scale commercial operators reaping up more than a third of total rental revenue. Airbnb did not dispute the findings, and a spokesman said: “We need to move forward.”

item.title: Hong Kong’s chief executive offers to talk with protesters.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: After a second night of police-protester clashes, CY Leung gave pro-democracy demonstrators three unappealing choices along with one possible compromise—a discussion about the make-up of the Beijing-dominated committee that screens possible electoral candidates.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://twitter.com/JohnSaeki/status/522665705028612096/

item.title: India has no idea how bad its air is.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: New Delhi is the most polluted city in the world, but like most of the country it has outdated pollution detection equipment, so the air quality could be even worse than the official statistics suggest.

item.title: Virgin America made a six-hour commercial.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: It shows an incredibly boring flight from Newark to San Francisco in real time, in an attempt to satirize rival airlines. But the result is a surrealist nightmare worthy of Andy Warhol, according to Adweek.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Brace yourself:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UsMZRl71Zo4

item.title: Monthly-change-in-German-exports-rate_chartbuilder
item.dc:creator: jasonqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: /home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/558/39587363/files/2014/10/monthly-change-in-german-exports-rate_chartbuilder.png

item.dc:creator: jasonqz

item.dc:creator: jasonqz

item.title: ppe_removal.0
item.dc:creator: glichfieldqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: /home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/558/39587363/files/2014/10/ppe_removal-0.png

a:5:{s:5:"width";i:755;s:6:"height";i:998;s:4:"file";s:89:"/home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/558/39587363/files/2014/10/ppe_removal-0.png";s:5:"sizes";a:0:{}s:10:"image_meta";a:11:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:0;s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";s:11:"orientation";i:0;}}

item.title: US-led forces rain down air strikes on Kobani.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Roughly 50 US-led airstrikes during the past 48 hours have killed several hundred ISIL fighters in the Kurdish border town of Kobani, according to a Pentagon spokesperson. Still, the US cautioned that the situation there is still very fragile and that it may fall to rebel forces. If only Turkey would let Kurds join the fight.

item.title: CBS cuts the cord too.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The great unbundling of American TV is underway: CBS will offer a live stream (paywall) in 14 US markets for $5.99 a month, a move that comes a day after HBO announced a similar offering. The catch: National Football League games aren't included in the service, nor are other live sports.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Just yesterday, HBO made a similar move, but didn't provide any details. Its service will launch in 2015 in the US.

item.title: US industrial output beat forecasts for September.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The 1% jump from August was the largest monthly gain in US industrial production since November 2012. The surge was tied to a bump in utilities and manufacturing. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg were expecting only a 0.4% increase.

item.title: Goldman Sachs is in the money.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The US investment bank's net income rose 48% this quarter (paywall) to $2.24 billion, thanks in part to its fixed income trading business and the recovering US economy. The company raised its quarterly dividend to $0.60 a share, a five-cent bump.

item.title: Washington wags its finger at the US response to Ebola.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Congress probed officials managing the country's response to the Ebola outbreak, as pressure mounts on the US Centers for Disease Control and the Obama administration about the disease's transmission in the US. Two health-care workers who treated an infected patient contracted the disease, and one nurse flew on a commercial plane.

item.title: Apple's new gizmos.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The company unveiled a baffling lineup of new iPads, along with a $2,500 27-inch iMac with a 5K display and a $500 Mac Mini. But its most disruptive new product might buried in the fine print: a new Apple SIM card that makes it easier to switch mobile phone carriers.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Among the thoughts of the day:
https://twitter.com/valleyhack/status/522814640091181056

It only took @elonmusk 10 minutes to reveal a self-driving car that goes 0-60 in 3 seconds, and Apple needs 80 min for a thinner ipad?

— Ashlee Vance (@valleyhack) October 16, 2014

item.title: No one's really working on airplanes.
item.dc:creator: qzroya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/282100/how-men-and-women-think-differently-about-airline-travel/

item.title: Why do work in-flight when you can take a terrible nap?
item.dc:creator: qzroya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/282100/how-men-and-women-think-differently-about-airline-travel/

item.title: Starvation fears are complicating the fight against Ebola.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Some patients are leaving West African quarantine zones because of a lack of basic food supplies; the disease has left farms unattended and disrupted supply chains, and as many as 750,000 people are at risk of a famine. Separately, a Dallas health care worker who handled lab specimens of an Ebola patient has quarantined herself on a Caribbean cruise, despite showing no symptoms after 19 days.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: US president Barack Obama said he is open to appointing an Ebola “czar” to coordinate the fight against the disease, while in Europe health officials called for more screening in West Africa (paywall) after suspected cases were spotted in Spain and France. Obama ruled out a travel ban, and much of Europe is undecided about the need for screening in domestic airports.

item.title: Hong Kong lawmakers plan to “occupy” the government.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Pro-democracy legislators may start blocking spending bills if the government does not agree to universal suffrage reforms, one legislator told Quartz. Separately, Hong Kong police largely dismantled another Occupy site, removing barricades, tents, and umbrellas that were blocking a major thoroughfare.

item.title: The last thing the world needs is a scaremongering Ebola TV series—but here it comes anyway
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The sensible advice is do not panic, but producer Lynda Obst and director-producer Ridley Scot aren't letting a global health emergency go to waste. Twenty years after optioning The Hot Zone, they say they've been "quietly" working on adapting the Ebola book for TV for the past year—though the quiet part appears to be over.

item.title: Jimmy Choo gets a mildly positive reception.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Shares of the British luxury shoemaker rose by about 7% in their market debut. Investors are watching the stock closely to gauge interest in IPOs amid European market turmoil.

item.title: Rolls-Royce is the latest bearer of economic gloom.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The bellwether engine-maker said its underlying revenue for 2014 would be 3.5%-4% lower than in 2013; it had previously forecast flat growth. Sanctions against Russia and a deteriorating economic climate will also make 2015 more challenging, it said.

item.title: Israel is building vertical cemeteries.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Pioneered in Asia, the concept has now been deemed kosher.

item.title: Starbucks is increasing employee wages next year.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: That's one of the slew of changes the coffee giant unveiled in a letter to staff. (Another: those with visible tattoos finally allowed to join Starbucks' ranks.) It's an interesting time to raise pay, when you consider how steeply the price of coffee beans has risen.

item.title: The head of the US Federal Reserve might need a raise.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Janet Yellen makes "only" $201,700 a year—her salary is set by Congress. According to documents obtained by Reuters through the Freedom of Information Act, at least 113 of Yellen's underlings earn more than she does.

item.title: $33,300 will get you a Master's degree in mindfulness.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The 36-credit degree program is offered by Lesley University in Massachusetts. You'll learn about meditation and how it can help both your body and your business life. There's also a mandatory one-week silent retreat and internship program at either a local school or hospice center.

item.title: Boko Haram is ready to release those school girls.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: More than six months ago, the terrorist group kidnapped 276 young women. Now it's finally ready to give them up, according to Nigerian military officials. A ceasefire reportedly has been reached, but the exact terms of the release of the hostages has not yet been agreed upon.

item.title: The US gets an Ebola czar.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Ron Klain, former chief of staff for vice presidents Al Gore and Joe Biden, will be put in charge of the US response to the Ebola situation. Klain's responsibilities haven't been ironed out, but US president Barack Obama says he made the appointment now "just to make sure that we are crossing all the t's and dotting all the i's going forward."

item.title: A Chinese investigation results in a VW recall.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The models are crash-prone if a part connected to the rear axle isn't fixed after a rear-end collision. This might not be an issue, except that Chinese drivers typically don't go in for repairs after having an accident (paywall). One million cars were recalled in the US, China, and Germany.

item.title: Obama ushers in a credit card reform—too late to help him, though.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Last month, when the US president was in New York for UN meetings, his credit card was rejected for fraud. "Fortunately, Michelle [Obama's wife] had hers," he said. The story is apt because today, Obama signed an executive order mandating chip-and-pin credit and debit cards for government employees—precisely to tackle this issue.

item.title: Snapchat finally has a business model.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The company behind the self-destructing-messages app notified US users that they soon will start to see advertising in the "recent updates" section of the app. "It's going to feel a little weird at first," Snapchat warned in a blog post explaining why the company has finally surrendered to commercial interests.

item.title: Bring your NRA membership to vote.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The US Supreme Court has allowed a strict 2011 Texas law that requires photo ID—a license to own a gun is acceptable—to remain in place. The state disputes charges that the law targets minorities. The Court has intervened on voting in November midterm elections in four states in the last three weeks.

item.title: Adjusted for inflation, most US families are no wealthier than they were in 1986.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/283059/ninety-percent-of-us-families-are-no-wealthier-than-they-were-in-1986/

item.title: The pope's efforts fall flat.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: The BBC reports that Pope Francis's proposals to promote greater acceptance within the Catholic church of people who are gay or divorced failed to win a two-thirds majority at a Vatican synod. The pope had called the special council last fall to discuss matters involving the composition of families.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Conservative US cardinal Raymond Burke, who has publicly voiced his concerns about the attempts to change church doctrine, told BuzzFeed that he expected to be stripped of his post as chief guardian of canon law as a result of his clashes with the pope.

item.title: The buck stops in Liberia, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf tells Dallas mayor.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz

item.title: Shinzo Abe loses two key ministers to scandal.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Two recently-appointed female members of Japan's cabinet, trade and industry minister Yuko Obuchi and justice minister Midori Matsushima, resigned over allegations of misused funds (paywall). The resignations come as Abe's approval rating has slipped to 48.1%: for most of last year he enjoyed an approval rate around 60%, much higher than his predecessors.

item.title: IBM can't even give its chip business away.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Big Blue has agreed to pay GlobalFoundries $1.5 billion to take its money-losing chip manufacturing unit off its hands, sources told Bloomberg. IBM will receive $200 million in assets to defray the cost slightly, and will receive crucial processors from GlobalFoundries under a new 10-year agreement.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: https://twitter.com/nicksummers/status/524194030079717376

Our 5/22 IBM cover: Everything you need to know about IBM's disastrous announcements today. http://t.co/j2sRGLCzV0 pic.twitter.com/nvhsENgBil

— Nick Summers (@nicksummers) October 20, 2014

item.title: "Outside forces" were blamed for Hong Kong protests.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Chief executive CY Leung cited "participation by people [and] organizations from outside of Hong Kong” for demonstrations that have entered their fourth week. The New York Times reported last week that the Hong Kong government's response has largely been directed by Beijing officials in a mainland luxury resort.

item.title: Joko Widodo was sworn in as Indonesia’s president.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The 53-year-old is the country’s first leader not to come from Indonesia's military or political elite. Two-thirds of the country's parliament is still controlled by an opposition coalition.

item.title: A New Hampshire pumpkin festival ended in a riot.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: "Student revelers" overturned a car and caused extensive damage. Many commentators noted the unrest was characterized much differently than recent violent protests in Ferguson, Missouri.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: https://twitter.com/JamilSmith/status/523726772974522368 https://twitter.com/john_weeks/status/523796727090794496 Earlier this year, HBO's John Oliver poked fun at Keene, New Hampshire for requesting a military-grade armored personnel vehicle, citing a need to protect the pumpkin festival from “the terrorism threat." https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KUdHIatS36A&feature=youtu.be

"Rowdy" is a peculiar word for the rioters at that #pumpkinfest, @cnnbrk. About 30 were injured. How about "violent"? http://t.co/QtqzoADN1D

— Jamil Smith (@JamilSmith) October 19, 2014

Video: #WhiteOnPumpkinCrime http://t.co/i606yoHn6l at #PumpkinFest. Hope Fox News is on top of this. Guard your patch.

— John Weeks (@john_weeks) October 19, 2014

item.title: 2014 does not have any platinum selling artists.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Top-selling artists Beyonce and Lorde are nowhere close to the 1 million sales mark, making it a possible that this will be the first year with no certified platinum artists since the designation was created in 1976. There will be at least one platinum album though: the soundtrack to the Disney movie "Frozen."

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Here is the first certified platinum album, Johnny Taylor's "Disco Lady":
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-3JkEoQ0Cz8

item.title: A bid for Reebok kicks off.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A consortium of investors from Hong Kong and Abu Dhabi will offer $2.2 billion to buy the athletic goods maker from Adidas (paywall), which acquired the company eight years ago for €3 billion ($3.8 billion), sources told the Wall Street Journal. Jynwel Capital and its partners will argue that Reebok would fare better as an independent company, echoing a wave of recent divestitures and split-ups in the tech industry.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: For a reminder of when Reebok used to be cool, here's an ad from 1989.

item.title: The US airdrops weapons to Syrian Kurds in Kobani.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A statement from the US military said the delivery of "weapons, ammunition, and medical supplies"—the first in a month—were from Kurdish authorities in Iraq, and that Turkish authorities had been notified of the drop beforehand. The Turkish government is reluctant to support arming Kurdish fighters in the Syrian border town as it views them as a terrorist group.

item.title: Russia is at war with McDonald's.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Almost half of the 450 McDonald's restaurants in Russia have been hit with either finance or hygiene probes, according to a statement from the company. Four outlets were first targeted in August, apparently in a tit-for-tat move over Ukraine.

item.title: China Mobile’s income falls for the fifth straight quarter.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The world’s largest mobile carrier’s profit dropped 15% to a lower-than-expected 24.2 billion yuan ($4 billion). Internet-based messaging apps like WeChat meant customers spent less on calls and texts, and the company spent more to attract new subscribers to its 4G network.

item.title: Sweden is hunting for a suspected Russian submarine.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Military officials say they are sweeping the seas around Stockholm based on reports of “foreign undersea activity.” It has so far mobilized its largest force since the end of the Cold War to find the ship, which was at one point less than 50km (30 miles) from Stockholm.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: {{unknown}}

item.title: Ctrl-Alt-Del! UK payment system crashes.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: Botched maintenance shut down a crucial part of the country's payment system, which delayed big-ticket transfers between banks and affected house purchases. These payments were processed manually, but thankfully, the system is back up. Card payments and other routine consumer transactions were unaffected.

item.title: Nigeria is officially free of the Ebola virus.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: According to the World Health Organization, no new cases of the virus have been detected for the past six weeks. "This is a spectacular success story," said a spokesperson. Several days ago, Senegal was also declared free of Ebola, though Liberia, Guinea, and Sierra Leone continue to struggle against the disease.

item.title: Microsoft is about to join the smart-watch race.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Forbes reports the software company will launch its own wearable device "within the next few weeks." The watch will last two days on a charge, work with both Android and iOS; Windows Phone should be a given. All that's unknown is its name and price.

item.title: Goldman didn't get the memo about the slowing economy.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: Russian artists slices off a part of his ear.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Pyotr Pavlensky says his demonstration—in public, in the nude—was symbolic, with the earlobe representing individuals who are "segregated" from society by being forcibly put in psychiatric institutions. This isn't Pavlensky's first extreme protest, earlier this year he nailed his scrotum to Red Square.

item.title: You can buy a Tesla in China now—on the internet.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Elon Musk has put the Model S on sale via Alibaba's Tmall.com website. Buyers won't be able to customize their vehicles; instead they'll have a choice of 18 pre-configured models. No word as to when the cars will ship, but buyers are being asked to put down a $8,200 deposit.

item.title: Marc Andreessen steps down from eBay's board.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: He's calling it quits after six years on the company's board. He had argued against splitting eBay and PayPal, and had a public spat over it with Carl Icahn. PayPal will be split from eBay next year.

item.title: Iran is fulfilling its nuclear promises.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: An unreleased report by the International Atomic Energy Agency—seen by Reuters—says Tehran has effectively made 4,100 kg of uranium useless. Its one of the numerous steps the country is taking before a Nov. 24 deadline for an agreement with Western powers about its nuclear program.

item.title: Wall Street versus Silicon Valley just got serious.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: Apple sold a whole lot of iPhones.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The company peddled 39.3 million to be exact, up from 33.79 million during the same quarter a year ago. That's despite the delayed launch of the iPhone 6 in China. Net income hit $8.47 billion, up from $7.51 billion, and revenues rose 12% year-on-year to $42.12 billion. iPad sales are down, however, to 12.3 million versus 13.1 million in the same quarter last year.

item.title: Total's CEO dies in a Moscow plane crash.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Christophe de Margerie and three members of the plane's crew were killed after their plane collided with a snow-clearing machine, according to a spokesperson for Moscow's Vnukovo airport.

item.title: Satya Nadella's karma is in mint condition.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Microsoft chief who recently suggested women not ask for raises but depend on "karma" instead was awarded an annual compensation package worth $84.3 million—mostly in the form of one-time stock awards—making him one of the highest earners in the tech sector.

item.title: Amazon reaches a truce with Simon & Schuster.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The online retail giant said its multiyear deal “creates a financial incentive for Simon & Schuster to deliver lower prices.” Separately, Amazon’s new e-reader goes on sale today, and reviewers say the $199 e-ink Kindle Voyage is the best the company has ever made.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: For those needing a primer on "Amazon vs. the publishing industry," there's a decent roundup here.

item.title: Fish invented fornication.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: New research suggests they did it “sideways, square-dance style” in Scotland, some 385 million years ago.

item.title: The US military wants to play in sandboxes.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: They are equipped with Xbox sensors (video) to create customizable 3D terrain maps.

item.title: China’s GDP growth slows to 7.3%.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Beijing’s carefully managed economic growth statistics (paywall) signaled that it is committed to reining in debt while still trying maintain control. The lowest growth rate since 2009 was still better than expected, providing a small bump to global financial markets, though it could also raise pressure on the government to roll out new stimulus measures.

item.title: Ebola would be more dangerous if it were less deadly.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The virus would spread more widely if it didn’t kill its host so quickly.

item.title: Oscar de la Renta died at home.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The beloved designer, who made classically glamorous dresses for first ladies, socialites, and Hollywood stars alike, was 82 years old. Last week Peter Copping, formerly creative director at Nina Ricci, was appointed as de la Renta's replacement, and was due to begin work in November.

item.title: China's economic statistics are "man made," but they still tell a story.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/284413/chinas-gdp-number-is-a-fiction-but-a-symbolic-one/

item.title: Hong Kong protestors talk with government leaders.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Protestors and government officials are holding their first negotiations as demonstrations enter their fourth week (watch the talks live here). Protestors want to elect their own leader over Beijing’s strong objections; Hong Kong’s chief executive said the city’s residents are too poor to allow direct elections.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius is sentenced to five years in jail.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The South African athlete was found guilty of culpable homicide in the death of his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp. The judge said the sentence was a “balance between retribution, deterrence, and rehabilitation.”

item.title: Oscar de la Renta dies.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The beloved designer, who made classically glamorous dresses for first ladies, socialites, and Hollywood stars alike, was 82 years old. One of the last dresses he made was for human rights attorney Amal Alamuddin, who recently married an actor.

item.title: Nokia no more—it's Microsoft Lumia now.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Less than six months after Microsoft completed its acquisition of Nokia, the company is phasing out the famous Finnish brand. According to a Microsoft statement to The Verge, Nokia France will be the first of many countries to switch to "Microsoft Lumia."

item.title: McDonald's profits have taken a 30% hit.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Americans are choosing to get their fast food from other restaurants, bringing the Big Mac maker's net income down to $1.07 billion, from $1.52 billion a year ago. Sales in the US and worldwide are both down 3.3%—investors were expecting a decline of 2.9% and 3%, respectively. The situation in China and Russia isn't helping.

item.title: Big banks get slapped with fines.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The European Commission has issued a €61.6 million ($78.5 million) fine to JP Morgan for rigging Swiss franc interbank interest rates between March 2008 and July 2009. Four banks—RBS, UBS, JP Morgan and Crédit Suisse—are also sharing a €32.3 million ($42.1 million) fine for fiddling around with Swiss franc-linked derivatives.

item.title: Estonia will let foreigners become "digital residents."
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: For €50 ($64), Estonia will soon let non-Estonians apply for an "e-residency" that gives them a digital identity allowing them do business in the country without actually being there. They'll still need to visit an Estonian police station to get their biometric data recorded, though that will expand to embassies in late 2015.

item.title: A virtual sting operation wins a conviction.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Last year, a Dutch charity invented a 10-year-old girl named Sweetie who was actually a computer animation, and lured 20,000 people into asking "her" to perform sex acts over a webcam for money. An Australian registered sex offender has become the first man to be punished for interacting with Sweetie—a sentence of two years.

item.title: Good luck trying to guess the cheapest time to buy your tickets.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

item.title: One down, two to go—North Korea frees US citizen.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Jeffrey Fowle is on his way home after nearly six months of being detained in North Korea for "anti-state" crimes—he left a bible in the bathroom of a restaurant. Americans Kenneth Bae and Matthew Miller remain in North Korean custody.

item.title: Daimler sells its Tesla shares.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: "Our partnership with Tesla is very successful and will be continued," but it seems the German automaker is more interested in the roughly $780 million it will make from ridding itself of its 4% piece of Tesla. The news isn't surprising given the Daimler CEO's bearish attitude (paywall) towards Tesla's battery "gigafactory".

item.title: Yahoo scrapes through the third quarter.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The tech giant’s mobile operations boosted results after generating $200 million in revenue in the period. Total revenue excluding partner sites was $1.09 billion—1.5% higher than last year and higher than estimates. But as one analyst put it: “To have 1% growth be better than expected says something about Yahoo at the moment.”

item.title: The Washington Post's legendary editor, Ben Bradlee, dies at 93.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Bradlee ran the Post newsroom for 26 years beginning in 1965. He oversaw the uncovering of the Watergate scandal that brought down Richard Nixon and the publication of the Pentagon Papers, which exposed the US governent's secret history of the Vietnam war.

item.title: ISIL may have US-dropped weapons.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The US military is examining a video uploaded by the Islamic State that appears to show its fighters in possession of weapons destined for Kurdish fighters in Kobani. US planes airdropped weapons and ammunition on Monday; a Pentagon spokesperson said the majority ended up in the right hands.

item.title: Taylor Swift's white noise tops the charts.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The singer accidentally released an eight-second track filled only with static, ahead of her highly anticipated album which is due out next week. It immediately became the top seller on iTunes in Canada.

item.title: Total selects a new CEO.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The French oil major held an emergency board meeting to choose a successor to Christophe de Margerie, who was killed in a Moscow plane crash. In fact, it selected two successors—board member Thierry Desmarest will become chairman and Patrick Pouyanné, head of the group's refining and chemicals unit, will become CEO. De Margerie had held both posts.

item.title: Back to square one for Hong Kong protestors.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Live-streamed negotiations between pro-democracy groups and the Hong Kong government failed to find common ground, so protestors marched to chief executive CY Leung’s residence. Meanwhile, anti-Occupy taxi drivers tried to dismantle protest barriers, but were stopped by police.

item.title: 11 EU banks will reportedly flunk their stress tests.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: That's according to Spanish news agency EFE, ahead of the European Central Bank publishing the hotly-anticipated results this weekend. The ECB promptly issued a statement that dismissed the speculation—"no final results have been sent to banks involved," it said.

item.title: Heineken’s wet European summer.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Third-quarter revenue for the world’s third largest brewer rose only 0.2% to €5.1 billion ($6.5 billion) from last year, due in part to a rain-soaked summer that saw Europeans drink less beer.

item.title: Playing chess will shrink your brain.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Don't worry though, that could be a good thing.

item.title: A Chicago voter warned Obama not to touch his fiancé.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The president kissed her instead.

item.title: Drug makers join forces to develop an Ebola vaccine.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Johnson & Johnson and GlaxoSmithKline—fierce rivals in the pharmaceuticals space—will set aside their differences in an effort get an Ebola vaccine out in the field in early 2015. Human trials could begin as early as January. J&J says it can have 250,000 does by May, with an eventual goal of a million.

item.title: Sweden is ready to fire its torpedoes.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Rear admiral Anders Grenstad told the BBC that if the Swedish navy finds a foreign submarine in its waters, it will not hesitate to use weapons to force it to surface. Sweden has been trying to find an unidentified vessel for six days now. Most think it is of Russian origin.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The rear admiral asked the public to help identify the vessel while on the islands near Stockholm by snapping a photo with their phone or camera if they see it emerge.

item.title: Sunken Nazi U-boat found surprisingly close to US shores.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: A German U-576 vessel has been lying next to a US freighter just 30 miles (48 kilometers) off North Carolina's beaches for the past 70 years. Its 45 crew members died after the submarine attacked a convoy of merchant ships, and was sunk in the ensuing battle. Germany asked for respectful treatment, to "allow the dead to rest in peace."

item.title: “Canada will never be intimidated."
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: So vowed prime minister Stephen Harper, speaking from an undisclosed location after a terror attack in Ottawa. Police are looking into Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, the gunman who was shot and killed in Canada’s parliament building yesterday; like a Montreal man who killed a soldier earlier this week, Zehaf-Bibue had been blocked by police from traveling abroad due to fears that he might join a militant jihadist group.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Watch video from when shots were fired in Parliament: https://t.co/8FlaQimx6b

— The Globe and Mail (@globeandmail) October 22, 2014
http://youtu.be/XrGqoISd-do On Tuesday, Canada raised its terror level from low to medium after a hit-and-run incident targeting two Canadian soldiers.

BREAKING: Canada police say a man shot at war memorial, reports of gunfire inside Parliament.

— The Associated Press (@AP) October 22, 2014

item.title: Boeing raised its 2014 outlook—again.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: That would make it the third time this year the airplane maker and defense giant has done this. And it has good reason, too—third-quarter profits came in 18% higher, year over year, to $1.36 billion. Sales in the company's division that handles defense contracts were down 2%, however, due to reduced government spending.

item.title: Labor unrest suppresses growth in South Africa.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The country's treasury was expecting to see economic growth hit 3% this year, but cut the forecast down in February to 2.7%. That number has just been reduced even further to 1.4%, with labor issues—specifically the strikes in its mining and manufacturing sectors—to blame. South Africa's GDP hasn't grown more than 2% annually since the 2009 recession.

item.title: Consequences for the notorious Blackwater shootings in Baghdad.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It took seven years, but today a jury in Washington, DC convicted four former Blackwater security guards who mowed down 14 unarmed Iraqis with machine guns and grenades in a Baghdad traffic circle. Only one of the soldiers—Nicholas Slatten—was convicted of murder. The other three were convicted of voluntary manslaughter, attempted manslaughter and gun charges.

item.title: The 30-year-old Mac business is enjoying its third wind.
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/285063/the-mac-is-back-why-apple-just-set-an-all-time-mac-sales-record/

item.title: A man jumps the White House fence.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The 23-year-old was stopped outside the building by the Secret Service K-9 dog unit, and was arrested and sent to the hospital with dog bites. A similar episode last month led to the resignation of the Secret Service director Julia Pierson; officers were on high alert following the Ottawa attack.

item.title: "Tax inversion" deals aren't dead yet.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: US generic drug maker Mylan will tweak its $5.3 billion purchase of an Abbott Laboratories unit, a deal designed to let it reincorporate as a Dutch company (paywall) and pay lower corporate taxes. In response to new US Treasury rules, Mylan will allow Abbott to maintain 22% ownership of the unit, versus 21% previously.

item.title: Procter & Gamble reshuffles its top brass.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The multinational consumer goods giant announced new leaders across its key businesses and the imminent departure (paywall) of Melanie Healey, the head of its US operations. P&G's US business is its most profitable, but it has failed to regain sales and market share following the financial crisis.

item.title: You’ve been peeling oranges all wrong.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Lop off the top and bottom, and unroll it into an “orange caterpillar.”

item.title: The empty reaches of space are actually quite loud.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: NASA’s SoundCloud account lets everyone have a listen.

item.title: Tesco's profit shortfall gets even worse.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Britain's  biggest retailer said first-half profits were overstated by £263 million ($422 million)—significantly more than the £250 million it warned of previously. Chairman Richard Broadbent announced his resignation.

item.title: Lloyds is cutting 9,000 jobs.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The UK’s largest mortgage lender will announce details of the job cuts along with its third-quarter results next week. The bank, which is about one third-owned by the UK government, said online banking is replacing the need for physical branches.

item.title: A manufacturing bounce in Europe and Asia.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Markit’s preliminary purchasing managers’ index for October was 50.7, higher than last month’s 50.3 and higher than an expected 49.9 (a number over 50 signifies expansion). In China the HSBC/Market preliminary PMI, which assesses small and medium-sized manufacturers, was higher-than-expected also, at 50.4 in October, and in Japan the Markit/JMMA PMI gauge rose to 52.8 (paywall). Markit publishes its PMI data for the US later in the day.

item.title: Kenny G backs down over Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: After risking Beijing’s displeasure by attending protests, the saxophonist now says he was just walking through.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The smooth-jazz musician arrived at the protest site on Wednesday and tweeted a seemingly inoffensive message: “I wish everyone a peaceful and positive conclusion to this situation." Beijing, however, appeared quite upset at this apparent support for the protestors; Kenny G deleted his tweet, but was then accused of letting down those he had met with. https://twitter.com/officialkennyg/status/524980597601497088 https://twitter.com/officialkennyg/status/524980814514122752 https://twitter.com/officialkennyg/status/524981129321779201 https://twitter.com/officialkennyg/status/524981273979129861 Kenny's protestations were picked up by some of the protestors who he spoke with, however, who seemed quite sure the saxonophist was fibbing, and that he did indeed support the protests for greater democracy in the city. https://twitter.com/VivienneChow/status/525200580466065408

I was not trying to defy government orders with my last post. I was in Hong Kong as a stop on my way to perform at Mission Hills

— Kenny G (@officialkennyg) October 22, 2014

And happened to walk by the protest area as I was walking around Hong Kong as a tourist. Some fans took my picture.

— Kenny G (@officialkennyg) October 22, 2014

It's unfair that I am being used by anyone to say that I am showing support for the demonstrators. I am not supporting the demonstrators

— Kenny G (@officialkennyg) October 22, 2014

I don't really know anything about the situation and my impromptu visit to the site was just part of an innocent walk around Hong Kong

— Kenny G (@officialkennyg) October 22, 2014

Protesters took pic w/ #KennyG accused him of lying #OccupyCentral #HK #UmbrellaMovement pic.twitter.com/weNWQkJO0g

— Miss Vivienne Chow (@VivienneChow) October 23, 2014

item.title: General Motors beat earnings expectations—barely.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The car company's third-quarter profit came in at $1.47 billion, 14% lower than the same quarter a year ago. The performance still bested analyst expectations. The company benefitted from more resilient North American customers who bought more cars and trucks at higher prices and made up for big losses in Europe and South America.

item.title: Boeing makes its first sale to Iran since 1979.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The American airplane manufacturer made official its sale of $120,000 in manuals, navigation charts and data to improve the safety of Iran's civilian aviation industry. Boeing disclosed it was doing business with the country in July, thanks to sanctions relief following a long freeze in relations after the 1979 Iran hostage crisis.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: /home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/558/39587363/files/2014/10/01.png

item.title: market-capitalization-jp-morgan-facebook_chartbuilder
item.dc:creator: stefanqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: /home/wpcom/public_html/wp-content/blogs.dir/558/39587363/files/2014/10/market-capitalization-jp-morgan-facebook_chartbuilder.png

item.title: US jobless claims hit a 14-year low.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The number of Americans who filed for unemployment over the past month reached its lowest point in 14 years. The four-week average of jobless claims—a steadier measure than the weekly update—fell to 281,000 from 284,000 the previous week, according to the US department of Labor. Steady US consumer demand has muted firings and buoyed payrolls at American companies, despite slow growth abroad.

item.title: Indians in America are killing it.
item.dc:creator: qzroya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/285610/indians-in-the-us-make-the-most-because-they-studied-the-most/

item.title: Comcast had a solid third quarter.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Excluding a one-time tax adjustment, the US cable and internet provider reported a 12.3% profit jump. Total revenue for the NBC Universal owner climbed to $16.79 billion, a 4% jump from the same period a year earlier (though slightly lower than what analysts expected). Its high-speed internet service attracted more customers than during the same quarter last year, while fewer of its cable subscribers cut the cord.

item.title: America's airlines are on a winning streak.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: United Airlines had a particularly strong third quarter, doubling its profits from the same quarter a year ago. American Airlines not only posted a record Q3 profit, but also predicted a record fourth quarter and full year 2014. Southwest Airlines and JetBlue both shined, too, thanks to through-the-roof demand and cheap fuel.

item.title: Spain's jobless rate drops (ever so slightly) to 2011 levels.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: It's sad when a 23.7% unemployment rate is good news, but that Q3 number is nearly a full percentage point lower than the 24.5% Spain clocked in the second quarter. The Bank of Spain predicts the economy grew 0.5 percent in the period, making it one of the fastest in the region. Still, unemployment remains the second-highest in the EU after Greece.

item.title: Canadian lawmakers carry on after Ottawa shooting.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The country's parliament responded briskly if calmly to Wednesday's shooting in Ottawa, saying it would introduce legislation this week to boost police and intelligence service powers to counter terrorist threats. Lawmakers and public servants were told they could return to work Thursday to maintain some sense of normalcy.

item.title: The end of cable TV is (sort of) nigh.
item.dc:creator: qzroya

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/286099/what-comcasts-earnings-tells-us-about-the-state-of-cable-in-america/

item.title: Paul Allen throws $100 million at the fight against Ebola.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The Microsoft co-founder joins Bill Gates (who donated $50 million) and Mark Zuckerberg (who donated $25 million) on the list of wealthy individuals trying to stop the deadly virus in its tracks. Meanwhile, a health worker who returned to the US from Africa three weeks ago is currently being tested in Manhattan.

item.title: Amazon tests investors' patience.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Shares of the company plummeted in after-hours trading after Amazon posted a 20% quarterly revenue gain, alongside a $437 million loss, its biggest quarterly profit loss in 14 years. Some doubters call the setup a ponzi scheme; others call it the future.

item.title: Microsoft's cloud is booming.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The company's quarterly earnings beat expectations, at $0.54 per share. Revenue was up 25% from a year ago, boosted in part by an 128% increase in cloud services.

item.title: Europe sets a major emissions target.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The EU signed a pact to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 40% from 1990 levels by 2030. Green groups said key aspects of the deal were left vague or voluntary.

item.title: Ebola takes a life in Mali—its first case.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: A two-year-old Malian girl who traveled to Guinea has died from the virus, making Mali now the sixth West African country to record a recent case. Senegal and Nigeria have since been declared Ebola-free.

item.title: AMC took control of BBC America.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The US cable network that is home to “Mad Men” agreed to pay $200 million for a 49.9% stake and operational control of the UK public broadcaster’s US channel. The remainder will continue to be owned by BBC Worldwide, the BBC’s commercial arm.

item.title: Shinzo Abe suffers his third scandal in a week.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: An aide to Japan’s trade minister spent public money at a sadomasochistic sex club and later claimed for it on official expenses. The minister, Yoichi Miyazawa, has only been on the job for three days; his predecessor was forced to resign for misuse of public funds.

item.title: Time to rewrite dinosaur textbooks again.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: To make room for this really ugly one.

item.title: Hong Kong protestors announce a vote.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The Hong Kong Federation of Students will poll members of the public to see if they should accept proposals from the government to establish a platform to discuss future constitutional changes. The HKFS initially rejected the offer after televised talks on Tuesday.

item.title: Sweden calls off its search for a suspected Russian submarine.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: The country’s defense ministry put a brave face on the failed “Hunt for Reds in October,” saying, “people were proud to see our military can conduct a large operation like this.”

item.title: More then 10,000 people have been infected with Ebola.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The spreading epidemic has claimed the lives of almost half of those infected, mostly in Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone, according to the World Health Organization. After a New York doctor came down with the disease, healthcare workers returning to the US from treating Ebola patients in West Africa through airports in New York, New Jersey, and Illinois will now face mandatory quarantine.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A two-year-old Malian girl who traveled to Guinea has died from the virus, making Mali now the sixth West African country to record a recent case. Dr. Craig Spencer, who had been working with Doctors Without Borders in Guinea, was rushed to the hospital in New York City Thursday after developing a high fever, and was yesterday listed in stable condition. City health officials confirmed that he tested positive for Ebola and had traveled around the city in the days before is diagnoses, but said the risk to the public was minimal.

item.title: Resentment and economic envy in Europe.
item.dc:creator: jasonqz
item.content:encoded: The UK economy slowed slightly in the third quarter, but its 3% growth remains the envy of Europe. Meanwhile, British and Dutch officials are incensed at an unexpected call to stump up extra cash for the European Union budget; they say this amounts to punishment for economic success, and is likely to embolden those who want to leave the EU for good.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
Think tank Open Europe has a good explainer of the controversy over EU budget contributions. Its conclusion:
While this does not necessarily seem to be a political stitch up from the EU there is no doubt that it is unreasonable and politically irresponsible. Retroactively taxing someone over 20 years is fundamentally unfair. The fact that the UK and Netherlands are being punished for doing better than expected and better than others almost encapsulates everything that is wrong with the EU’s approach – particularly when the Eurozone economy is struggling to find any growth.

item.title: Cute robots could be the most dangerous.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: Their big eyes encourage people to drop their guard, and their passwords.

item.title: Melanie Griffith grew up with a lion.
item.dc:creator: rmacauleyqz
item.content:encoded: It was part of the most expensive home movie ever made.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Actress Tippi Hedren, Griffith's mother, recently told the Daily Mail she "deeply regrets" letting the 400lb animal sleep in the same bed as her daughter. "We’re dealing with animals who are psychopaths," she said. "They have no conscience or remorse genes, and they will kill you for their dinner."

item.title: Two dozen banks are expected to fail the ECB's stress test.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: An early draft of the document that the European Central Bank intends to publish on Oct. 26 seems to indicate that 25 banks have not met the ECB's rubric for adequate strength in the face of hypothetical financial disaster. About 10 of the 25 may need to raise additional capital to please ECB head Mario Draghi.

item.title: Dead hearts go on to beat again.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: In a major medical breakthrough, Kumud Dhital—a surgeon at St Vincent's Hospital's hospital in Sydney, Australia—has performed three successful "dead" heart transplants. Transplant patients traditionally depend on donors who are brain dead, but with hearts that are still beating. Dhital used hearts that weren't pumping blood for over half an hour.

item.title: Procter & Gamble is dumping Duracell.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: The consumer goods giant plans to split off the battery brand, one of the world's largest by market share. It's likely the biggest part of a plan to shed as many as 100 sluggish product lines, slim down the company, and focus on businesses with growth potential.

item.title: Putin acknowledges he helped a friend.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: When former Ukrainian president Viktor Yanukovych knew he was about to be overthrown, he called the Kremlin. Now for the first time, Vladimir Putin has publicly admitted to assisting him. "He asked to be driven away to Russia, which we did," said the Russian president.

item.title: A computer scientist sets the record for high-altitude skydiving.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Remember when 45-year-old Felix Baumgartner jumped out of a stratospheric balloon back in 2012? He did that from an altitude of 128,100 ft., setting a world record. Alan Eustace—a 57-year-old computer scientist at Google—just broke that record, jumping from a height of 135,908 ft. "It was amazing," he said.

item.title: School shooting in Washington state hospitalizes three.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Law enforcement officials tell the Seattle Times that a male gunman opened fire inside the Marysville-Pilchuck High School cafeteria, shooting four people in the head. Three are in critical condition and undergoing surgery. One is dead. The shooter is also dead in a reported suicide.

item.title: Roku is planning its IPO.
item.dc:creator: stefanqz
item.content:encoded: Sources at The Wall Street Journal don't know exactly when it'll happen, but it'll happen (paywall). The television and TV peripherals company—which last month said it sold more than 10 million units of its set-top boxes—is said to be looking to raise $150 million.

item.title: Some of Europe's banks need more capital.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Around 25 banks in Europe have failed the European Central Bank's latest stress tests, the results of which will be announced officially on Sunday. Though it's not all bad news as 105 have passed, Bloomberg reported. Some of the 25 that failed are Italian and Greek banks, though none are said to be French or German.

item.title: Some European banks need more capital.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Twenty-five banks in Europe failed the European Central Bank's latest stress tests, the fourth time that euro zone authorities have assessed the health of its financial institutions. Those banks need to raise €25 billion ($31.7 billion) to meet the regulator's requirements under "adverse" conditions. Among those with work still left to do, banks in Italy need to raise the most capital to bring their balance sheets up to scratch.

item.title: A boat accident in Zambia kills two dozen children.
item.dc:creator: isenqz
item.content:encoded: Almost all—23 of the 26—people who were drowned when their boat capsized in Lake Kariba were children. The boat was taking people across the lake to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the country's independence from Britain. Authorities blamed the accident on overloading—the boat was carrying 20 more people than its legal capacity.

item.title: The most affordable city for young people is...Paris?
item.dc:creator: isenqz

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://qz.com/286679/the-most-affordable-city-in-the-world-for-young-people-is-paris/

item.title: The IMF says "enough" to low interest rates.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: The International Monetary Fund introduced a floor of 0.05% for the interest rate on Special Drawing Rights, its own currency that it pays to lending nations. The return on the SDR—a weighted average of euros, yen, dollars and the pound—was threatening to turn negative due to the huge amount of global monetary easing.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: While the US is winding down its asset purchases, the euro zone and Japan are still going strong, hitting the value of their currencies—the euro rate was -0.02% and the yen rate -0.01% in the most recent weekly SDR calculations. The IMF's floor is to be introduced as there is no legal basis in the IMF charter for paying a negative rate, a senior IMF official told the FT.

item.title: Retailers switch off Apple Pay.
item.dc:creator: kabirchibberqz
item.content:encoded: Wal-Mart, CVS and Best Buy are among the retailers that have stopped allowing iPhone users to pay with Apple's new service in their stores. The reason is they they have their own e-payments app, CurrentC, which they're trying to launch next year. Unlike Apple Pay, no bank currently supports CurrentC.

item.title: No human help wanted.
item.dc:creator: hlandyqz
item.content:encoded: Two strong themes in manufacturing—the internet of things and the drive to push labor costs ever lower—are leading the industrial sector to develop smart factories, where machinery can fetch, assemble, and even customize products without the need for human intervention. Germany has some of the best examples of where the trends are heading.

item.title: Dilma Rousseff wins Brazil's closest presidential election in decades.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: The incumbent Brazilian president narrowly triumphed over pro-business challenger Aécio Neves, winning 51.6% of the votes with more than 99% of ballots counted. The election was largely seen as a referendum on Rousseff's leftist Worker's Party, which has recently struggled to boost the country's flagging economy.

item.title: New York and New Jersey ease their Ebola quarantine policies.
item.dc:creator: apasickqz
item.content:encoded: Governor Andrew Cuomo will allow health workers returning from treating Ebola patients in West Africa to be quarantined in their own homes (paywall), after intense criticism of New York and New Jersey's mandatory 21-day quarantine policies, which kept a nurse returning from Sierra Leone confined to a hastily-erected tent. New Jersey governor Chris Christie said those not displaying symptoms would also be allowed to spend the quarantine period at their home.
